Gorgeous deep red color with a nice slightly pink head that lasted a bit and left nice thin sheets of lacing.  Aroma is wow out of this world, tons of awesome fresh raspberries, along with sweet tartness.  Flavor is monstrous raspberries, just the perfect definition of what a fruit beer should be like.  Body is light but packed with raspberry aftertaste and a champagne like quality.  You could drink this all day long on any day, but I think it would go best with an outdoor sunday fruit brunch on a brisk autumn day when the leaves are changing color.  Definitely one of the my favorites, and dominating in the world of fruit beers.  New Glarus may have topped all competitors for all times with this and the Belgian Red.  This is about the fifth time Ive traded for it.  Absolute must try.
A very good brew. The scent is nice,  the raspberries are very noticeable. This is a great tart beverage. Its not overly tart & sweet, it has a good balance. Definitely worth trying.

Poured from a 750ml bottle into my Founders snifter. Split with my buddy for his birthday day.

A: Pours a dark purple with nice cherried hues woven throughout, but mainly on the edges. Light pink 1 finger head that lingered for a little while, then instantly dissipated.

S: Very light berries up front and then it sort of morphs into a nice sweetness, almost like a fruit roll-up or fruit by the foot. I pick up a slight bread-like malt on the back end. These smells were all very light and it took some effort to find them.

T: Very nice semi-tart mixed berries up front with a nice dry malt bill. This gives way to a nice sweetness that lingers throughout the middle and back end, just like the nose. Slightly less medicinal than the Belgian Red.

M: Medium bodied with an oily mouthfeel. Coats the palate with a semi-bitter berry. Medium carbonation.

O: While I dont like fruit or vegetable beers, New Glarus has definitely upped the ante and made me at least enjoy them. While I probably wont try this one again, Im glad I did because Im always trying to expand my horizons and if there is a beer that can sway me Im all for it.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 07-24-2011

750ml bottle, thanks dude! Poured into a weiss glass. Pours a redish/copper color with a small off white head. Aromas of raspberry, oak, basement funk, and a bit of spice. Flavor is super mellow and packed with fruit, Vanilla, oak, raspberry, suagar,and finishing tart. Dang fine brew and easy to drink a whole bottle yourself
Bomber. Poured amber with a quarter inch thick cream head into my champagne flute. Aroma is fresh raspberry. flavor is raspberry. Delicious fruit beer.
Sweet raspberry aroma and flavours with a slightly syrupy body. Ruby pour with little lacing.

Enjoyed on tap at Palm Tavern despite the several bottles stowed away in the cellar. Pours a vibrant red-brown with a thin white head with a tinge of pink to it. Smells of berry gummy candy but the taste is not overly sweet. Heavy on raspberry and enough carbonation to tickle the tongue with a very mild, slightly dry finish. One of my favorites, for sure, when I am looking for something fruity and easy drinking.

Bottle.  Pours a clear dark red with a medium lasting off-white head.  Sweet, tart Aroma of raspberries, raspberry preserves, and just a little funk.  Taste is very sweet, quite tart with more raspberries.  Sweet, sticky finish. Medium body, soft carbonation.  Tasty
best fruit sour ive ever tasted by FAR. Flavor mixed with the low abv make it easy to drink all day and very good to pair with a berry cheese cake desert for a night cap.

Into wine glass. Pour is fine--great brown-red color, but more brown than red than youd expect from a fruit sour. Head sits up for a bit but doesnt stick. Aroma is raspberry pastry--sweet and desserty, but enticing. This is balanced in intensity--it has a lot of sweet and a lot of sour, but theyre matched pretty well. Tartness really lingers on the finish. Good lively palate helps reign in the sweetness a bit, too. Overall, nicely put together; still just a bit too sweet for my taste. Could be interesting for pairings.
Great pour with a nice ruby color and some off white head.  So fruity and raspberry but done really well.  Not just flavor added.  Great palate and overall beer.

Bottle. Pours with little head and a nice red color. The aroma is super fruity. The taste is very smooth and a strong raspberry. Very good fruit beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Perfection is a big word. This beer deserves it. This is, bar none, the finest Ive ever encountered. A sweet raspberry core explodes around a grenade of tart acidity that tickles the tongue and never leaves this heavy or cloying. Incredibly thirst-quenching, given the low alcohol. And the beer underneath is top-notch. This is the ultimate refreshing brew for a summer day.
It as a great taste of raspberries. It is a sweet  beer but not overly sweet. Great especially during hte summer.
Tap @ Sour & Bitter. Brownish body with no head. Aroma is christmas, cloves, plums, raspberries. Flavor is spices, tart, raspberries.

Pours a deep murky red with 2 finger head leaving a moderate lacing. Smells strongly of sweet fruits - strawberry and raspberry.  Very sweet up front and mildly sour, balancing out. Medium bodied and moderate carbonation. Medium finish.  Reminiscent of Lindemanns Framboise. Very good.

This one isnt for the masses.  I loved it, but my sister couldnt finish 4 ounces of it.  Its very, very sweet and tastes like a raspberry pie, including the cookie crust.  It has a condensed bubble, cider-like feel (and taste) and a medium body. Its a liquid dessert. The raspberries taste fresh, tart, and not synthetic.

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2012 Wow, super intense raspberries was my first response to the aroma.  The flavor is raspberries, mild sour notes, funky yeast notes and a mix of the three in the finish.  Cant really say theres a fruit beer Ive had thats better than this.

"Thanks to Jon for sharing this.
A: Pretty ruby hue. Mild lacing.
S: Wow! Fresh raspberries. Theres not much else to report. Summertime. Picking them right off the bush. Incredible aroma.
T: This is a masterfully crafted raspberry beer. The aromas hit you as you get the glass close to your mouth, then its raspberry pie in the form of a beer. It is, however, pretty sweet. As good as this is, and I wouldnt want it to change, I prefer sour fruit beers.
M: Smooth, crisp, fresh, light.
D: The sweetness is formidable. A couple of ounces is the perfect amount for me. If you havent had this before, I recommend sharing the bottle with a few other folks."

Draught at Mikkeller Bar, Copenhagen, Denmark. Deep ruby, medium pink head. Very fresh raspberry aroma, with some fudgy notes. Medium bodied, soft carbonation. Sweet with low acidity. A bit of a disappointment with the sweetness and lack of acidity.
Magenta pink with light bubbles. Very raspberry nose, just jumps out at you. Taste is dominated by raspberry with some acidic tartness. Awesome.

Bottle as shown at Camp Beer XI. Pours a cloudy amber with a small paperthin head. The aroma is a strong raspberry and funk. Medium mouthfeel with a strong raspberry tart and sweet finish. Really enjoyed this one. A very impressive fruit beer from New Glarus.
Pours a shiny blood red, aroma is a glorious tart raspberry with some wine notes.  Taste hits you with a nice light bodied carbonated raspberry and it is just awesome to drink.
Thanks jpdurden24! Its wonderful.  The palate is creamy carbonated and lingers. Its sweet but not metallic tasting or too much. the tart flavor balances the beer nicely and the beer is delicious.

bottle (thanks JPDurden24). Pours a clean, ruby reddish brown with a few, light bubbles at the edge of the glass. Aroma of tart raspberries and merlot. Taste starts sweet before a slight tartness kicks in for a light finish. Very light, carbonated body. The blend of sweet and sour makes this one of the best American framboise-style beers I have had.

Big things come in small packages huh? Lovely raspberry sherbert and soft vinious nose. Dark, magenta pour. Big flavours, big body. LOTS of raspberry with a softly tart finish. Sweet and perhaps a little cloying after a while. Great beer to share - I couldnt imagine drinking it all myself. A masterpiece of expression for 4%.

Tap @ S&B. Clear deep red color with a small light cherry head. The nose is super sweet raspberry and cherries, plenty of soft powdered sugar and light artificial syrup. The taste is very sweet raspberry juice concentrate and cherry jam. Red fruits. You cant exactly call this one subtle! The bodys light and supple, amooth and drinkable. Very light carbonation. Overall, tasty but lacks sophistication.

Pours a pinkish red hue with great carbonation but no head. The aroma is mind blowing. So much raspberries, thats really all I can smell its so powerful and amazing. Taste follows the nose, sweet but not too much, not an everyday beer but a great dessert or special treat beer!

Thanks Craig!
Pours deep crimson with fluffy pink head, tart funky raspberries on the nose. Fruit sweetness but also tart character that complements, rounded palate, plenty of carbonation

On tap at Sour&Bitter Copenhagen. Beer in the glass light red, small head. Sweet aroma, a bit moldy, intense hints of cherries. Starts very fruity, modest sourish, more and more moldy. Less fruity finish, still quite moldy. A bit disappointing.

S&B 2012. Pours clear ruby mahogany with a nice off white pinkish head leaving lace. Aroma is sweet sour fresh raspberries and raspberry seeds. Flavor is sweet sourish acidy a bit tart and raspberries; all well in balance, very nice indeed. Finishes sweet raspberry.

On tap at Sour and Bitter: Dark ruby red with a small off-white head. Rasberry sauce aroma, would go well with ris ala mande. Lots of sweet berry syrup in the flavor aswell, not too tart, but the acidity is there. Quite unique this brew.

UPDATED: DEC 8, 2015 Re-rate 12/15: Bottle sample at a tasting at Dancing Camel. Thanks Becca. Deep red. Aroma with lots of natural raspberry juice, a bit candy-ish. Sweet and mildly tart raspberry flavor, somewhat candy-ish. Slightly sticky. Very juicy. A lot better than last time. 8/4/7/3/14=3.6

[5/10/12] Draught sample at Sour & Bitter. Clear deep red color. Aroma is somewhat medicinal with berries. Very sweet berries flavor. Medium-bodied. I was looking to try this for a long time, and its very disappointing. 5/4/6/3/11=2.9

Keg at Sour & Bitter 2012. It pours clear deep ruby, with a thin off-white head. The nose is gummy bears, funky, sour yoghurt, sweet raspberry and strawberry. The taste is sweet-tangy red fruit: raspberry, red grape, watermelon and lime, as well as gummy bears and Ribena, with a tangy, sweet-sour finish. Medium body and average carbonation. A solid tangy fruit beer, which I prefer over the Belgian Red.

Pours mahogany with no head. Aroma is a bit candy like raspberries, raisins, somehow christmas spices and fruits (gløg) and cherry wine. Taste is also a big "gløggish" with some apples, oak, raspberries, candy sweetness, marzipan, and some cherry wine.
Sour & Bitter 2012, Copenhagen. Redbrown beer with an offwhite head. Raspberry,fruity and berries, sweet and sour aroma. Silimar flavour. Fresh nice summerdrink but a beer....?

Sample @ the Sour & Bitter event in Copenhagen. Pours clear dark reddish brown with a small creamy pinkish white head that quickly dissipates without leaving much trace. Smell is sweet and sour with grass, lemon zest, raspberries, burnt sugar and hints of lemon juice and vinegar. Taste is very sweet and sour with lemon zest, orange juice, raspberries, grass, burnt sugar, dark bread, golden syrup and hints of vinegar. Mouthfeel is sticky sweet, tiny tart and medium bodied. Finish is sweet and sour with grass, raspberries and hints of vinegar. Nice raspberry character but its way too sweet to be enjoyable.

Side-by-side comparison of a 750ml bottle from 2010 picked up at the Historic Casanova Liquors in Hudson, WI and a 750ml bottle from 2012 picked up last week at Sadhana Wine Shop in Madison, WI. Both pour a deep brown body with a ruby tint as well as a finger-width, frothy, creamy and slightly fizzy, beige head that dissipate slowly and leave solid lacings throughout. The new bottle is clear and leaves a bit less of a lacing than the two-year-old version. The 2012s aroma is loaded with very bright and fresh raspberries with a light sweetness and tartness. The 2010s aroma is still packed with raspberries and gives off a really nice natural smell, but smells more like an aged jam with a bit more of a tartness mixing with the light sweetness. I get a bit of a rounded, bready pale malt backing as well. The flavors are similar. The 2012 starts with just a light tartness and plenty of fresh raspberries before the sweetness of the fruits comes on nicely with just a light malt feel. Finishes clean and smooth with a light tartness and a really nice, fresh raspberry sweetness that isnt cloying at all. The 2010 starts with a light tartness as well as plenty of raspberries. Not quite as fresh, but still really natural. The sweetness comes along nicely and gives off a bit more of a syrupy or jam flavor, but it doesnt feel syrupy. Finishes clean and smooth with a bit more of a pale malt backing than the 2012. The 2012 seems to have just the slightest hint of hops in the finish making it a bit more crisp than the 2010. Both leave lengthy aftertastes following very smooth, medium-light bodies giving off a somewhat creamy feel and light carbonations. Overall, this is pretty straightforward, but its a really enjoyable and impressive fruit beer. Tons of fresh raspberries with a light sweetness and tartness that are nicely balanced throughout. The raspberries hold up really well in a two-year-old bottle, although I think I like the fresher bottle better. Never cloying and very natural. Great beer.

Fad: Har fået et nøk op sammen med belgian red. Overrasket over de var på fad og havde ikke forventet så søde øl. Rødbrun med et lille skumhoved. Igen duft af tyggegummi og en lille smule hindbær. Nærmest ingen syre, men faktisk en fin sommerøl igen.

Very much a lambic without geography requirement, but excellent. Very bitter and sour, much like a raspberry. Almost overwhelming sour, but smooth palate made it a lighter drink. Pours amber gold, not red as expected.
Sour and bitter 2012. Amber beer with a beige head. Raspberry aroma, sweetish, sourish, fruity, berries. Sweet raspberry flavor, sugary, fruity, too sweet.

Tap @ S&B thanks to lortsker. Nice deep amber mahogany pour, head dissipates within few seconds. Aroma is like a mix of raspberries and cherries, very sweet and a bit artificial and candy like. A bit of irony feel which seems odd. Other than that, the aroma is actually very pleasant. Taste is very much like the aroma - sweey and fruity, particularly raspberries, which still come off candy like. A bit of cinnsmony spiciness and a nice tart edge to the finish, which rounds the beer off very nicely. Better than the Wisconsin Belgian Red, I think.

Tap @ sour bitter! Pours deep ruby, reddish, no head , Aroma: sweet tart raspberries, marmelade , red wine, berries, vinous, malled wine, glögg, cherries, acidic,  honey, oak  Taste: deep fruity sweetness, raspberries, red berries, red wine,tart, malty sweet,  vanilla, oaky, candy, gummy bears, quite sweet, very refreshing! Nice!

From the bottle. Powerful Raspberry aroma with some tart characteristics.
Jam like sweetness levels on the palate with an underlying tartness, overall not too tart and the sweet Raspberry dominates the palate, lingering finish.

Poured from 750 to brandy snifter...

Pours a hazy ruby/gold with a short-lived white finger of head. Average lacing and no discernible beading.

Smell is incredibly tart - sweet fruits, mild honey, fresh cut grass, pleasantly one dimensional.

Taste is massive. A cubic fuck ton of raspberries, some lemon, piercing sour undertones, a curious mix of flavors that doesnt overwhelm the senses.

Drinkability is rather high, given the aggression of the raspberry bite. It remains light and and sweet, without moving into the dessert category.

Originally reviewed: 11/3/09. Poured into my flute glass. Pours a tawny-tinted ruby with a thick light-pink head on top. Great retention. Leaves some lace spots on the glass. Scent is of cherries, raspberries, fresh bread, and a very light grassy tone. 

Crisp body due to a moderate amount of carbonation. Semi-spritzy, but in a good way. Complements the style superbly. Flavor is unsurprisingly of tart red fruits. Tastes like a cherry cobbler in a glass. Bitterness is absent. Nice sweet finish. Though it is tart, it is not puckering in any way. Just a well-made beer here. I want this on my table for every Thanksgiving and Christmas from here on out. Highly recommend.
Smells like raspberries.  Beautiful red color.  I think its a little too carbonated, but other than that I could sip on this all day!

Amazing. 

Pours ruby red, aroma of raspberries, candy cane and subtle tartness. Flavour of raspberries - thats it. Not cloying at all. Perfectly done. Amazing and gorgeous! Sadly would be higher if it was a DIPA or Imp. Stout. Im Style-ist.

Crazy crazy crazy sweetness to this one, highly recommend sharing the bottle at min 4 ways. I felt a sick after sharing 2 ways, But the flavour was very raspberry like and the finish was very nice, this one was very easy drinking and it was enjoyable, just super sweet

Poured a deep ruby, with a frothy pink head. Aroma is very sweet with smells of raspberry, cherry, tartness, and a hint of vanilla. Taste is very sweet with cherry, big raspberry, and a medium tart finish. I am loving the taste of this beer and it is leaving my lips tingly. Delicious and I will definitely seek this one out again.
Pours a dark reddish color with a cherry colored head. Nose is all raspberry. Taste is also stron raspberry flavor. Lightly carbonated and easy to drink. Medium bodied.

750 ml bottle. Thanks to mashmaster for this one! Deep red, clear liquid with small to medium light brown head. Aroma of fresh raspberries, red berries, wheat, more raspberries, raspberry soda, oak and cranberries. Taste is medium sweet, light tart and not bitter at all. Lots of notes of rapsberries. Medium bodied with nice carbonation. Really good. Refreshing and lots of raspberry flavour and aroma.

Bottle. Pours a clear electric ruby maroon with a two-finger, bubbly off-white head that dissipates quickly, leaving outrageously beautiful lacing down the sides of the glass. Aroma of fresh raspberry jam spread on warm toast, malts, dark cherries, plums, cranberries, and slight notes of honey and orange marmalade. Thin bodied with a fizzy, soda-pop sweet and crisp mouthfeel. Tons of fresh, sugary raspberry tarts and smooth vanilla cream in the finish. Not much alcohol, but theres no reason to burden these delicate aromas and flavors with any additional components. Overall, this far exceeded my expectations, even with the accompanying hype. You really need to try this beer yourself to appreciate it. Amazing.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2012 A - pours brown tinted very cranberry red with some tight bubbles pink/white head. S - aromas of cranberry up front. Notes of cranberry juice and malts. M - tangy high carb medium bodied brew. Lingering sweet tangy end. Lightly syrupy. Very nice. Juice like, not too sticky. T - raspberry and cranberry cocktail through out. Hints of apple and vegetal notes. Malts and hints of yeast as well.  O - very good fruit beer. Clean and drinkable. Much like a fruit juice. A bit more complexity would put this into a whole other tier. 7+\8-

Bottle courtesy of James at his shindig. Dark red pour, light red head. Aroma and palate of fresh berries. Very tart; approaches sour but stops tastefully well short. Incredibly fresh tasting with "natural" tasting sugars. Would love to have an entire bottle to myself sometime.

A - Pours a opaque ruby with a touch of brown in it and a thin finger of pinkish bubbly head. The head fades down fairly quickly leaving behind a little head.

S - Aroma is full of lots of fresh sweet raspberries. There is a bit of tartness with a bit of sweet caramel as well.

T - Starts off with lots of sweet and tart raspberry flavor with a bit of sourness and a bit of other berries. Through the middle, a touch of caramel comes through with some more fresh fruit flavor. The finish is a mix of tart and lightly sour fresh raspberry with a hint of yeast.

M - Medium bodied with fairly mild carbonation. Very smooth with a tart and dry finish.

D - Very drinkable. The raspberry flavor is very fresh and rich and works so well in the beer. The strong tartness is excellent as well.

Copied and pasted this review which I did for Belgian Red.  With the exception of substituting raspberries for cherries it is the same beer.  750 bottle.  Ruby red pour with an average head that quickly disipates.  Nose is lots of cherries and some yeast and grain.  Taste is one of the best of any style.  A cherry malt bomb that is sweet but with a nice tartness on the back end.  Better than sparkling wine (which many compare it to) as the malt cuts into the sweetness very nicely.  Absolutely need to get a bunch of these.

Purchased Jan 2011 at Woodmans in Oak Creek, WI, price $7.80. 2,400th Rating! Pours a pinkish brown in a small sampling chalice, ring of foam. Smell is sweet raspberry juice, nothing else in the way. Taste is raspberries in cream with just a little bit of tartness on the side. A very slight hint of barnyard flavor based on the spontaneous ferment in wood. My previous rating was for a gluten-free raspberry brew, but this one still keeps in beer heritage with slightly thick malt, more in the mouthfeel than on the palate. I ask the same question I asked with my first Dark lord: is this really worth all the fuss? I agree, it may be the best fruit beer you can find, and its different than any other fruity alco-pop.

From notes.  First reviewed 12/13/2010.  Poured from a 750 mL bottle into a tulip.

Raspberry Tart pours a murky deep ruby cherry color with a fluffy pink head. 

Just a ton of raspberries wafting up into the nose. Sweet and tart, just how a bowl of mashed raspberries smells. Pretty awesome.

As the beer rolls over a new spot on the tongue, the flavor moves from sweet, then tart raspberries. Very robust and accurate portrayal of raspberries. Slightly tangy toward the end. 

Crisply carbonated so the bubbles dance on my tongue. Smooth, medium feel, which complements the taste really well. Sticky and just a touch syrupy -- really the only negative thing I can say about this beer.

This gets a strong score from me because of the great raspberry taste. I am extremely tough on fruit beers, raspberry in particular, and this is a great one. This is a situation beer though, perfect to pair with a dessert or brunch.

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2012 Conception impeccable du début à la fin. La robe est rouge sang, immaculé et translucide. Arôme de framboise très mûre avec une légère acidité vineuse. Elle se déverse dans le palais comme une confiture maison encore chaude, immensément riche et mâchable. Un voile crayeux et surette dune douceur absurde enveloppe sans effort son corps. Une petite bière avec un profil gustatif plus près dun riche vin à dessert italien. À tous les points de vue époustouflant.

Bottle thanks to BrainLair.  Clear brick-red pour with a light tan head.  Extremely fresh raspberry aroma.  A bit tannic.  Slightly sweet at first but finihs of good dry and tart.  Fresh raspberry throughout.  Nice beer.
excellent example of a fruit beer done right. raspberry flavor from start to finish with waves of sweetness and tartness. crisp, light and refreshing.

Bottle. Pours clear red with a thick off-white head (red tint); good retention and lacing. Aroma is heavy raspberry, sugar, and other sweet notes. Flavor is dominated by esters, with faint malt and hops; sweet finish. Medium body, carbonation, and warmth. Amazing beer all around.

Dark ruby with big, foamy, pink head / Big, bright, nose of candied fresh raspberries / Light to medium body, lively carbonation, very sweet but tart and not cloying, with good finish / Flavors are just like the nose - candied raspberries and dark berries / I dont if I would order this, or when, but it is very well done.  The best of its kind that I have tried, without comparing to lambics.  Might be nice shared with a fruit dessert, or a green salad with a light vinaigrette.
Shared bottle with Timfoolery. Poured a dark red color and of course, smelled of raspberries. I could drink a ton of this and probably forget theres alcohol in it. Great fruit beer.
Absolutely delicious.  The name Raspberry Tart says it all.  It literally makes my mouth water.  Champagne-like mouth feel.  Very good sparkling fruit ale.

Poured from a bottle into a becher. Beer is about what you expect as far as color, looks red and hazy, forms a white head made up of medium to small bubbles. Head falls away leaving lacing on the glass. Beer looks good.

Aroma is full of raspberries and sweetness.

Beer is sweet and full of tartness from the raspberries. Medium to low body, lots of carbonation on the palate. Sweetness is up front and the tart is in the back of the mouth. Beer finishes rather cleanly and there is no aftertaste. Its a very pleasant experience and I love drinking this beer. If raspberries are your thing, I would check this out totally. Drinkability high, good mouthfeel.

750 mL bottle.  Pours a coppery, slightly pink color, with an off-white head mixing orange and pink.  Raspberry aroma, some funkiness, light tartness.  Juicy raspberry flavor mixes with toasty malts, some tartness.  Juiciness makes it seem sweeter than it actually is.  Quite well done, nicely balanced.

25oz bottle.  Ive had this one many times, cracked the most recent at new years.  Pours a beautiful light red hue, rich raspberry tones with a pink frothy head.  Aromas are ripping ripe raspberries with a hint of acidity making my nose dance.  Palate is very light as the ABV indicates and the fruit hitting right up front spreading through the mid and the tartness hitting the edges gracefully.  Its like candy, really delicious.

(Bottle) Pours red with small off-white head. Authentic and fresh aroma of raspberries. Reminds me a bit of raspberry pie and Swedish fruktkräm. The nose doesnt have much that reminds me of beer, maybe a touch of malt. The flavour is near medium sweet and light acidic. No bitterness. The mouthfeel is light sticky and juicy with a light carbonation. Light to medium bodied. Throat burn-like aftertaste from the raspberry seeds. A raspberry bomb with too little beer taste if you as me.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2012 From the 1/2012 3R6P tasting. This is the first beer that I have had from this brewery and one that I have been eager to try for quite some time. I was not disappointed. +++ Sampled from a 650 ml brown bottle this beer poured a dark red-brown color with a medium sized beige head that faded quickly and left decent lacing. The aroma was tart sugar and raspberry.  The flavor was very tart yet sweet very strong raspberry jam with a nutty honey undertone. The finish was very long tart and tangy raspberry jam, bread and honey. Fairly full bodied. Excellent.

Tasted on 1/1/12 from a waxed and capped 750mL bottle purchased at Discount Liquor, probably around 18 months ago.  Pours cloudy amber red with an average beige head that recedes to nothing more than a thin collar of lace.  The nose is tart and dusty raspberry with some raspberry syrup sweetness and a touch of light malt.   The flavor is more syrup sweet than the nose, with the tart, dusty notes underlying, and just a hint of some light malts.  The body is medium with a syrupy texture, medium carbonation, and a long tart and sweet raspberry finish, and some tannin.

Bottle (trade with arkurzynski - huge thanks).  Tart raspberry and malt aroma.  Hazy reddish brown color with small head.  Sweet-tart raspberry and light malt flavor.  Tasty - sweet without being cloying.

Bottle from trade. Amazing aroma of raspberries and sweet fruitiness. Flavors of tart raspberries and sweet funk. Rang in the new year with this beer. Excellent beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours brownish red with tiny fizz. Smells like raspberries with a touch of woodiness. Tastes like raspberries. Medium-bodied with a sticky texture and lots of mouth-carbonation, New Glarus Raspberry Tart finishes with mild tartness, from the raspberries.

Ruby amber with an off white head.  
Smells like raspberry.  
Tastes like sweet raspberries.
Finishes with a pleasant tartness.
Very tasty.

750 mL bottle.  Pours a dark ruby red with a medium, pinkish head with little retention.  Aroma is almost entirely of raspberries.  Medium body and the mouthfeel is champagne-like carbonation. Flavor is fruity; sweet raspberries at the beginning with the finish becomes tart.  It lacks the breadiness of Belgian Red, which takes away some of the complexity and depth of flavor.  Overall, the beer is very drinkable and refreshing.
Smells wonderful. The raspberry is simply amazing. This bottle had a few months on it and was sweeter and more pronounced than before. Great brew, and cant wait to get more.

750mL bottle, pours a mostly clear ruby red with a small beige head. Aroma is pure raspberries, candy cane, subtle tartness, but the sweetness overtakes. Flavour is pure raspberries, raspberries and more raspberries - what else is there to say? The sweetness is not cloying, the tartness is almost non-existent, and the balance is perfect. For the style, this is phenomenal. Immensely enjoyable.

On draft at Sugar Maple. Pours a deep, ruby red color with a thin pink head.  Aroma is fruity, raspberry, nothing else. Medium on the palate, with soft, champagne-like carbonation. Flavor is sweet, fruity, raspberry, with a sweet-tart finish. A bit easier to drink than Belgian Red, but equally interesting.  A work of art.

Raspberry dominates the flavor, aroma, and overall character.  This mightve been a bad thing, had it not been done well.  As it is, this is probably the best fruit beer, save maybe their cherry variant, Ive ever had.  Tart, sweet, with a hoppy foundation.  Tried in Wisconsin on the way to Josh and Angies wedding in Green Bay, 2010.

750 ml bottle
There were notes of raspberry, spices, sweet berries, and some malts. I felt the aroma was one dimensional, raspberries were the only thing I could smell, however the raspberries were well done. A very enjoyable beer.

Pours a translucent, deep, pinkish rose.  Nose is floral,perfume, and sweet raspberries.  This is a really nice fruit beer, but it isnt nearly as "tart" as the label would suggest.  Raspberry and floral notes dominate, with a bit of strawberry, but the flavor is really more sweet than tart or acidic.  For that reason, I much prefer the Big Red, with its nice balance of acidity.

GABF 2011.  Clear reddish with a small off-pink head.  Amazing tart raspberry aroma with a sweet, slightly sour lambic quality to it.  Taste was delicious tart raspberry, a touch of slightly sour cherries, sweet fruitiness...couldnt taste much hops or malt.  No worries.  Ends dry and slightly sour.  Big body with a long linger, and slightly boozy.

Bottle shared with the Mane Liquor crew. Pours a dark pink, almost mahogony, with a large, fluffy light pink head. Nose resembles raspberry champagne - mass amounts of raspberry with some bread notes lingering behind it all. Loads of raspberry in the taste with slight oak and tarty fruits. Perfectly mixed. Finishes with some light bread and biscuit notes. Resembles a raspberry tart which has been thrown in a blender. Unbelievable beer

Shared 750ml bottle with 6 people. Poured a ruby red color, pink/white small but foamy white head. Aroma was raspberry, tart fruits, not much else. Flavor was tart raspberries, berry sweetness. Fantastic.

22oz bottle been saving for what?  who knows but popped the top last night and it poured out a reddish/purple color with lacing that hung on the side of the glass. no head to speak of..the flavor is of raspberry and some tartness that is perfectly blended together...this is a fantastic beer..

Pours red with slight fizzy white head. Aroma is raspberrys and lots of them. Lots of carbination, almost like champagne. Taste is extremely fresh raspberrys, oak and slight hops. Very, very tart stuff. Its like drinking candy. Amazing.
UPDATED: OCT 17, 2011 Strong raspberry flavor and aroma. Just a slight taste of malt.  Very sweet, would not want a bottle to myself.
The raspberry couldnt ask for a better representative. Show cases all the great qualities of the fruit and the brew. Love it. Crisp, sweet and tart. Color is ruby. Refreshing.

Rust colored pour with thin to no head. Obvious raspberry nose with hints of malt. In the mouth, crisp, with raspberry and a sweet maltiness. Pretty much like a rasberry desert in beer form. Gotta be in the right mood for this one.
Raspberry aroma.  Pinkish-amber in color with a pinkish head.  Raspberry tartness and fairly sweet.

Finally got to try this baby. Huge raspberry nose, slightly tart, pie-like and jammy. Fruit is only joined by a bit of piecrust. Deep red with lace. Lovely raspberry flavor, sweet and tart. Nothing at all like beer. Barely fermented, a touch of wheat. Delicious, for sure, nicely tart and tangy. Too sweet, though, and 0% beer-like. Really glad I got to try it, though probably wont go looking for it again.
Its all about the raspberries with this beer.  I like raspberries so this beer is a winner.  Reddish tinge with small head and much deliciousness.
Pours a dark red with a bit of pink head.  Aroma is raspberries...go figure.  Taste is slightly sweet, slightly tart with lots of raspberries.

Bottle, as pictured.  Pours a clear, dark red with minimal white-pinkish head.  Smells strongly of tart raspberries, as youd expect.  Really good, doesnt even taste like beer at all.  Really superb.

Bottle courtesy of northernbrews.
Pours brilliant red in my snifter with a large pink head that leaves no lacing. Aroma is full-on raspberry, with a sweet maltiness in the background. Body is light & crisp. Flavor is also huge tart raspberry with a little bit of smooth maltiness in the background. Could drink this all day!

Pours a deep rosey color with a medium pink head...lively looking.  Aroma has fresh raspberry, earthy and musty notes, a hint of a grape smell...slightly winey.  Flavor lives up to the name...loaded with fresh raspberry and a crisp tartness...bit of that hallertauer spicy pop subtley creeps in.  Mouthfeel is lively and champagney with a tart, dry raspberry finish that is more earthy and vinous than sweet.  Outstanding beer!

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2011 If your like fruit beers, this beer is for you! It smells and looks like finely pureed raspberries. Very sweet and syrupy. Would be a great beer to serve with dessert, and possibly as a beer float if your into that kind of thing. A good beer to serve to wine fans.
Old Gabf. Orange with tan head. berrry sweet and caramel like a dessert sauce. Flavor follows berry/sugar syrup sauce ending quick dry and sweet.
UPDATED: MAY 25, 2012 Wonderful.   Truly great.  I dont usually care for fruit beers, but damn!  This si great stuff
Maybe the best tasting drink ive ever had.  Just amazingly tasty with super dominant raspberry flavors throughtout.  Nice sweetness and light oaky flavors.  This is what a fruit beer can taste like.
Pours a ruby/slightly pink color with a foamy white head.  Strong raspberry aroma.  The flavor was sweet and fruity with a dry finish.   Tasted like a wine or flavored soda, but still very enjoyable.

Ok so this is perfect. Pours dark red. Nose is complex elegant raspberries. The flavor, intense decadent raspberries with a complex tartness. Flavor for tart, raspberries, tart again with an late second after taste of raspberries. Fuck yea.

Thanks to cmillward.  A definite step up from the Belgian Red, but I still dont quite understand all of the praise.  Pours a transparent brownish ruby with no head, just a light smattering of bubbles on the surface, at first.  Aroma is a nice mix of band-aid, juicy raspberry and earthy almost-funk.  Theres less sweetness than the Red, which I appreciate, but still a bit too much, and a similar cough syrup note pops up in the taste.  Mouthfeel is a bit syrupy, probably a shade less than the Red.  Its a beer that I sorta enjoy but couldnt handle, much less want, anything more than a small glass.  Its probably a good choice for blending with stouts, if you want to explore that.

750. Pours a nice bright but deep red with a small off white froth. Aroma of super aggressive and sharp raspberries. very real, not candy and very sweet n sour with a beautiful bouquet of floral and herbal hops. Flavor starts with a nice sharp raspberry crisp tartness, amazingly refreshing super sharp and perfectly balanced, finishing crisp and tart. Medium body and a sharp[ carbonation. Awesome stuff
750ml bottle. Ruby red, partly hazy, red tinged off-white head. Big raspberry nose, sweet, hint of tart, short but dry finish. Glad I split the bottle - a third was about the right amount.

Cloudy reddish pour with a small white head. Aroma jumped out of the glass, packed with huge raspberry. Legit as can be. Flavors were also jam packed with raspberry goodness. Quite sweet with a light tartness on the finish. So, so, so decadent. The ultimate desert beer. Really a one of a kind. Mouthfeel was a bit syrupy yet smooth. Mmm this is good stuff. One to be shared.

750ml Bottle poured into a shaker glass.  The beer pours a reddish brown that is cloudy and capped by a thin pinkish white head despite a vigorous pour.  The aromas are amazing, straight up raspberry, smells like jam tastes.  Taste is sweet for sure, almost too much so, but there is a tartness that kicks in to balance things out on the finish.  Body is light to medium, with average carbonation.  A very good summer brew, overall.  I would drink this very cold.

Bottle from a trade with MIBRomeo. Pours dark reddish pink color with pink head. Aromas of sweet raspberries. Sweet raspberry flavor with some tartness. Medium body with average carbonation and a syrupy mouthfeel. Really nice desert beer. Thanks Chuck.

This was a welcome palate cleanser after starting with the Estrella Dame. The aroma is fruity with bubbly freshness that aerates around the glass. One could have easily mistaken my Tart for a glass of champagne. Then came the taste. Amazing! I could easily have drank 4 or 5 more of these. You could taste the raspberries, but the taste was not overpowering. The next time I am in Wisconsin I am bringing some of this back home.

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2011 Date: July 15, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: Discount Liquor, Waukesha, WI Appearance: Cherry red with hint of purple and thick head. Aroma: Raspberry and sweet. Flavor: Consistent with aroma, slight carbonation but very smooth, sour finish. Other: a very different kind of beer, good but not something you could drink a lot of in one sitting.

Location/Date:Bottle split with Dave on 7/12/2011.
Appearance: Pours a dark red-black.E 
Aroma: Aroma is very full of raspberry.
Taste: Mostly raspberry, some tartness at the end, maybe a hint of hop.
Palate:Quick finish, light fizz.
Summary: A tasty fruit beer although one glass was enough(it is almost a desert), and at times I found it hard to believe what I was drinking was in fact a beer.

Dont know much about fruit beers but figured I would give this a go when I got a shot.  Very impressed.  The aroma is amazing and it looks and tastes nothing like beer.  Mostly it tastes like fruit, raspberries of course.  Its very drinkable, not too sweet, and quite refreshing.  Try it if you get a chance!
Hazy red amber color/ ivory sheen. Raspberry skin, woody, seedy aromas. Light to medium bodied. Very nice sweet tart raspberry juice, lemon, wheat, caramel flavors
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Thanks to bobbypaulson for this very nice trade. As I pour this into my flute glass the huge pink head cascades into an amber liquid, it reminds me of something poured from a nitro tap. Smells of musty raspberries, fresh pastery, oak, and hay. Light on the mouth, sweet raspberries, fresh pastery dough, some woodiness, light carbination with a touch of tartness the end.

Pours a deep mahogany red with a full pink head.  Smells of fresh ripe raspberries, vinegar, raspberry pie, syrup, pie dough, and sourness in the nose.  Wow!  What flavors!  Rich raspberry pie, dough, sourness, earth, stale and paper-like hops, with a tart finish.  Fairly lively mothfeel.  Perfectly like a raspberry tart.

Pours ruby red with a small head. Nose is pretty one dimensionally sour with absolute loads of fresh raspberries. Flavor is sweetly raspberry candies  and lemonade like tartness. Really this is a good beer but not for the sour lover. Just a step up from lindenmans or however its spelled. Wheres the Brett? Wheres the super lactic sourness?

750 ml bottle thanks to ekoerper, poure a red cloudy hue and a thin reddish head.  Aromas of raspberries and a sweet fruit.  Lightly crbonnated so doesnt over power the palate, and a nice flavor of raspberry, that was surprisingly not overly sweet.  A really good beer and lived up to the hype.
Aroma is subtle brown malts and lots of raspberries. Super sweet and sugary. Raspberry flavor all over the place. Again, not my thing but definitely a solid fruit beer. Exactly how it should taste.

Pours a blood red color with a tall bubbly pink head that fades down quickly to reveal large bubbly carbonation popping at the edge of the liquid and air. Aroma is very sweet and full of fresh raspberry goodness. A very mild tartness can be had on the nose late and is overall pretty sweet. Flavor starts with a very pronounced raspberry presence and some mild tartness very late. The sweetness is perfect though as its very well balanced and not overpowering. Body has a modest heaviness to it. Great feel really comes from the high carbonation rate and big gas bubbles it produces. Overall a fantastic beer. Picked up fresh from the brewery and a brew I cant wait to have again in the not too distant future.

This is a near-perfect fruit beer and my current second favorite after New Glarus Belgian Red, a cherry beer.  It has strong raspberry aroma and great red, cloudy appearance with a good pink head that rapidly dissipates.  Is all natural and tastes very fresh as if the raspberries were picked the same day you drank it!  The one year aged hops complement the beer well.  It has appropriate sweetness and tartness in its consumption.  It is nearly perfect being slightly more acidic than my tastes once in a while.  Excellent fruit beer in all ways that represents raspberries really well.  Was 2nd best fruit beer in the world in ratings recently.

[1pt 9oz bottle courtesy of cgarvieuk] Foaming red pour, perfectly clear. Looks an absolute picture. Smells exactly like raspberry juice  tremendously fruity on the nose. Tastewise, raspberry dominates, as youd expect. Its pretty sweet  only getting slightly tart on the finish, but never sour. Incredibly drinkable  the taste reminded me of a raspberry mivvi (obscure British ice cream reference there). Dry, slightly tart finish really helps, cuts through the sweet raspberry juice beautifully. Having said all this, I doubt I could polish off an entire 1pt9oz bottle however [02062011]
Too sweet for me. Te beer pours a beautiful clear amber-orange. Heaps of raspberries on the nose and palate. A little tart but not sour (thanks Craig for pointing this out!) Not for me.

2 June 2011, bottle at one of CGarvieuks legendary tastings! dark rose colour in the middle w/ amber around the edges, clear w/ no bubbles. amazing nose! super strong raspberry nose but it doesnt smell artificial. sweet raspberry aroma with the bitterness of raspberry seeds. such a great aroma! body is thick and a bit syrupy w/ just a little carbonation. reminds me of a softly carbonated fruit juice. Not sour but tart. however, the sweet syrupiness balances it perfectly. this is the best fruit beer ive ever had. lovely raspberry flavour w/ no competition.
bottle shared by murphym45... Arouma is lots of berry tart. Huge sour profile, sweet berry fruit and sugar. Really smooth finish. slightly puckering and refreshing.

Pours dark brown and mildly cloudy. Nice generous head but not out of control. Smells fruity and a little peppery maybe. Tastes sweet and tart. Loads of raspberry cream or ice cream. Blended smoothie. Nicely done. Not too sweet at all. Lovely tart finish that balances the sugar. Yummy. Best fruit beer that Ive ever had.

From notes:

Received in a past trade with WilliamD. Thanks again Will, wherever you are.

Pours a very dark purplish plum/cherry red color with a thin pink foam head that quickly fades leaving no lacing.

Huge raspberry aroma with subtle oak and an overwhelming sweet sugary character. I know they use real fruit but it smells like artificialy flavored syrup.

Medium bodied with very soft, tight carbonation up front and a very sweet cloying raspberry flavor that dominates lingering into a slightly tart dry finish. Theres a subtle earthy oak presence but again tastes mostly like artificial raspberry syrup. Just way too sweet and one dimensional for my taste.

Bottle. Pours deep red with a big off-white head. Aroma is raspberries and cherries. Flavor is fresh raspberries, cherries, grass...not medicinal at all but more earthy and authentic flavor. Refreshing medium mouthfeel. Loved this.

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2011 Thanks Dan!
Ruby pour with a quick head
aroma is raspberry, some earthiness.
Flavour is delicious raspberry, nice and sweet, but not cloying. 
Simple,  Delicious.

Bottle @ Private tasting, Denver, thanks to Notalush for sharing. 
Pours clear deep reddish golden with a small white head. Aroma of sweet and sour raspberries. Taste is candied sugar, strong tart raspberries, sweet fruit. Medium body, soft carbonation. Pretty good, but har do drink alot of. 100411
UPDATED: MAY 15, 2011 Bottle in wine glass. Small froth white head, wonderful clearing ruby red color. Dances on the palate, awesome flavor, great. A bit too much candy sugar sweetness.

750ml bomber shared with family after dinner. What a hit this one was. My family isnt into beer as much as I am but this was a real treat for everyone. I even heard "This is the best beer Ive ever had" a few times. A delicious fruity beer that I was completely satisfied with.

Couldnt wait to try this beer.  Being a homebrewer and creator of over the top fruit ales I was stoked.  Major disappointment.  Ruddy brown raspberry color.  Fake raspberry candy aroma.  Sugary sweet taste that refuses to go away.  My wife and I had a bottle of my raspberry homebrew to compare with this.  My wife took my homebrew and made me finish this stuff myself.  I have to say that from the 5 or 6 New Glarus beers I have had, they must be the most highly overrated brewery in the country.  I must say that I am spoiled living in Colorado, but come on.  How could thousands of reviewers be brainwashed into thinking this is good?  Give me a Lindemans any day if I want a sugary sweet raspberry ale.

Well, this is about what you would expect, but had none of the punch.  It is wonderfully tasty and quite creative.  Pours an almost blood red, with slight pink head that goes away quickly.  Aroma...yeah, raspberries...maybe some sweet malt in there somewhere.  Flavor matches well and is tasty as hell...for a little while, need to split the bottle with 1 or more people.

Super. Pours, appropriately, a deep raspberry color. I didnt get to see the pour and the resulting head, but tarheels86 tells me it was a "pretty intense khaki head". Looked good when I got it. Aroma was great, raspberry and fresh fruit. A bit sweet in the smell and the taste but not too intense. A bit sour actually, to balance it out.

750ml bottle from a trade with Ughsmash last year 
Appearance: Pours clear reddish amber with a nice light pink head and some light lacing left in the glass 
Aroma: Slightly tart fruit (raspberry) and some oak 
Taste: Tart raspberry, sugar with a nice dry bitterness in the finish 
Very nice and enjoyable to drink, I liked this.
Fruity, sweet/sour tartness.  Some nuttiness/malt.  Highly refreshing.  Maybe a bit overrated.

Bottle @ home, courtesy of notalush. Huge thanks! Dark red maroon appearance with a light red tan head. Quite sweet raspberry purée nose thats incredibly mouth watering. Slightly tart, raspberry pie filling flavor. Tart raspberry and pretty sweet finish. Lingering tart raspberry aftertaste. Excellent.

I have had this a few times, finally getting around to rating it, bottle thanks to thebaldwizard.  Clear amber red, with a thin off white head.  Tons of sweet raspberry, sweet malt, I find it almost closing, but the flavor is good.  An excellent fruit beer.  I could see females liking this a lot.

Thanks to fear025. Bottle pours deep ruby with a slightly pinkish head.  Aroma shows notes of raspberry goodness, as well as caramel, oak, and a touch of funk.  Flavor shows the same with additional berry notes and some vanilla. Overall body is moderate, sweet and somewhat tart.  Definately one of your sweeter style desert type lambics, but tasty nonetheless.

Big ups to fidelis for forwarding this a bonus. A BONUS! Taste is very dessertish and reminds me of raspberry cheescake. Nice fruit flavor followed by a smooth and sweet mouthfeel and coating. Full bodied. A nice funky finish to this awfully entertaining beer. Smooth sticky sweetness in the flavor. A little too quick on the finish is my only complain.

This beer pours a deep violet with very light pink head, but there is no head or retention at all. Lacing is very light as well.

The aroma is phenominal. It is candy sweet, just sweetness all over. It smells more like blackberries than raspberries. 

The taste is dead with the smell, just total wonderful sweetness. The best part is that its not so sweeet you cant drink it. Just the perfect amount. 

The mouthfeel is a little light, not a long lasting flavor. Drinkability is great, can drink this all day.
The raspberry hits your nose the second the bottle is open. The taste is a very strong raspberry flavor, it is very good but something I could not drink all night.
Light brown hint of purple and thin brown head. Very rasperry juice flavor.  Sour.

750ml bottle courtesy of kbutler1.  Shared bottle poured into a 4oz Stone tasting glass.  (Caviot: Tried this beer after Wisconsin Belgian Red) The beer pours a ruby red with next to no head.  The aroma is of berries but I was not able to pick up a distinct raspberry aroma, more faint.  The taste again was nice and sweet but the raspberry did not jump out immediately.  I found it near the middle with almost another generic "candy" berry coming though. The texture didnt lend itself to a super thick and syrupy mixture that I thought it would which was a nice surprise.  I thought this was a find drink but kept coming back to how great the Wisconsin Belgian Red was in comparison and this just didnt stack up.
user_location: Morro Bay via Orange County, California, USA

text: Pours dark red with light carbination.  Nose and palate all show deep bowls of fresh raspberries......enough said.

Aroma: very fruity, bursting with raspberries, some sour notes, a touch of toasty malt.  Appearance: ruby color, fairly clear, thick head with moderate retention, good lacing.  Flavor: dominated by raspberries, some tartness from wild yeast, toasty malt notes, pleasant lightly sour and fruity aftertaste.  Palate: medium body with high carbonation, tingly on the tongue.  Really nice brew, one of my favorites from New Glarus.

Pours a ruby red. Very clear. Small whitish head that fades fast and leaves little lacing.
Very raspberry. Can smell a bit of butter in there as well - maybe try a diacetyl rest next time. And a sour aroma mixed with a sweet smell. Smells of sour cherries too. 
Sour up front. Tart is very appropriate in the name, because it is. Underneath is a raspberry taste as you would imagine. Slight bit of sour cherries, medicinal like throat lozenges.
Mouth-feel is not overly bad. The tartness mixed with the medicinal properties gets old pretty quick. 
ITs an alright beer, but not one I would try and get again. I would only consume the small amount I poured out of the bottle and let my wife polish off the rest.

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2012 Pours a deep red into my champagne flute with papaya on the edges and a small slightly rosy rotten raspberry colored head that quickly dissipates and leaves no lacing.

The smell is very candy-like. It is mostly sugar and raspberries with a hint of oak, Im not a huge fan of the oak barrels New Glarus uses, there is just something a bit off with it that affects the scent.

The taste is phenomenal though, pure sweet and tart raspberry goodness. Not very sour, it is more of a tart flavor, hence the name. I definitely prefer the more balanced tartness over the acid bombs that some of these beers can be.

This is a great beer with just about any dessert, highly drinkable, drink it cold.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-18-2009 02:44:36

reddish brown with little white head. nose is beautifully pungent of raspberries. carbonation is surprisingly low for the style. little bitterness before a lot fo rich raspberry flavor with some medium crystal or munich malt with a slight tartness before medium residual sweetness leaving a sugary note on the tounge intermingling with the raspberry flavors. overall a very flavorful fruit beer, but slight higher carbonation may accentuate the fruit more than the lower carbonation that leaves a lot of malt character to this. overall very nice though

Hazy orange-ruby.  Fizzy head to lace.  Nose is raspberry jelly.  Sips of it are so tart it makes my eyes go wonky.  Cinnamin and tart.  Pared exceptionally well with crackers and peanut butter.  Loved it.

A delicious beer Ive been waiting years to try! Aroma was a little disappointing. Theres raspberry there, but not the mind blowing aroma I was expecting. Pour was a beautiful ruby red with a few bubbles and a thin pinkish film for a head. Taste was great. Nice and sour with only raspberries making a presence. Not overly sweet like some fruit beers can be. There is a perfect marriage of sweet and sour. Light carbonation doesnt hurt this sweet desert in a bottle. Would love to try the Belgian red!
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Enjoyed from a 750ml bottle in a champagne flute.  The beer pours a deep ruby color, with a fairly frothy light pink head.  The nose shows notes of strawberry, in a manner that almost seems artificial.  Background notes of bready malt come through.  The palate is unabashedly sweet, lacking the expected tartness, and coming dangerously close to being cloying.  The strawberry flavor comes through and is pleasant.  Carbonation is moderate, mouthfeel is appropriate.  The finish leaves a fairly large amount of residual sweetness and strawberry character.  Overall, a very pleasant drinking experience, especially as a dessert beer, but not quite a "tart."

Armoa is lively, sweet like jam, grassy undernote.  Weak and light color head, dark red-gold color.  Sweet taste with a tart and slighly dry finish which lasts.  Overall a great ale, not too sweet, refreshing.

This dark red pour smells of raspberry and a certain mustiness which I would attribute to packaging material.  It would a bit odd.  The flavor is sweet and fruity yet more complex than their cherry offering.

750ml bottle. Pours amber/reddish color with a white head. Nose is fruity, raspberry, almost like preserved fruits or jam. Flavor is full of raspberry, fruity, tart, not super sweet as I was expecting and actually enjoyable. Nice medium body and long lasting finish.

Bottle from my friends from Wisconsin shared with friends on Super bowl Sunday watching Greenbay vs. the Steelers. Pours a jewel like amber/crimson raspberry red color. Very tart berry aroma with slight sweet notes. Nice carbonated medium body beer with a nice tart finish. Beautiful tart raspberry with a slight sweetness coming through in the palate. Really great framboise especially for a true American spontaneously fermented beer! Overall (A)

Bottle..Clear deep red pour , small pinkish head ,some lacing . Aroma is ripe raspberry with a slight sourness . Flavor is a pleasant raspberry tartness , mouth coating sweetness (sticky) and a lingering dry finish . Light bodied and refreshing . Excellent

Review from notes, sampled 12/2/2007

Got this in a trade with dirtylou, thanks for the opportunity.

Pours a cloudy reddish purple with a pinkish white head that disappears quickly. Smell and taste is raspberries, raspberries, raspberries. Mouth feel is a little sticky, syrupy with moderate carbonation. Has a tart bite to the aftertaste. Descent brew, kind of a mix between a beer and a wine cooler.

Poured into a tulip. Thanks to alcstradamus for this one.

4.5 A: Clear somewhere between ruby red and burgundy color. Two fingers of ever so slightly pink frothy head. Pretty good retention and moderate lacing.

4.0 S: Wow, the raspberries! Tart raspberries totally dominate the nose and dont allow for any other aromas to be perceived other than a general vinousness. Of course, I have no problem with this since raspberries smell great.

5.0 T: Wow again. Totally wasnt expecting it to be so full bodied and flavorful. Most fruit beers are scant on the fruit and make what tastes like a watered down beer mixed with a watered down fruit juice. Not this one! Whether justified or not, I really like Lindemans Framboise and this is in several ways a bigger, bolder version of that. Raspberries are pretty much the sole flavor and give only a mild tartness. Loads of residual sweetness, which could contribute to a low level of perceived tartness.

5.0 M: Heavier medium body. Good moderate carbonation is spritzy and dances on the tongue. Somewhat sticky, but super smooth.

5.0 D: I really like it. I have another bottle in the cellar that Im tempted to open up, but I must resist. Gotta share. The people of Pittsburgh need to know about this one.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-30-2010 00:19:17
sample at sour tasting.  Surprise, this was my #3 of the night.  flavor of raspberries and cherries. more tart then sour, but still had the kick. Only 4%, this beer kept the flavor amazingly.
Bottle shared with RJ and served in wine flutes.  Strong fruity nose, predominantly raspberries.  A fantastic beer.  Another nice offering from NG.
(750ml bottle) pours rose colored white head. Aroma is raspberry.  Taste is sweet with a little fruit tartness. Medium bodied with slick texture.  Smooth.  A really nice beer.

750ml bottle pours a translucent, deep purple with a thin, white head.  Big berry aroma, raspberry, cough drops, sweet, candies.  Strong raspberry flavor, sweet, like a raspberry popcicle, some cough drop, light malt, honey.  Medium bodied, lightly sweet, lightly tart finish.

750 ml graciously fetched by CaptainCougar, thanks!  Dark, muddy maroon, light pink edge head, solid lacing.Aroma of pure fruit, lemon peel.  Taste has raspberry, lemon, cherry.  Slight sour edge.  Very nice stuff.

750 ml green bottle from Skyview. A deep ruby color beer with a nice head. The aroma has a lot of rasberries. The taste again has rasberries and has a slight tart edge in the end especially on your lips. This is a berry filled beer.

750 ml bottle courtesy of woosterbill.  Pours a reddish amber with a very small white head leaving close to no lacing on the glass.  The arma is raspberry syrupy.  Sodaish with some light lemon.  Taste is raspberry, syrupy sweet.  Very sodalike.  Light lemony tartness.  Fizzy carbonation.  Light-medium body.  A bit too syrupy sweet for my tastes.  I can see how people really enjoy this, but it was a bit too much like drinking a soda for me.

Bottle served in a flute.  First thing I notice is the amazing raspberry nose of the beer along with many fine carbonation bubbles.  Head dissipates quickly leaving traces along the edge of the flute.  Taste is out of this world, raspberries with a lingering tartness.  Wonderful.

Bottle to flute. Pour is ruby red with an amazing kahki soapy head that slowly fades to a collar around glass. Aroma is very nice raspberry and malt with some spice. Taste is strong raspberry that are tart and sour and fades to a nice malty finish. Palate is medium mouth feel that is sticky and chaulky. Wow this is delicious!

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2012 The beer pours a strawberry red with plenty of visible carbonation and a pink-tinted white head. The smell is one of slight sourness accompanied by overpowering fresh raspberries. The taste is much the same with an added tartness that complements the fruity sweetness of the raspberries perfectly. The mouthfeel is one of a good dose of carbonation on a fairly light-bodied beer; not too different from champagne, but perhaps a bit less carbonation. Drinkability is about as high as can be--with 4.0% abv, Id have no problem going all night with this one.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-24-2009
sweet big fake sweet raspberry coolaid.  Back sweetend. Pretty tasty, but acidic bite on the tail.

Aroma- raspberry, oak.  pours royal blood red.  taste is raspberry, raspberry jam, oak, hint of cinnamon.  The flavor is amazing in that it tastes like a wild raspberry right off the bush.  The after taste of earthy oak and dark fruit perfectly complements the sweetness that came before.  palate is light bodied, medium carbonation, refreshing.  This one is difficult to stop drinking.

Magnum in trade with Fear025.  I stared at this one inmy fridge for a bit and finally decided to try it this past weekend.  It was so tasty that I nearly forced a glass on my neighbor Barry as he pulled into the drive.  Gentle nose of fruit.  A light rose in the glass with steady carbonation.  Body is light to medium, slick buyt not cloying.  A pleasure to consume from start to finish.  A light tartness near finish realy ties this together.
If you want rasberry in balance, this is it. Not too sweet not to tart. Tasted GABF 2010 wish this brewery dist. out of wisconsin would be a great dessert beer for some cheesecake.

So I go back and forth between this and the Belgian Red for witch on I like more.  I give up, they are both FANTASTIC.  I think this it just depends on which fruit sounds better on the given day.  Another cant miss NG beer.
What can i say that has not already been said.  I have not tried the bottle yet, but the keg was a bit vinegary.

I heard about this for years so at GABF i seeked it out.  Well it is certainly something different.  Super rasberry nose and flavor.  Its sweet and honestly tastes nothing like beer which for me is a problem.  I can see having this as a dessert if I were a child.  But it smells great and has plenty o flavor.

Big thanks to trevor211 for sharing. Hazy ruby body with thin, bright white head. Tart raspberry wafts across the room, with some maple syrup and jam on the nose. Sweet and juicy. Very cidery. Sweet and crisply light bodied. Not my normal arena but quite interesting and tasty.

Pours a beautiful bright pale pink with a tall, loose, white head with a whisper of pink.  Striking, sweet aroma of raspberries that does come across as sour, but in multiple ways from both the acidity of the fruit and the fermentation agents.  The body is light and airy and delivers a tart pickle on the palate with the clear flavor of fresh raspberries and very soft malt and hops.

Sampled at the Great American Beer Festival on September 16, 2010.  Deep, translucent deep-reddish color.  Aroma is of raspberry (if i didnt know the name of this beer I would have guessed at least some sweet berry was involved). Flavor... wow.  This is a dessert!  You cant tell theres any alcohol in this *or* that its even a beer.  An amazingly delicious treat if youre in the mood for a dessert beer.  Easy.  This is candy!

Poured from 22 oz bottle, purchased at the New Glarus Brewery, enjoyed while watching a football game with friends.  Aroma dominated by raspberries, oddly some cherries as well, very sweet.  Appearance ruby red, clear, thin head.  Taste very tart at first, then subsides the more you drink.  Very sweet, great raspberry taste and mouthfeel.  Would definitely have this again.

750 ml. Aroma is of fresh rasberry and sour. Appearance is cherry red with p. generous red head. More rasberry in the taste with slight sour tang. A little sweet and syruoy. Smooth on the palate. A nice prickle from tghe carbonation. Overall a nice beer.. A liitle on the sweet side but I like the tartneess about and the aroma from the rasberries.
Clear red with a medium beige head. Sour raspberries in the nose along with oxididation. Quite vinious flavour with raspberries, oxididation and lacto. Finished sour.

The aroma is strong raspberries, tart.  The ap[pearance is a reddish brown.  The flavor is also loaded with raspberries, more trat than sweet however.  The finish is a tart raspberry flavor.  Raspberry is the key word here. Not a very inventive brew, but undeniably enjoyable.

Bottle. Big snappy aroma of crushed raspberries, light spiciness, earth, mild sour fruit notes, ozone, milled fresh grain. An excellent, rousing aroma, just right up into your nostrils and waking up your senses. Flavor has highly concentrated berry flavor, like a mouthful of sticky berries. Prickly tartness follows along with a nice, very subtle herb-like, mellowness imparted by the hops. Tart and sweet juices coat the mouth long after a swig. Unforgettable.

Bottle obtained in trade from atxdelivery.  Red wine looking pour from bottle.  Aroma is fruity, with notes of berries, sugar and vinegar.  Taste is mixed fruits, seltzer water and earth.  Slightly bitter, bubbly finish.  A fantastic fruit beer.

Bottle: Pours a Brown/Rasberry color into a flute. The head is an off white, with a slight purple hue. Smells a little earthy, a little like rasberry. The initial flavor was a mindblower - such a different experience than Ive ever had. I love rasberry, but This Brew is just incredible. Nice carbonation, Nice smooth finish - There is no negative comment to think of here. WOW.

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2010 Bottle. 24.5 oz. Split with James. Pours a clear electric ruby maroon with a two-finger, bubbly off-white head that dissipates quickly, leaving outrageously beautiful lacing down the sides of the glass. Aroma of fresh raspberry jam spread on warm toast, malts, dark cherries, plums, cranberries, and slight notes of honey and orange marmalade. Thin bodied with a fizzy, soda-pop sweet and crisp mouthfeel. Tons of fresh, sugary raspberry tarts and smooth vanilla cream in the finish. Not much alcohol, but theres no reason to burden these delicate aromas and flavors with any additional components. Overall, this far exceeded my expectations, even with the accompanying hype. A must try for fans of fruit beers and sours alike.

UPDATED: JUN 27, 2015 Bottle split with pat. Pours a pitch red wine body with no head, no lacing. Aroma is, hands down, the best thing "fruit" related ive ever smelt. It literally smells like pure raspberry jam. Mouthfeel is a bit thin, but considerable for the 4% alcohol - great notes of fruit jam, raspberries,  cherries, tart.

A: pours a nice deep and intense red almost hard to see any light through it. Nice dark pink head. Great retention and very good lacing.

S: solid tart raspberry aromas. Huge fruity nose.

T: great tartness, with a huge overpowering raspberry flavor. A little too sweet but totally expected from the style.

M: very thick and warming. Mild carbonation level. Solid flavors and a great palate.

D: very drinkable....a 750mL is made for sharing, especially with this one. Outstanding.

Bottle, LSXI.  As a huge fan of raspberries, Im excited.  Reddish pour with a light pink head.  Very rich, ripe, raspberry aroma.  Flavor is also loaded with juicy raspberries.  This loads in so much rich berry flavor without being syrupy.  Some tartness builds after sipping it and serves to keep it from feeling too sweet.  Im amazed by how simple, yet impressive, this beer is.  It very much succeeds at being a fruit beer thats fruit forward while not tasting like a soda.

Had this on tap at Vintage Brewery in Madison, WI.  Poured into a tulip glass, has a great red apperance with a pink head, aroma has is very sweet with raspberries, taste has a nice tartness and is very enjoyable.  Try this one on tap if you can find it!

Picked this 750 ml. bottle up at Discount Liquor in Milwaukee, Wisconsin. Translucent dull ruby color
that looks pretty good. The head faded away fast, but I can tell this beer is quite carbonated. It smells so 
deliciously fruity. Wow, this sucker is aromatic. Its very pungent and smells of raspberry jelly and puree. Its
not tart smelling whatsoever, but again, its quite aromatic and smells like its going to be a delicious breakfast
beer. Wow, light on the tongue and tart at the end. This is a damn near perfect fruit flavor. The raspberry pop through
and hit my taste buds, but not in a cloying way. The beer is crisp, in terms of carbonation. It seems as though
someone is squeezing fresh raspberry juice on my tongue. Shit, this fucking thing is nice. A perfect tart finish.
Finally, a New Glarus beer that I am thoroughly impressed with.

Bottle, thanks for sharing tarheels! Pours bright red with a big reddish white head. Flavor is big, big raspberries (duh) with a sweet and sour taste to it. For such a simple fruit beer, this really blows every other fruit beer away Ive tried.

UPDATED: NOV 9, 2011 750mL thanks to my secret Santa (I think). Whoa holy sh!t this is good. I am not a giant fan of the Belgian Red but I know it is hard for NG to come out with a beer that is not stellar. What an outstanding fruit beer that is neither 10%+ nor a lambic.Pours a clear deep purple to ruby with a towering, thick, creamy, slightly pink head that has excellent retention and good lace. Aroma is incredible: fresh raspberries, pithy raspberry, seedy raspberry preserves, really so rich and bright with fresh fruitiness. No candy sugar, no sticky sweetness. Taste is so brilliant: it is malty, creamy, not buttery, with so much fresh raspberry that brings out a naturally tartness that is not framboise sour. No pedio, lacto, acedic acid. No lambic character. But somehow is perfectly balanced between sour berries and sweet malt. Lively, bubbly tart on the palate that finishes super quick making you beg for more. It is not massively complex, but it is a beer that I will crave from now on every day. Destroys all fruit beer. 8/10/2010 8/5/8/5/15=4.1750mL. Pour is perfect- a clear jewel black ruby with a massive pinkish beige head. Huge retention and wispy, gorgeous delicate lace abounds across the raster tulip. Nose is seedy raspberry smoothie. Taste....wow. So much lactic sourness, seedy raspberry, sweet raspberry smoothie. Palate is ultra silky with a long lactic finish. Mild spice and sharp sting. Perfect blend of sweet and sour. Incredible raspberry character. Impossible for any organic lifeform to not thoroughly enjoy this. Whoa. 11/9/11 8/5/9/5/17=4.4

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2015 Bottle. Pours a mostly clear, deep red with a fine, fizzy, red-white head. Huge aroma of fresh raspberry and some tartness. Very sweet flavor with lots of berries, sour notes and some wood. Light to medium in body with fine, tingly carbonation. Reminiscent, in flavor and partly in mouthfeel, of a nice raspberry ginger ale. Finishes semi-dry with lingering sweetness and some lip-puckering tartness. This is, I believe, the best Fruit Beer I have ever had. (August 2010, score: 4.5)

Picked this up while visiting the brewery right before Darkness Day 2009. Opened this one up while some family visited for the Christmas holiday. Split several ways in wine glasses. 

A - Pours a pink/red/brown color with a very small amount of head. Theres no lacing to speak of and no head retention as well, just a reddish-brown colored liquid.

S - Sweet berries, burnt sugars, and some tart notes as well.

T - Similar to the nose. Berries and sugars with a nice punch-in-the-mouth tart finish. It was too tart for some of my family members, but I could appreciate it.

M - Light, kinda syrupy, good carbonation, tart finish.

D - Great during the holidays and should be split several ways, IMO. Im almost 100% sure theres no way I could finish an entire bottle by myself. Truthfully, I prefer the Wisconsin Belgian Red.
Pours sparkling ruby red.  Aroma is sweet, thick and fruity.  sparkling but syrupy mouthfeel with the taste of tart berry.  finishes sweet but not overwhelming. Lovely!

75cl bottle at home, unknown vintage. Full blown raspberry aroma with not much going on. Palate is thin and oily. Flavor is so sweet and quite one dimensional. As with the Belgian Red there is a medicinal quality to this beer. It tastes sweetened and false even though its 100% fruit.

Reddish amber brown pour ... light pink head .... tons of raspberry in the aroma and a tart raspberry taste .... smooth and fresh taste light oak .... nothing overdone here just solid and tasty fruit beer with just the right amount of tartness

I loved this beer. I shared this bottle on a trip to North South Campground in Haines Falls, NY with adrian910ss. Pours an awesome deep red colour with a frothy pink head. Fragrant aroma of raspberries, raspberries, raspberries and some malt. Tastes like a sweet yet tart carbonated raspberry and malt beverage. Another hit from New Glarus. Its the only time I wish I lived in Wisconsin.

Bottle. Pours a magnificent reddish hued clear color with a nice pinkish head. The aroma is strong raspberry notes with a sweetness I have come to expect for the NG fruit beers. Slight tart as well. Nice balance of sweetness and tartness upon my first couple of sips. This beer is so good. This weekend I had Phoenix Kriek, NG Belgian Red, and this and I have to say this was my favorite of all 3. Light/Medium mouthfeel.

It pours dark pink with a slight orange tint and small light pink head.  It smells like raspberry jam, and as the name suggests, it is both raspberry and tart in the flavor.  It is completely delicious.
An amazing smelling beer.  If you like Raspberrys you will love this beer.  My wife who hates beer enjoyed this beer.  Its a great after dinner beer.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 A: Served in tall champagne flute. Rich, dark ruby red... small pinkish head with minimal retention and mild lacing.

S: Delicious, tart and sweet raspberries. Thats about it, but thats good enough for me!

T: Delicious, I knocked it down to a 4.5 because the taste isnt quite as complex as the nose... perhaps its limitations of the tongue, but its still excellent. The greatest part is the naturalness to the flavor... Its not candy sweet. Nothing artificial at all. Just fresh raspberries.

M: Medium bodied, with a nice carbonated zip. Not quite champagne, but more so that beer.

O: Superb. A very nice beer.

Refrigerated bottle poured into a white wine glass.  Pours a dark red with a creamy medium pink head.  Great lacing and good carbonation.  Taste is big complex sweet/tart raspberry.  Best fruit beer I have had.

Im not normally a fan of fruit beers, but given the high rating and the fact that it was only $8 for 750ml, I considered this a wine well invested. Strong odor of raspberry spritzer is present. Very little foam. Tastes of tangy, sweet, sour, and raspberry. Color is somewhat ominous and rich brown/red. Sparkles and bubbles like a champagne....impress your beer loving woman with this gem!

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2010 Pours a pretty pink-purple color. Aroma is strong of raspberry and and a hint of malt. The fruit comes through beautifully with nice balancing acidity, and a hint of malt. Great complexity in this fantastic beer.
Pours ruby red with a small pinkish head.  Aroma is raspberry and cotton candy?  Flavor is sweet raspberry with a tart finish.  Simple and delicious.
Bottle.  Pours red with brown hues.  Smells of sweet raspberries and sugar, mild chocolate.  Sugary sweet with raspberry and chocolate.  Dry and tart finish.  Solid.

Bottle at RBESG Rome Grand Tasting. Clear red colour, pink head. Aroma of sweet raspberries. Flavour is sweet, sugary, raspberries, light tart finish. Light bodied. Highly overrated imo, this is just a (nice) raspberry sodapop.
Bottle thanks to Rando7. Pours ruby red with thin white head. Nose is cranberry and raspberry juices. Taste is same with mild tartness.

What can I say that hasnt already been said? I imagine this isnt a "beer" experience as much as a fruit experience. The pour is a brilliant purplish red with a pink disappearing head. The aroma is fresh raspberry puree and cherry pie filling. The flavor is a massive hit of fresh, sweet, ripe raspberries, cherries, and yeast. The finish is a little syrupy (berry pie filling). This is a real treat. One of the freshest tasting, authentic fruit beers in the world. Deserving of the hype

Tap at Sugar Maple, Beautiful magenta pour with medium beige head. Aroma of raspberry preserves punches you in the face. A slight pinch of sugar in the nose, but its a complement to the richness of the raspberries. Flavor is again a ton of raspberry preserves with hints of rose petals and yeast. Whats really special is the soft tartness of strawberries and raspberries that stays on the palate prominently but delicately. The tartness adds up with each sip but is never dominant. I dont think I could have more than one, but damn.

UPDATED: JUN 12, 2010 Bottle courtesy StFun.  Liquid fruit!!  Sugar sweet raspberry with a medium tart finish (not sour but a wonderfully engineered end-cap to the sweetness).  Tastes like a sunset behind the mountains on a "day-of-the year" summer evening while you hold the hand of the one you love.  Amazing. 

2nd half of the bottle the next day - after drinking this s bit more I still find it amazing but really, really sweet so that you only want to drink it in small doses.

Pour is at first a light ruby but once the carbonation rises it becomes a deep garnet.  Aroma is intense fresh fruit, raspberry, black cherry, fresh, non medicinal fruit.  Flavor is extreme raspberry fruit with some tannic notes, some yeasty tart notes, but mostly Chock full of raspberry fruit.  DELICIOUS.  rediculiously tasty, more depth then the Belgian Red for me.  Damn

Deep garnet pour with a small bubbly white head. Aroma holds lots of raspberry, golden raisin, other berries, and some touches of cherry and peach. Flavor is heavenly; tons of raspberry, cherry, and just tons of fruitiness that comes at you from every direction, with a bit of musty tartness. Palate is syrupy but light, and has a semi-dry finish. Great stuff.

Ruby red pour with a small white head that dissipates rather quickly. The aroma is pure unadulterated raspberry with notes of blackberry, cherry, and light red nectar fruits. Incredible. The flavor is massive raspberry and black cherry. Not overly complex, but utterly amazing. A slight tart note comes in near the middle of the quaff, but by no means would I call this sour.
