Its like Im eating a raspberry- pure raspberry puree. The palate is just perfect- full, slippery, and delightful. I like this more than the Belgian Red for sure.
Bottle @ RBESG, Rome. Pours bloody red with a off white pink head. Fresh raspberries. Clean and tart. Very fruity, refreshing and crisp. Niceness..
Bottle. Deep red with a small creamy off white head. The aroma is truely sweet raspberry, some caramel and fruit. The flavour is heavy raspberry, light sour notes and caramel.

Had this on friday (thanks brian) and saturday (thanks chris).

A- Body is a vibrant fuchsia-with a bit more red than purple/pink. Bubbles can be seen rising to the top. Head is slightly off-white and retains at a thin collar with minimal lacing left behind in the glass.

S-Smell is dominated by both tart and sweet raspberry but a hint of cranberry is also noticeable in the nose as well as a hint of bready yeast.

T- Taste is pretty much raspberries across the board-the first bottle I had, for some reason, was more tart than the 2nd-The first bottle was left opened before consumption a lot longer than the second which may have something to do with it. The second bottle was on the sweet side but still balanced. A lot of raspberry, a hint of cranberry, and a hint of yeast.

M-Moderate tingly carbonation and medium weight, full body.
body

D- This is a very good, well put together raspberry fruit beer. Much better, IMO, than the Belgian Red. Very enjoyable and a top notch fruit beer-but somewhat lacking in complexity.

Serving type: bottle
This was the last beer of the night for me at Sour Slam- an excellent way to finish the night.  What can I say, New Glarus, your fruit beers are delicious, divine and one of a kind.

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2011 A-pours a clear ruby red, looks like cranberry juice.

S-the nose is quite strong, very sweet with lots of raspberries and notes of cranberry juice.

T-the taste follows the nose, lots of raspberries and cranberries in taste.   there is a light tartness in the back but not overly so.

M-very prickly on the palate, soft feel to it with a good carbonation level, strong creating a crisp finish.

D-this is quite easy to drink, very sweet and a little singular but tasty and could enjoy many.

750 ml bottle from madvike, thanks man!  dark red, little head, smells of rasperries and tastes of sweet rasperries.  I dont like it as much as the cherry but this is a close second.  wakes up those taste buds after a night of drinking or refeshes you on a hot day.

Poured red and brown and mostly clear.  A few little white bubbles constitute the head.  The aroma was tons of sugar, raspberry and earth.  The flavor was sugared raspberries, earth and a touch of vinegar.  Thin to medium in body and fairly laborious to get through.  Ill never understand this beers score.

Warming fruit aroma.  Dates, currants, and of course, raspberries.  Color is deep, rich red with a thin light pink head that lasts and lasts.  Taste is like fresh pie.  Initially a burst of sugar followed by raspberries by the boat load.  Filling and pie like.  Finishes with a tartness that is just perfect.  Coats the mouth and lasts forever.  Near perfect.

UPDATED: AUG 22, 2010 Pours a dark red with pinkish head that fades quickly.  A fruity aroma with a light malt background.  Tart raspberries dominate the flavor with nice malt background.  Every once a while I caught the hops out right.  A very well done fruit brew.
user_location: Town of Maple Creek, Wisconsin, USA

text: bottle thanks to GodofThunder.  pours a rose pinkish red with some white head and a little bit of lace.  Great nose that smells pretty much like fresh raspberry puree with just a hint of a funk to it that only makes it more enticing.  Flavor is more sweet than tart but with an ever so slightly sour dry finish.  Excellent especially for a sweet fruit beer.

750 ml bottle shared at DLD, but I dont remember by whom.  No matter, I had another bottle at home and cracked it open with my girlfriend last night.  Pours a weird but cool cloudy orange-brown-ruby color with a tiny white head that doesnt last.  Aroma of fresh raspberries, oak, sugar, floral notes, and a hint of hops.  The hops disappear in the flavor, which is heavy on raspberries and oak.  Im surprised, actually, at what an oaky character this has and it complements the rasberries so well.  So fresh, sweet, and tart, for an awesome mouthfeel.

lucent mahogany, no head.
aroma is very raspberry brandy.
taste opens with dark fruit and moves toward lambic is you go. lots of raspberries all the way through.
good, but really needs to be paired with cheese or dessert.
Slightly dark red pour. Very fruity aroma with slight carbonation. Very nice raspberry and slight tart flavors. Wonderful beer and very reasonably priced!

Pours a deep murky read with a rocky white head. Aroma is straight up raspberry. Theres no fooling around here. Raspberry and nothing but. Flavor is tart and sweet raspberry through and through. Really tasty but if raspberry isnt your thing probably no point.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2013 Bottle. Pinkish pour when poured in bright light. Looks a much darker shade of pink/red in a more dimly lit room. Initial pink fluffy head, which dissipated with little lacing. Strong aroma similar to Juicy Juice or any other fruit juice. Raspberry dominates. Some acidity / vinegar on the nose as well. Smooth mouthfeel with some carbonation, big raspberry taste, tart but not so much as to make it tough to drink. Very well done.

Bottled sample via and shared with oakbluff. Very dark red in colour with mild spritzy carbonation. Aromas are of raspberry jam and raspberry stalks. As one would expect, the raspberry dominates on the palate as well, with supporting notes of pale malts, and lemon. Fairly sweet and heavy mouthfeel. Could use a bit more carbonation or a bit more acidity for balance, but its still a good after dinner sort of fruit beer.

bottle acquired from trade, poured into a snifter. Huge raspberry aroma, pours a raspberry red with a small white head. Medium body with medium carbonation. Flavor intense of raspberry flavors almost olverwhelming with raspberry flavors. A lil too fruity for my liking.

Thanks to Exiled for sharing this wax-dipped 750 ml bottle of Wisconsin goodness. I had beer looking forward to trying this beer for quite some time and I was not disappointed. The beer pours a medium-dark red color with a large white head. The aroma is strong raspberry. The flavor is sweet raspberries with a nice strong tart finish. Medium mouthfeel and medium, crisp carbonation. This has a more soda-like mouthfeel than the Belgian Red which seems to be more juice like. Overall, an outstanding fruit beer.

The aroma is crushed fresh raspberries with a nice funk on top. The appearance is ruby brown almost like a brandy. The flavor is a layering of delicious sweet berries on the tongue with just a bit of funk funk/ tart to combine perfectly in this amazing lambic.

Bottle from Ugmash.  Poured dark clear red with a small off-white head.  Nose of tart raspberries (whodathunkit?).  Some light malt in there as well.  Really difficult to tell this is a beer from the aroma.  Taste is similar, with lots of tart fruit.  Not very beer like, but pleasant either way.  Mouth is medium with a tart finish.  Overall, a nice fruit beer.

(Trade from Pantanap) Small thick head. Very slight tinge of pink to it. Body is clear red colored. No haze. Good tart raspberry aroma. Flavor is kick in your teeth chock full of raspberries!! Almost to the point of drinking liquid sour raspberry jam. Good mouthfeel. Sure wish this was a regular around my neck of the woods!!

Bottled...pours redish purple with a thin ring head... Aroma is sweet raspberries...flavor is sweet but not overly sweet with lots of raspberries..So Good! Due note that while I was drinking this my underwear strangely took themselves off.. definite panty dropper.

750 ml bottle.  Pours a clear reddish purple brown color with a small to medium fizzy pinkish head.  The aroma is wonderful fresh raspberries with a slight tart component.  There seems to be just a hint of oak as well.  The flavor is as advertised: big fresh raspberry with the perfect amount of tartness.  The back and forth between sweet juicy raspberries and tart juicy raspberries is part of the experience.  As with the nose, there seems to be a slight woody character that makes its presence known.  Medium bodied, rich flavor and very smooth.  I wish all fruit beers could be like the ones produced at New Glarus.

A really nice beer. It had a wonderful taste that wasnt artifical at all. I could taste real berries in it. It smelled great just like fresh fruit and the color was fantastic. No doubt I will gladly buy this again when I get a chance.

Pours a reddish mahogany that is barely translucent, and has a minimal head, which may be an artifact of how it was poured. Raspberry dominates the rich and sweet aroma. Flavor is mainly raspberry, fairly sweet and slightly sour, more like a raspberry liqueur than a beer but still tasty. Texture is tingly, fizzy and edgy so it fairly dances on the tongue.

25 oz bottle from Vince. Pours a slightly hazy deep crimson with a small fizzy off white head that quickly fades. Aroma is mostly all raspberries, there is a bit of tartness and some light graham cracker as well. Flavor is sweet tart raspberries, the tart sourness hits you right away and then the taste mellows out and finishes sweet and fruity. Medium body with a lively carbonation and a long crisp finish. Fantastic beer, New Glarus really knows how to make some damn good fruit beers. Thanks again Vince for another excellent beer.

Wow...this is right up there with the Belian Red from New Glarus.  Actually my only criticism would be that it is too much like that wonderful brew.  A nice sweet tasting beer without being syrupy like some of the maple/bourbon beers or being sugary like Leinenkugel Berry Weiss.  This is something you could drink all day long.  Nicely with perhaps a peace of angel food cake and strawberries.  light to medium and easy to drink.

Bottle from Kevin at Hangar 24. Appearance golden reddish with small bubbly white head. Aroma fresh raspberries and jam and pie. Taste very sweet, tons of raspberry taste that is very nice. Nice pallet and very very tasty.

Bottle shared by joetheyounger.  Pours a dark pinkish orange with a short pinkish white head.  Aroma is sharp and tart, tons of raspberries and oak.  Flavor is like raspberry pie, sweet and tart and a bit of funk and oak.  Medium bodied, candy like and moderately carbonated.

A: The pour is a clear, dark, ruby/garnet color with little to no head.

S: Great raspberry aroma. Theres a wonderful mix of tartness and sweetness. Maybe a bit of cranberry as well.

T: Like the nose, there is a great balance of tart and sweet raspberry. The flavor is not candy-like such as other fruit beers.

M: The body is medium and the level of carbonation is fairly low. Somehow, it works though.

T: Much, much more drinkable than the Wisconsin Belgian Red. The lack of cloying sweetness is quite a nice surprise and makes this beer very enjoyable.

Bottle shared with bro and Glouglou
Aroma : INTENSE fruity raspberries and cherries. Sweet fruity

Taste : Awesome fruity raspberries. A bit tart and quite sweet.

Finish : Slightly tart, very fruity and sweet.

Overall : Better than the Belgian Red. Still the same insane fruity intensity. It got a bit better after it heated up a bit. Not so much complexity but so intense. Only downside is I dont think I could have a full bottle by myself. A bit too intense. There is nothing like this beer. You cant die without trying this. Thank you sooo much Eric !!
Bottle.  Pour is clear red with a small whitish head.  Aroma and flavor are sweet malt with a very notable raspberry component.  A bit sweet for me, but not bad.

Pours dark red with thin white head, poured into a champagne glass as advertised.  Aroma is full of tart and fresh raspberries with a bit of yeast funk from the oak.  Taste is like a raspberry pie, with sweet raspberries up front leading into a nice oak funk with some nice tartness at the end.  Excellent!

Bottle. Pours a deep reddish color with a small off-whitehead. Has a rich fruity slightly tart raspberry aroma. Sweetish fruity and slightly tart raspberry flavor. Has a smooth fruity and slightly tart raspberry finish.

On tap at the Sugar Maple bar in Bay View.  Very tasty - one of my favorites.  Great raspberry flavor with just enough tartness to keep it from being too fruity.  Great level of carbonation for the beer.  Easy to drink, refreshing, and a great fruit beer.
pours sparkly and blood red.  sweet berry smell. fruity and almost wine like.  raspberry lingers on the roof of the mouth.  soda like qualities.  could use a skosh more tartness.
Pours a bright red with a little pinkish head. Aroma is amazing, like the freshest raspberries in the world. Very smooth, raspberry/tart taste.  It is very carbonated but it is not overwhelming.

Bottle from john or wayne... (Hartford Co boys) Shared at Roberts house. Pinkish in color, thin bubbly head. Great aroma of raspberries, duh? Taste: Imagine if some one put a fresh raspberry pie in a blender and than served it. Yup, its better than that. Lots of tart raspberries all blended so well together. So smooth, wow. Low carbonation level with that has a thin oily texture to it. Overall... a great beer. Now I want my own bottle!

A: Pours a love sparkling ruby red color. There is a nice light pinkish white head that dies down. Lots of carbonation rising to the top if you can hold it up to light that is strong enough to penetrate this bold red beauty.

S: Wow tons of fruit come wafting from the glass. I dont think you could squeeze a hand full of raspberries and get more aroma than this one has.

T: Wow lovely. This is the nectar of the freshest purist raspberries. I have no idea how they have taken fruit juice and transformed it into something so nice. It is the perfect marriage of sweet and tart. I like a good bottle of wine, but would take this one over wine anyday.

M: Simply Sparkling.
bottle: dark red with a foamy white head, aroma of raspberry (very fruity), taste is tart raspberry, lots of carbonation, almost taste like a glass of juice, crazy sweet beer.

Thanks to StFun. Pours a weird mixture of orange, brown and red (maybe one would consider this rust). The aroma smells very much like frozen raspberries in a puree or raspberry concentrate. The aroma is decadent and phenomenal, there is almost a freshly baked fruit pie sent. The flavor is very sweet with a medium to moderate tartness. Although its sweetness is what I am a sucker for, their are subtle complexities that make this framboise much better than say a lindemans

Bottle.  Pours a beautiful, clear red body with a light pink head.  Aroma of raspberries and light wheat.  Flavor is basically all raspberry with a light tart finish.  Lively palate that is smooth and fizzy.  Mouthfeel is slightly syrupy, but never cloying.

I opened this bottle for a dinner party last night and served a bunch of non-beer types. Everyone loved it, and whats not to like. This one pours an effervescent column of red in a flute with a big white head. The nose in raspberry and raspberry. The first taste is raspberry and sweetness, but there is just the perfect hint of sour to balance the sweetness. the finish is slightly sweet, but not lingering or cloying. Im going to be more deliberate about keeping a couple of bottles of this on hand. In summary, this would be a good beer to help introduce non-beer types to the joys of soured or slightly sour flavors and get them started thinking about the possibilities of other flavors in their beers. And its great to be enjoyed for its own virtues.
Distinct and very raspberry aroma, smooth and pleasing taste, realy enjoyed this one.
Bottle at Craigs house. VERY raspberry flavoured. Seems a little sinful to enjoy but it is nice.

75cl traded bottle. Another great fruit beer from NG. Extra special to me because I LOVE raspberries! Everything is real about this beer, not funky chemical notes anywhere. Outstanding mix of sweet, sour and tart notes. Definitely something I will track down again.
Bottle thanks to Cavie.  Bright red pour with a thin pink head.  Aroma is lots of raspberry and fruit.  Taste is sour, tart, and very raspberry.  Sweet, sticky finish.
Bottle courtesy of bonk0076. Red pour that is fairly clear. Smells of raspberry with bitter tart. Taste is more fruit than tart. Finish us overly tart with sour notes. Sickly sweet but solid as hell.
Bottle from Cavie.  Pours a dark red with a white head.  Smells like a raspberry bubbly.  Tastes like it could be a good breakfast drink.  Very tart.

Pours medium red with a fizzy pink head. 
Nose is heavy on natural fruits, smells like an organic fruit roll-up. 
Taste is pure fruit juice, it actually reminds me of Manichevitz.

750 ml bottle aquired via negotiations with kw mat j. pours clear deep red with almost no head and minimal carbonation. the aroma is of tart raspberry. the flavour starts with raspberry but becomes much more. its complex and huge in the mouth. the spontaneous fermentation adds layers of flavour and this one takes a while to truly sink in. sometimes you just need to crack an amazing beer and today was one of those days. i wish i had more.
Red pour with minimal head. Flavor is very fruit and surprisingly raspberryish. Doesnt have a cheap fruit flavor. Very easy to drink and a great beer to share.

Shared with my girlfriend over Thanksgiving. Wonderful sweet, tart, and fruity nose-I had to sit down and stick my nose way inside the glass on this one. Very dark red with a foamy head. Taste is remarkable-fruity, tart, with the raspberries and nice ale flavors coming through. Easy to drink and the taste stays with you all the way through the beer. One of the best and easily equal of any Belgian fruit beers.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: Pours a deep ruby red into the glass with a small reddish tinged head.  Aroma is raspberry with a bit of an acid funk.  Flavor is extraordinary with loads of raspberry coming through with a quenching quality to it.  Phenomenal beer that has completely changed my mind about fruit beers!
Very, very strong raspberry taste.  Almost too strong.  The aroma gives you a heads up on this.  Im not much of a fruit beer drinker, but this lives up to the hype.

9th September 2008. Dark pink beer with a pink head. Strong raspberry nose. Raspberry dominates throughout and treads a fine line between sweet and sour with sour just winning towards the finish. Refreshing and very very tasty.

750 ml bottle - shared this w/ a few non-beer geeks after thanksgiving dinner; opens with a faint pop and pours a murky dark purple with faint purple bubbles along the edges; oh man, love the nose of pure raspberry pie and fruity goodness; just straight up, big raspberry with almost a chocolate note too; texture is thin with a creamy quality and fruity zing; hardly tart though IMO; in a way this is very one dimensional, but perfectly one dimensional and much more impressive to me than the 2 times ive sampled belgian red; having a big glass might have helped that though; the sweetness is muted and texture/flavor detail becomes much more complex as it warms; great stuff that really lets the raspberries shine and perhaps the best fruit beer ive had
bottle thanks to my boy dodd. pours dark ruby red with fizzy head. aroma of raspberry, fresh fruit, sugar. flavor is light and delightful. excellent beer.

750ml bottle.  Thick cloudy unfiltered cranberry juice color with pink foam that quickly settles to some small bubbles. Intense raspberry, cranberry, cherry aroma thats sweet and tangy smelling. This beer looks and smells like a raspberry vinaigrette, but it tastes more like cranberry juice and cherry wine. Very intense and concentrated fruit.

Thanks to rayjay for this one.

Dark ruby red with a small pinkish head that leaves a small ring of lacings.

The smell is dominated by genuine raspberry aromas with nicely complementing notes of grass, earth and fruit pits. This brewery really knows how to make fruit beers that smell like fruit.

Lots of fruity sweetness in the flavor, and raspberries all around. A fruity tartness counterweights the sweetness together and develops together with notes of earth and seeds. I might pick up a hint of chocolate as well, but I might be fooling myself. The finish is dry with sweet and tart raspberry notes. The finish is really great, very well done.

Medium body, decent carbonation and a slick dry finish.

A good beer. A raspberry bomb. Very intense, and Im very impressed that a beer with such low ABV can showcase such strong flavors. This one would probably work well as a dessert or coupled with dessert. But I wouldnt want to drink too much of it, one glass is enough.

Since it is hard not comparing this one the Wisconsin Belgian Red, I must say that I preferred this one.

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)

bottle shared with my wife, pours deep ruby with a tall frothy light tan head. Aroma is tart raspberry with some cherry and sugar.  Flavor is nice and sweet raspberry jam with just a hint of tart cherry in the finish.  Very nice for a fruit beer, I think the sweetness is balanced with a mellow tart dryness.

Nose is quick with fresh raspberries and crushed apple however the yeast doesnt talk much. The palete intro is of bubbly champagne followed by a rush of fresh raspberries. This beer shows proper earthiness for a fruit beer mid palate. I can even taste the little crunchy bits!  Finish is proper and tart leaving you wanting another sip. Overall, a delightfully bubbly beer for sure to please anyone who is so lucky.

Ruby red body with a small filmy head and little to no lacing. Tons of real raspberry aroma, granted its fairly one dimensional but its done really well. Easy going, mildly tart and sweet. A refreshing and spritzy body. Some biscuit is picked up on the flavor, but its primarily a showcase for the wonderfully fermented raspberry taste. Fresh, lively and tart with a nice sweetness. Top shelf fruit beer, I would love this on hand all year long.

750ml bottle thanks to gandgkevin, crushed with LJ! pours a bright, ruby red color with a light pink, bubbly head and very nice lacing. aroma is wonderful with huge, fresh raspberries and light touches of candied cherry, red grapes, and vanilla flowers. flavor is fantastic as well with juicy, sweet raspberry notes up front backed by mouth puckering berry tartness, vanilla, sweet caramel notes, and a touch of spice cake. palate is bright, crisp, and medium bodied with a tart, fruity finish. overall, another wonderful fruit beer from New Glarus.

Bottle via trade.  This is just as good as the Wisconsin Belgian Red (i.e. its [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ awesome).  Pours a brilliant ruby color with a lasting off-white head and good lacing.  Aroma is intense raspberries.  Thats just about all there is to it, but its great.  Flavor is loads of fresh raspberry, oak, and vanilla, with maybe even a hint of chocolate.  Both sweet and mildly tart.  Body is medium and palate is incredibly smooth and creamy, with an amazing long finish.

Sampled at the Metro Detroit October 09 tasting.  Ruby copper pour with a short lived white head.  The aroma is sweet raspberries and brown sugar.  More of the same in the flavor with a long, juicy, berry finish, a little chocolate, some tartness on the finish with lingering nutmeg and cinnamon.  Awesome balance and complexity!  Sticky, medium full body.

Bottle thanks to Dalezale. Raspberry and more raspberry. Aroma and flavor are all raspberry and Im lovin this. It borders on cloying but never quite gets there. Its just damn good. Very creamy smooth finish.

Nice deep red with a small pink head on top. Sweet cookieish raspberry aroma with somewhat odd yeast notes. Flavour is obviously raspberry but with earhy notes, cookies and other dessert related sweet flavours. The beer ends with a nice light bittersweet and rather tart flavour that reminds me of the seeds in freshly picked raspberrys. Body is quite full with very finetuned carbonation.
Bottle. Yes darling but is it beer? INTENSE rasberry. Reminds me of Brämhults hallonjuice.
Bottle. Thanks Matt. Pours reddish pink with a medium head. Aromas are raspberry, raspberry and raspberry. Flavor is sweet, sweet raspberry with a slight tart edge in the middle. Yum.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text:
Bottle from Cracked Kettle.

Pours dark blood red
Heavy aroma of raspberries and chewing gum.

Slightly sour but mainly sweet, I found it better when it got warmer even though it was supposed to be served cold.

Red pour with orange highlights and an off-pink head.  Aroma is extremely fresh and fruit-driven, pretty intense.  Taste follows suit with extreme fruit flavors, and a little sweet malt.  Im reminded of flemish sours if you remove the "sour" part and add more fruit.  Medium to light bodied, but very flavorful.  Good!

sample from the pitcher at GABF on 9/26/09... light red color with a white head... sweet raspberry aroma and flavors... sweet but balanced... tart finish... I liked this one better than the Belgian Red.

Poured at 2009 GABF, sampled twice for good measure.  In short, I think I expected much more of a Sour Ale here, so the fruity-sweetness of it all was disappointing.  Nose is sweet berries and sugar with a hint of sourness and herbs.  Flavor starts off initially semi-tart berries, but quickly sweetens and smooths out into candied raspberries.  Im just not getting the hype here.  I tried so many delicious Fruit-influenced Sour Ales at GABF 2009, this offering just seemed muted, and average by comparison.  However, I could see that with no predilections about this beer, it certainly reveals itself as something quite decent.

Thin frothy head with deep red pour.  Aroma is strong of raspberry.  Pulls off the fruit beer aspect without the chemical flavor.  Tart as expected.  Fruit beers are not at the top of my list, but you cant dispute greatness.

A really nice fruit beer, probably the best out there. Bright red pour with plenty of raspberry aroma. The initial taste is very tart but then it is just raspberry throughout. It seems like a mix between a wine and a beer. Very good!"

Clear dark red color with a thin pinkish white head.  Straight raspberry aroma.  Slightly carbonated raspberry flavor.  Medium bodied (nice).  Little less carbonated than what a sparkling raspberry beverage would be.  A nice tartness to it, especially in the finish.

750ml bottle. Ive had this beer many times but never rated it. Pours a lovely and rather clear mahogany with lots of red. Nose is superb but somewhat muted but that could be because it was a modest pour in a huge glass (we only drank about 1/4th of the bottle, the rest was blended into a homebrew).  Flavor is similar to the belgian red, its full on raspberry pie, crust and all. Tart raspberry with balancing sweetness. Not sour at all just slightly tart and tangy. Big thick mouthfeel on such a light beer. This is just amazing and since I like raspberry more than cherry I actually prefer this to the Belgian Red. Just brilliantly crafted and executed. Dan Carey continues to amaze.

Thanks to STLWill for hooking this up!! Much appreciated bro!! Pours a deep mahogany and white head. Looks like red velvet cake with white frosting. Smells like raspberry halls, frosting, and ripe fruit. I cant wait to taste this...the taste was all I could hope for. Raspberry syrup, chocolate covered raspberries, and heaven...man this beer is awesome. So. damn. awesome. There is nothing not to like. Wow.

Bottle thanks to Bigmmartin.  Pours a nice dark red with little to no head.  Aroma is raspberry poptarts and a little bit of sweet malts.  On the palate it is dry and tart.  The flavor is almost identical to a raspberry poptart.  It finishes dry, leaving a fruity aftertaste.  Not very balanced at all, way to fruity for me.

Had this on a couple of occasions thanks to "hannont"!  Colour... cloudy-ruby with a thick, frothy head. Nose... did someone just pie my face with a fresh, chilled raspberry pie?! Palate... delightful effervescence, a burst of raspberry juice, bakers sugar, pie crust, yeast and zest of citrus. New Glarus should sell  this to NASA so they can label it, "raspberry pie" and give it to astronauts as a space dessert!

Big ol bottle, thanks to Ughsmash. Pours a dark purplish-reddish brown with tall light pink head. The aroma is raspberry with some floral notes. The flavor is fresh raspberry juice with just a little bit of edge to it. There are some floral notes and a light honeyish malt, but its hard to pick anything up past all that raspberry.

Bottle from MrPickles. 
Pours a clear red with light purple around the edges.  There is a thin pink head.  Looks like a wine cooler.  Aroma is obviously raspberries.  You can pick up on the tartness as well.  Flavor is... well raspberries.  Quite tart and sour.  Very fruity flavor that really resembles a juice rather than a beer.  Very sweet overall. The palate is quite thin and watery though.  Seems to be a well made fruit beer, which I can appreciate in small doses.   The Belgian Red is much better in my opinion.
Amazing flavor.  Perfect balance of tartness and sweetness.  Not sour or pungent at all.  Great dark red color with a pinkish head.  Took a long time to track this one down but well worth the wait.

A great beer from ericandersnavy. Thanks a lot man. Pours a very dark, deep red, with a lightly pink tinged tan head. The aroma is freshest of fresh raspberry. Medium body with mild carbonation. Flavor is quite mellow but intensely raspberry. A strong astringent tartness - but not sour. Maybe astringency is from the oak vats. It is quit tastey. Could go through a bottle or 3 any time.

Graciously shared by bhensonb. This fruit beer poured reddish brown with a thin, but pretty pinkish brown head and a delicious raspberry aroma. There is a mellow raspberry flavor that is pleasantly sweet, but not too much, and pleasantly tart, but not too much. There is a definite oak undertone. I could drink this all day. Fantastic. Thanks Bill.

750 ml bottle acquired via trade. Pours deep red with a thick pink head that fades quickly. Aroma is raspberry, a little sour vinous note and some sugar and malt. Flavor is very sweet raspberry, slight tartness to the finish not much complexity, but is there supposed to be? Enjoyable, but only in small doses, much like other fruit beers.

Bouteille de 750 ml, rapportée du Wisconsin par Dany. Merci ! Arômes intenses de framboises fraîches. Robe rouge et claire, effervescence moyenne et légère mousse. En bouche, les framboises fraîches et très naturelles sont sur toutes les tribunes. La finale est très légèrement sucrée et moyennement sûre. Préférée à la Belgian Red.
Glorious fruit flavor, nott too fake and not too sour. Like a natural fruit juice with beer. Deliscious. Really cleans your mouth. Bottle from a tasting at the house of chris Montelius

Nose is pungent wild raspberry with just a hint of yeasty beer goodness behind.  Taste is huge raspberry sweetness that is mellowed by the wheat and bready yeast. Nothing subtle about this one, very straightforward and perfectly done for what it is. Just a touch of sour tartness on the finish, and the carbonation is perfect to spread the flavors around. No way I could drink an entire 750, but I dont think thats the intention. Perfect with brownies and vanilla ice cream.

Appearance: Deep ruby red with small pinkish head
Aroma: Tinny metallic aroma with tart raspberry.  The tinny aroma faded over time with a little airing.
Flavor: Massive tart raspberry.  Absolutely delicious.

Bottle via rustychiles Wisconsin hookup. Aged approximately 8 months. Pours rather flat and the darkest of ruby reds. Aroma is beautiful unadulterated raspberries and a definitive sourness (moreso than expected). Taste is the tartest raspberry taste that you could imagine, with a rather clean raspberry aftertaste reminiscent of the centers of from Sees candies. Very easy to drink and I can see why this is the gateway sour beer for so many people. Bravo; a must-have.
Really enjoyable fruit beer.  Aroma is of sweet raspberry and sweet malt.  Flavor very similar but really enjoyable.  Nice beer.

Pours dark ruby-mahogany with a 1 finger, creamy, grey-pink head that has good retention and leaves specs of lacing. Aroma is really strong raspberry, sweet malt, a lightly toasty cereal, rhubarb and some light herbal/grassy notes. Flavor is sweet raspberry, dusty grass, tart raspberry, rhubarb preserves, light wood notes, a little mustiness and raspberry danish. Finish is raspberry, wood and a little acidic. Palate is light to medium bodied, sticky on the lips yet dry on the palate and with a perfect carbonation level. Good stuff, very good stuff, not quite as good as the Belgian Red and maybe a little too sweet for me, but still fantastic.

In an effort to knock out the rest of my backlog, my ratings will be fairly generic and sparse.  If the beer had anything special to offer, it will be noted following this disclaimer.  The number ratings above are accurate based on my tasting notes.  Following the elimination of my backlog, all beers will be entered in real time and will be more useful.  Sorry for the inconvenience. 
Special thanks to Beerlandos wife for letting me have some of her beer that I hadnt had yet.  Great aroma and flavor.  Perfect american tart fruit beer.  Nothing medicinal from the berries, just good fruit candiness.

75cl bottle courtesy of photomike.   I just want to start by saying that I cant imagine a fruit beer smelling better than this.   Every time that I put my nose in the glass, a huge smile crept over my face.   I love raspberry jam, and this smelled like just about the best raspberry jam ever.   I have no idea how they got such a vivid and intense aroma into this beer.   There is a great mix in the flavor of sweet fruit and tartness that keeps the sweetness from overrunning the drinkability.   I have to day that I cant imagine the flavor keeping me captivated for ever like the aroma, but this is a superbly done fruit beer in every aspect.

Bottle. Pours deep tawny red. Nose is raspberries, sweet, tart, fresh, preserved, raspberry pie, raspberry jam. Every aspect, stem, seed, fruit, incredibly pretty. A vague hint of sour ale underneath, providing a funky backdrop. Best fruit beer to pass my lips ever. Kickass!

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2010 Bottle.  Pours a brown red with a thing white head.  Very pleasant aroma of fresh raspberries, light medicine, and sugar.  Flavor is sweet with the slightest hint of tart raspberries on the finnish.  Very creamy. Raspberries with whipped cream.  A great dessert beer. super well made.  best fruit beer.  Neat brew

Much more tart and sour than the Belgian Red makes this an equally fine beer. Pours a dark ruby red with a dark pink head. Aroma of tart raspberries and cherries. Flavor is solid and very tart, but still a little too sweet for my tastes. I wish it was dryer and less syrupy. I really enjoy the sour funk that is present, but I think it would benefit from being bottle conditioned with some live bacteria.

It is somewhat difficult to review to style on something of a catch all style, so I will try my best with this one. One of my few remaining top 100 that I have in my cellar, been sitting on this for a while. New Glarus Belgian red was fantastic, and this one gets similar love. I hope it gets similar love from me. Here we go!

Look is something like a cranberry or grape juice which looks good. I am going to penalize it a bit for the lack of head retention and lacing, but otherwise no problem with the appearance here. 

Scent is, no surprise here, very strong sugary raspberry. A slight bready scent as well. Good, but one dimensional. Its difficult to not judge this against wild ales which would be penalized for not having a bit more to it, but this is exactly what it says it should be.

Taste however is very very good. I dont even like raspberry, but I like this. Not cloyingly sweet or sour, a pleasant (surprise) raspberry burst that has some candy character. Very good but just a little too rich, so rich that I will probably not be able to kill the bottle in one sitting.

Mouth is great, syrupy and bubbly. That is to say its thick, which again would seem off in a wild ale or lambic, but works here.

Overall Im going to come in slightly below the average rating on here, but this is a very good beer. Given the option I am going to opt for its Belgian Red brother every time, but this is still a damn good beer.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2010 Delicious! Everything you could want in a sour fruit lambic style beer.  This is probably the best lambic Ive ever had, and its not even from Belgium!  Another great feature is that its very likable by non-beer-drinkers.  Will probably serve some of this at my wedding.

(750ml bottle) Pours a ruddy red with nice oily white head. Nose is tart raspberries, taste is sour and tart raspberries as well. Pretty one dimensional but man it is good. Cheek puckeringly so too. The linger on the palette is oaky and sweet.

Bottle graciously shared at BCTC by yet another wonderful person.  Whomever you were, thanks.  This was delicious.  Pours a clearish ruby brown with a thin white head.  Enormous clean fresh raspberries and a faint touch of vanilla.  Big and chewy.  Nice tang to it.  Crisp.  Delicious.  Not sure how they do it, but New Glarus manages to do fruit beers so incredibly well.  Clean and distinct, not cloying, not artificial.  Just real and up front.

Ill take my raspberry tart as is, please, maybe a little dab of fresh whipped cream. The real thing please; no oil or nitrous added. As for the raspberry tart, only the freshest berries, natural sugars, and homemade crust for me. As my lips wrap around its sweet, succulent, moist, and raspberry-rific body, a playfully tart kiss lingers while warm crust provides a soft chair to lean back upon. Delightfully delicious. As I open my eyes, I realize that I am not partaking of a real raspberry tart, but instead I am supping on the Raspberry Tart from New Glarus Brewing in New Glarus, Washington. Let me elaborate.


She came to me on a quiet, starlit night, deep burnt ruby-red eyes sparkled like a precious gem unfettered and unadulterated by the corruptive touch of mankind. This is made all that more ironic by the fact that this particular beer is a product of mans tender loving machinations, but machinations none-the-less. Her voluptuous bouquet is picked up by the gentle breeze and wafts past me fully aware of their irresistibility. Vanilla bean and pie crust are content to linger in the background, allowing the raspberries and cream to take center stage, as they very well should. There is a finishing playful nip of tartness, a reminder that not all things in life must be saccharine to be enjoyable. There is no resistance or shyness; all that has been thrown to the wind as I greedily sup on her liquid ecstasy. Creamy milky vanilla center with raspberries all around, sour and sweet, resting in a warm pie crust fresh from the oven. There is very little lingering dryness, though I easily thirst for more. If there were ever a perfect dessert beer or sophisticated aperitif, the Raspberry Tart from New Glarus is all one needs. A gentle coating within my mouth blossoms raspberry and cream with a touch of vanilla and crust. She doesnt last long in my glass at all. As I savor the last drop, a whisper of dry wood touches the roof of my mouth, and is gone. All that is left are sweet memories of freshly served raspberry tart.


Im not into really sweet things anymore. I prefer a more artisanal interplay of opposition and cooperation. The Raspberry Tart could be sickenly sweet, but New Glarus understands the artistry of balance. This is the perfect aperitif, after dinner delight, or party highlight to show off to your friends, family and strangers. Grab some champagne flutes, pour, sip, and lose yourself to her sinfully delicious delights. You deserve it.

Bottle shared generously by footbalm. Pours a bright red-brown color with a medium white head. The aroma is sweet raspberries, tartness and super sweet. The flavor is similar; amazingly natural flavors of sweet and in the finish quite tart raspberries. Light oak and vanilla perhaps, but this beer is all about the fruit, and I like me some red raspberries. Very awesome for what it is.

75cl bottle courtesy of Ughsmash. Pours a dark ruby with thin white head. Aroma is sweet and fruity with notes of raspberries, syrupy esters, light tartness. Flavor is sweet and fruity with notes of ripe raspberries, fresh jam, fruity esters, yeast, light carbonation. Generally medium body with a pleasing sweet and fruity finish.

UPDATED: AUG 10, 2009 Bottle. Pours a dark red color with a medium pink head. Smell is of raspberries. Taste is full of raspberrys up front with a nice tartness on the finish. Very well done fruit beer.
bottle, dark red brownish color, small pink foam, aroma of bready raspberry, jammy flavor but was a little less than expected, nicely made

Bottle. Poured a dark red with a small reddish head. Aroma was full of raspberries and had a nice tart bite to it. Flavor began a bit sweet raspberries but lead to a more tart finish. An amazing fruit beer.

750 mL bottle shared at Immys Backyard Throwdown.  Originally purchased at Discount Liquor in Milwaukee, WI on September 15, 2007.  WOW!  What a spectacular beer.  Pours a murky, muddy red similar in appearance to the Belgian Red but a little darker.  Strong, tart raspberry aroma.  Big, flavorful raspberry flavor blended with wheat to balance and not overwhelm with its tartness.  A spectacular fruit beer from New Glarus every bit the equal of Belgian Red.
750mL..amazing aroma, raspberries are predominant, but not overwhelming, excellent tartness

750 ml bottle courtesy of a trade with brentfeesh.  Pours a murky pinkish/reddish amber with a moderate tan head that lasted through the first third of the glass.  Huge aroma of fresh raspberries.  The flavor is again filled with tons of fresh raspberries along with just a bit of malt, brown sugar and just a hint of vanilla.  Wow!  The mouthfeel is creamy while at the same time tangy from the raspberries.  Reminds me of a raspberry parfait.  I shared this bottle at my sons graduation party yesterday, and everyone who tried it, really liked it.  Delicious!

Original review date 4/28/2008...

From 750 to Bristol Motor Speedway mug...

Deep raspberry red with thick, bready raspberry sherbet-colored head. Cloudy, frothy and nicely carbonated.

Strong aroma of fresh raspberry puree. Natural, perfumy creaminess with slight kick of yeast and carbonation.

Beautiful character of naturally fermented raspberries. Tasty, yeasty presence blends well to make this quite fulfilling. Extremely tangy with moderate carbonation - similar to a champagne-juice mix.

Feels like a creamy version of a sour raspberry soda - well-balanced with no aftertaste; bubbles create interesting zip on finish.

The ABV is quite manageable and this is awesome stuff. Surprisingly its quite filling! Can imagine only 1 or 2 per sitting to enjoy and savor. Excellent!

bottle thanks to thirdeye11.  purple pour with a light pink head.  nose is tart with fresh plucked raspberries, imagine that.  amazingly smooth and the raspberries are not overkill at all.  this is one very enjoyable brew.

Mmm, I love raspberry. 
I dont know what to say about this beer other than its simply amazing.

Reddish-caramel color with a nice, medium-sized head. Strong aroma of raspberries. Flavor is a nice mix of sweet and sour and very strong raspberry. Still prefer the Belgian Red ale with cherries, but this is a strong second.

Reddish-brown pour with a white head infused with a red tinge. sweet raspberry aroma with a hint of sourness to it. Sweet tasting- raspberry. It goes well with the hops and wheat. I gave some to my Miller Lite swill-drinking hillbilly neighbor and He even liked it. It is a very well rounded beer.

Bottle, Coffee Grounds, Eau Claire, Sconsin.  Reddish Brown pour.  Amora is very raspberryish.  Tastes like raspberries, a little sour and tart on the finish.

Fuckin awesome.  Buy it anytime you see it, unless you dont like raspberries.

Bottle. Pours murky reddish brown, with a very thin tan head. Aroma is somewhat tart, with aroma of real raspberries and wood. Flavor of fresh raspberries, brown sugar, and slight lactic acid. Finish is fairly tart, and a little astringent. Really great stuff!
A great tasting fruit beer. sweet but not too sweet. something everyone can enjoy.
Bottle. Thanks to Rciesla for sharing. Great beer with a nice aroma and full flavor. Was interesting when mixed with a small amount of black chocolate stout.

On draft at Sugar Maple.  Pours a hazy dark red with reddish head.  Aroma is tart raspberry possibly with some other sweet fruits.  Flavor is ultra-sweet raspberry upfront and finishes very tart.  The sourness lasts quite a bit after swallowing.  This is one amazing fruit beer.  I bought a couple bottles to share at a wedding this past weekend, and got rave reviews from both beer drinkers and non.  I got several "This is beer?" statements from people.  Thanks for having this on tap Sugar Maple.

Bottle thanks to Awiseman01. Pours a bubbling raspberry red with a big but disappearing raspberry stained head. Raspberry donut filling, fresh raspberry, slight vinegar, oak notes, very sweet with a big tartness on top. Great beer in small doses.

So I just moved from WI, and I probably took New Glarus for granted.  I had a mini-panic attack when I realized that I hadnt rated this beer before I moved; thanks to Flyer for giving me a second chance at this beer.

Ive had the Belgian Red a few times, and found the quality to be rather hit and miss.  Sometimes Ive liked it, sometimes not so much.  Not sure if this beer has the same consistency issues, but this bottle was terrific.

Color was a dark blood-red color with some light white effervescence.  Aroma was light and fruity, but more tart than sweet.  Flavor was sweet enough to be quite palatable, but again more tart than not.  This tart seemed somehow more true to the fruit than an overly sweet Lindemans frambose ever could be.  Reminded me of a Cantillon frambose.  Flavor was quite good.  Mouthfeel was fairly dry, like a good red wine, but without some of the drying astringency.

Ive not been a fan of New Glarus beers, living in WI gave me the pragmatism to be critical at times rather than to fawn.  But this beer is quite good and Id highly recommend.
1pt9oz bottle @Tampa Wkly Gathering-pours light pink head and cloudy red color.  Aroma is sweet raspberry.  Taste is sweet raspberry with some tart-medium malt.

Bottle.  Poured a a deep reddish color with a thn off-white head.  Nose is dominated by raspberries.  Flavor is also dominated by tart raspberry, very sweet but not cloying.  Alcohol is not noticeable.  Very much like lightly carbonated raspberry juice.  Great flavor.

Bottle - Looks and smells wonderful, with a deep rose pour, a fizzy head, and real raspberries on the nose. Theres definitely cherries in there too -- sweet and rich. Taste is the same -- raspberries, cherries, and a little woody, oaky flavor. The finish is tart and a little dry. Just a touch of hops and spice on the end. Its smooth and creamy on the mouth, but the carbonation bites a bit. While its a little syrupy and heavy, it never seems cloying to me. I was worried about it being too sweet and cloying, but its restrained enough that its like drinking liquid dessert without coating your mouth for the next two hours.
Sour. Frutity. A desert beer that I know not to do by myself - as I have done with others. Sweet. Syrupy. Excellent.

Big thanks to kmadison for this gem.  Pours raspberry red with a fruity/ vanilla nose.  Flavor confirms this as a dessert beer, and a cordial.  Flavor has tons of fresh, hairy, tart raspberries.  Excellence in a fruit beer- just enough hops to bring out the sweetness- like salting chocolate cookies.  Mild/ moderate carbonation and medium mouthfeel.  This is a symphony where everything blends to make music.
Completely amazing. Before this beer, I wouldnt give fruit beers a second thought. I am humbled.

Bottle from RustyChiles, thanks man!  Poured a deep ruby red color with an inch thick light pink head that faded to a thin layer.  Aroma of fresh raspberry jam, a light yeastiness, and some faint Hallertau grass notes.  Smooth, sweet entry with a strong raspberry fruitiness paired with a tart berry skin leads into a light yeastiness that finished lightly dry with some soft hoppiness.  Moderate carbonation and solid mouth feel.  Overall, a very solid example of a fruit beer, but still a bit too sweet for my tastes.  Thanks again Rusty.
Strong Raspberry aroma and flavor... very tart... with some sweetness... well balanced
Dark dark red/purple pour with a pinkish head. Lots of carb. Sweet and unripe fruit tartness. Tons of raspberry flavor. Amazing beer.

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2009 bottle poured into a flute has a dark ruby red color and one finger of fink froth. aroma has pureed raspberry, sweetness, and berry tart. flavor has a sweet and tart thing, loads of raspberry, berry seeds, and sweetness. really thick like pureed berry. certainly in a class of its own as far as being a fruit beer.

Pours a dark red color with a small, foamy pink head. The aroma was full on fresh raspberries both sweet and tart along with some residuak sugar. The flavor follows with the sweet and tart fresh raspberries. The flavor comes in waves with the sweet followed by the tart raspberries. Full bodied and thick on the mouthfeel and just shy of syrupy with a sweet-tart finish from all the raspberries. Very nice fruit beer, but one I couldnt drink a lot of.

Whooo!  At first sniff, I thought I was not going to like this one.  Smelled like raspberry yogurt vomitus.  But, after appreciating its subtle beauty through a frosty Blatz glass, I slammed it down and let the raspberries take me away.  Very niiiiice as Borat would say.  This may now be my second favorite raspberry beer (With Crazy Shirleys Raspberry Disaster taking full honors and accolades.)  Dont question it.  Drink it.

Bottle. wow this one pours with a bright red color and fairly subdued carbonation. probably the most intense fruit I ever had in a beer almost like syrup. Perhaps a bit too sweet, aromas have a bit of faint hops in it, 
flavorwise it is pure raspberry. Nice but I like the Cherry better.

750 ml bottle:  This one pours a murky browish-red color.  Mine had a small fizzy head on it that went away almost immediately.  No lacing.  Nice nose.  It is pretty much tart raspberry and not much else.  There is a good body to it, but still a lighter mouthfeel.  There is some effervescence in your mouth.  The taste is mainly tart raspberries, but it is not overpowering.  It is very unique.  It is almost hard to classify this as a beer, but it is very good none the less.  I would definitely buy this one again.
So smooth and tasty and fruity, this is one delicious beer!  Yummy!

Source: 750 mL waxed bottle in a trade with illinismitty.Appearance:  Cloudy red color with a two finger pink head.  Head quckly dissipated and left spotty lacing.Aroma:  Raspberries, residual sugars and booberries.Flavor: The flavor was very tart raspberry.  There wasnt much else.  No bitter finish, just mouth puckering raspberry. Palate:  Medium/full body and full, chewy mouthfeel.  This was a surprisingly heavy beer.Overall:  This was great for a fruit beer.  I was concerned about the potential for a bottle of medicine, but this didnt disappoint.
Pours out a slushy red. Aroma of raspberries, and goodness. Flavor is super sweet, and full of raspberries, a bit tart and puckering... its like a liquid raspberry pie without the seeds.

UPDATED: MAY 4, 2009 Pours a murky brownish red with a small pink head.  Fresh red raspberries dominates the aroma, just a faint whiff of oak and yeast peek through every now and then.  Flavor is as expected - this beer is just bursting with tart raspberries.  A touch of oak and maybe just a hint of floral hops in the finish.  Substantial body, yet quite effervescent at the same time.  A wonderful beer, but obviously only if you like raspberries.

Beautiful amber red pour with a light rim of creamy foam. Aroma of yeast, deep ripe berries and fresh bread. This would be prefect for a brunch. Nice and spritzy while retaining a solid mouthfeel. The beer is the essence of eating fresh toasted brown grain bread with the boldest raspberry jam. An absolute gem.

Warm, rubescent-amber with ring of head. Rich, sugared raspberry swarms the olfactory sense. Sweet, sticky, sugary raspberry flavors. Lots of residual sugar. Pure raspberry flavor, no real tartness or off-flavors. Ok in 2-3 oz doses, but otherwise, cloying and un-balanced. A dessert beer and nothing else. Liquid, carbonated raspberry preserves. Raspberry madness for sure.

loved this brew. probably my favorite raspberry beer. pours rich dark red. tons of fresh raspberrys on the nose and through out the drink. lots of fizz and great tart flavor make this a great drinker. absolutly great
750ml bottle. Pours dark red color. Aroma is fruity with a hint of raspberry. I think you can guess the taste of this one. Very good indeed.

Just as nice as the Belgian Red counterpart, this was amazing.  Truly a desert beer, the color was a great dark hue.  The aroma came out as soon as it hit my glass, and the taste did not disappoint.  God i wish i lived closer to New Glarus.

Pours a nice red color with a bubbly head.  Aroma is nice and fruity and sweet.  Flavor is where its at.  Its so fruity and delicious and sweet and wonderful.  Carbonation is nice and full.  I really like this beer.

There are not many breweries in the entire world that make constantly amazing and well constructed brews, i mean, with New Glarus, it will always be something highly enjoyable.. 

Raspberry Tart goes over this rule, an amazing brew!


Pours a vibrant red with a man pink head, great lacing of course and exceptional strength of the foam .. 


Smell is of light berry and fruit juice, subtle...

Pure wonderment in a bottle, bliss in glass, enjoyment at its core, just simply a joy to drink..
The sweetness and mouthfeel are so polite and refined, while still holding there ground, full and respectable, a beer! a good beer!!

sitting here on such a nice day with a beer of this caliber i now know what lottery winners do on their private islands.. 

Raspberry Tart!


thanks to John for getting me a bottle, i will need more..
at the very least to inject into my veins!!
Pours deep garnet with no head. Nose of raspberries and vanilla. Same in the flavor with a full mouthfeel and tart yet sweet finish.

750 ml bottle from discount liquors (milwaukee, wi). Split with my girlfriend. Pours a deep dark largely clear dark reddish hue, a touch of copper, but very burnt red with moderate reddish head that dissipates to a small amount and laces. Aromas are nice aromatic raspberry, light sourness and sweetness, with a natural feel. Initial is lightly tart, nice tannin like feel, moving to mixing tart and sweet natural raspberry, light maltiness, but largely natural raspberry with little yeast or malt. Sweet and tart, light carbonation, creating a balance that prevents cloying qualitiws. Hard to drink a ton of this, but a well executed fruit beer that is considerably different that the typical fare. Nice.
Dark red, pleasing aroma, geat raspberry taste.   Very nice from start to finish.   I prefer Belgian Red, but this is a very close second.

Bottle shared by Dogbrick.  Cloudy dark red pour with a thin pink head.  Sweet and juicy raspberry aroma with a hint of yeast.  Tastes like straight up raspberry juice with a hint of citrus to sour it up.  I still prefer Belgian Red, but this one is mighty tasty too.  No one does fruit beers like NG.

UPDATED: APR 9, 2010 Courtesy of pfoxyjohn. Pours a crimson color with a thin pink head. A crazy amount of fresh raspberries in this, sweet and tart but neither overly done and a nice balance of the two. Very soft on the palate and a little bit of malt behind it. Actually, this is incredibly thick, it tastes like they mashed an insane amount of raspberries in this. Quite tasty. One of the better fruit beers Ive had and a style Im starting to enjoy a little more now than I once did. Thanks pfoxyjohn!  Re-rate.  Awesome.  Insane fresh raspberry aroma and flavor.  Like the whole plant is in there.  Soft malty sweet complexity.  I think I prefer Belgian Red but its very close.
Another Thanks to Kingpin IPA.  Smell was outstanding with raseberries and sweentess.  Beautiful color and it was nice and tart as well

A fruit beer that does not disappoint its namesake.  Very enjoyable and pronounced raspberry aroma .   Fruit juice in appearance with a thin head and ample fruit bouquet.  Tart but balanced with natural sweet and ale drinkability.

Both this and the Belgian Red are great.  This one I perhaps enjoyed more because it did not affect my stomach, but I did not let that impact my rating of the Belgian Red because the beers are similar so it may have been the day.

UPDATED: MAY 7, 2009 Overall? One of the best fruit beers Ive ever had. It tastes like raspberries, it smells like must and raspberries and the nose is all raspberries. Looks like raspberry juice with a thin wisp of pink head. Finishes clean with almost a salty note.

750ml. Pours a murky red color with a small pink head. Nose is tart and fresh raspberry. Initial taste is tart and mouth watering raspberry. Very fresh and natural tasting. Mid palate displays some eathiness. Finishing continuing tart raspberry. Definitely a desert in a bottle. Palate duration is above average.

Bottle shared by Daknole. Is there anything Daknole wont share? Color of pressed raspberry, a pure berry rich juice color. Not much head. Intense, dense raspberry aroma of pure crushed raspberry, seeds and all. Entry is pure tart, lip-puckering lovely fruit. Intense compacted fruit-tart concentrate. Finishes with lingering candy-like sweetness like sweet-sour candy. Very nice fruit beer.
Maroon in color and cloudy with a small pink head. Aroma is of freshly picked raspberries...ripe and tart. Flavor is of sweet raspberries and pastry. Full body.

750ml bottle courtesy of ughsmash.  Pour a dark red, almost purple in color.  A bit murky with a very thin pinkish head.  Nose is pure raspberry, very jam like and super fresh smelling.  Taste is just like the nose with the slight vinegary twang in there.  This is a very decadent beer and too much to drink a full bottle by yourself.  Thanks Jason for sending this one to me.
Bottle. This is like drinking a slice of raspberry pie. I would call this a desert beer and limit it to half a bottle.

aroma of thick sweet raspberry jam. sludge like. appearnce is quite nice, very dark red ive never seen before in a beer. flavor is at least slightly tart. though i cant give the brewers too much credit since that is the nature of the fruit. palate is super cloying and sticky. i can almost deal with the sweetness but not how much and long it lingers. another waste of time from new glarus. there is absoultely nothing beer like in this at all. i shared this with my mother since she loathes beer. she hated it as well, and became amazed with the high ratings for this and belgian red. she searched through pages looking for anything critical but alas could find nothing. no thank you to this marmalade.

Seven-fiddy ml.  Pours a beautiful dark ruby red with an emasculatingly pink head. Aroma is the freshest, most perfectly ripe example of raspberry youve ever laid your olfactory system on.  Taste is gen-u-wine berry and none of that syrup crap you so often taste in fruit beer.  I couldnt discern the aged hops or get much of the wheat character of the beer over the overpowering taste of berry.  Nicely carbonated and the perfect mouthfeel for the dessert beer this very clearly is.  Splitting a bottle with my wife verged on overdosing on sweet/tart, so would recommend splitting with at least 2 other people unless you regularly mainline liquid jolly ranchers and snort rails of Pixie Stix.

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2010 Bottle...  Poured deep reddish/burgundy with a pink head.  Tart and sour aroma with a little bit of raspberries.  Tasted of fresh, fresh, fresh -- did I say fresh -- raspberries.  It was amazingly pleasant and didnt taste artificial at all.  You could really taste the authenticity in the quality of the raspberries used.

750 ml bottle from Noblesquirrel. Pours a murky-cloudy purple color with a small pink head that soon dissipated. The aroma is big with fresh ripe red raspberries. The flavor is more of the same, raspberries, raspberries and more raspberries. The finish is extraordinarily long with (you guessed it) raspberries. The mouthfeel is medium with a bit of a gritty feel, which actually worked rather well as I can imagine seeds in the mix. Overall: Wonderful concoction with excellent drink-ability, the only negative that I can think of is that its not very tart.  Very tasty--perhaps the perfect desert beer. Thanks Brian.

Wax topped 750 pours a clear and radiant ruby body with a small and wispy pink head. Huge raspberry aroma with a hint of earthy mushroomy yeast underneath. Light body has a sparkly carbonation. Taste features freshly pureed raspberries, front, center, and finish. Just a hint of wheat malt midway through. Incredible drinkability. Tart and sweet, but anything but cloying. Excellent reason to travel to Wisconsin!

Bottle.  Pour was syrupy rich red color with excellent aroma of raspberries.  Flavor was rich, sour raspberries and funky yeast on the finish.  An excellent dessert beer worth sharing, but I would be able to finish an entire bottle by myself.

Pours a rusty brown with a pinkish head. Heavy carbonation. Aroma is huge on the raspberries, and thats about it. Taste is of raspberrries, with faint hops and oak. This beer is all about the raspberries, obviously. Taste is extremely tart and refreshing. Im not big on fruit beers, but this one is tasty.

Bottle shared by ajm at the 09er.  Pours a brilliant shade of amber that seems to glow.  Bursting with the aroma of sweet raspberries which carry into the flavor along with notes of cherries and red grapes.  A juicy confection, like something Willy Wonka would serve.  Fairly one note, but that note is rediculously good.

Thanks to Monger for trading me this.  Brilliant nose of sweet raspberries and gorgeous ruby appearance.  The addition of Hallertau hops was a shrewd move as it tinges the fruit flavor with a spicy outline.  However, the syrup level seems high and the flavor is my new definition of cloying.

UPDATED: APR 22, 2009 Appearance: Pours a murky, pinkish-brown body with a pink-hued, bubbly head.

Smell: Rich, fresh raspberry fruit aroma with a touch of tartness. Maybe a lil bit of heaven added, too.

Taste: Its delish! Raspberry compote with just the perfect balance of pleasing sweetness and tartness. Small tinge of bitter and oak character serve as a reminder that youre not simply feasting on fresh juice. Finishes with a long, lingering fruitiness.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium-plus carbonation.

Drinkability: Unrivaled drinkability. I can say, quite categorically, that New Glarus Raspberry Tart is a phenomenal, incredibly delicious beer. Its a damn shame all fruit beers cant be this good.

750 Bottle. Pours deep reddish purple with light purple head. Aroma is raspberries. Flavor is rich with raspberries and finishes tart. About as good as a fruit beer can get. Kind of like a combination of fruit wine and champange. Great stuff.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2009 750ml bottle bought in Wisconsin.  Wine red color,  Fizzy but quickly fading head.  Raspberry jam aroma.  This is the most flavorful raspberry beer Ive ever had.  Thick and sweet, not unlike a Lindemans, but somehow even better.  Sticky and luscious.  This is really an excellent, world class Raspberry Ale.

This is a great beer.  Pours a dark pink with a light pink head.  Lively carbonation.  Tart, but with a great raspberry flavor.  It somehow manages to avoid the "artificial" and slightly metallic taste that many beers in this category have.  This is easily one of my all-time favorite fruit beers.
Dark dark cherry red with two fingers of whitish red head.  Strong tart raspberry aroma, nice smooth wheat body is apparent.  A tart and sweet raspberry taste, seedy and ripe.

750 ml bottle.  My 400th rated beer! Hmmm this stuff is damn good.  Pours a dark cherry with a head that dissapears quickly.  Aroma and flavor is all raspberry...and very tart and a faint oakiness.  Meidum mouthfeel with a lively carbonation.
Rasberries throughout the whole brew, color, aroma, flavor. New glarus has mastered the art of fruit beer. Im so not worthy.

Rich, red-brown pour with a reddish foam head.  Lovely berry bouquet.  The flavor is rich raspberry jam and wine, with hints of cheese, raspberry soda pop, and lemonade.   It has a kind of essential flavor that is a little hard to pin down.  Well-balanced and goes down easy.  It is hard to believe this is a beer at all!  Another remarkable creation from New Glarus.
Delicious. Dark ruby color.  Smooth taste of raspberries. Has a enormous amount of flavor. Would buy again. Really liked it.

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2010 Thanks to fantomas23 for the bottle!Pours Ruby, fluffy pink head. Nose is all raspberries, rather singular. The flavor is a little more lactic but practically the same, very sweet. Mouth is refreshing but a little creamy in the aftertaste, not as crisp as Id hoped. Very tasty stuff, but I cant help wondering that there must be better tasting juice out there.Next to Blushing Monk and other raspberry beers. Transparent ruby body, beige cream head, light lacing. Nose and flavor destroy blushing monk, light vanilla and very sugary raspberry, almost a fruit juice. Flavor similar, sweet and short like a fruit juice. 747314

Back in the day I was a fiend for the raspberry beers, a lot has changed since those days. But one thing has not; this was then and remains to be a favorite of mine.  The beer pours a beautiful light purple with a large lasting pink head. Aroma is of fresh raspberries, a faint oak, and yeasty funk. The taste is remarkably tart and slightly sour and dominated by the fruit accented by yeast and very light malt. The beer is well rounded and has a sharp initial mouthfeel. 

Oh, and this was also served at my wedding too.

Deep purple color, true purple foam head. Great fruit beer, share with a mate. Too sugary, sweet tasting. Its raspberry and tart, period. A rare treat, glad to open with sleepy the night he takes the reigns at Ginger Man.

bottle thanks to BMan1113VR and shared with swalden 28.  poured a reddish brown with a pinkish/beige head.  aroma was that of rasberry and some liquid smoke.  flavor was rasberry and some cranberry as well.  this was my first sour and i enjoyed it greatly.  thanks Bman for this one!!

Bottle thanks to JB175...shared with Swalden_28, and ericsandersnavy. Pours a dark brown with some reddish highlights and a foamy light brown-to slightly pinkish head with some good lacing. Aroma of veery fresh raspberries, some berry brandy, a tart element, some farm, and a bit of smoke towards the very end. Taste is raspberry syrup with some light tartness and a touch of brett. Light mouthfeel, slightly creamy with lively bubbles.

Bottle thanks to BMan1113VR.
Pours a very nice looking raspberry color with beige/pink head. Aroma of tart raspberry and some farmhouse mixed in. Flavor is very good, raspberry,  tartness, some Brett.....Mouth feel is light-med. body, high carbonation. VERY VERY GOOD, I want more.......

750 ml bottle.  Pours a nice rich red color with a aggressive pink head.  Aroma is very bold scent of fresh raspberries.  Almost smells like candy...yummy!  Flavor is a tart/sour raspberry.  Exactly like I expected.  It is very effervescent and almost heavy.  At some points it reminds me of a soda.  Very delicious and easy to drink, so much that I downed the whole bottle myself.  A great beer that everyone must get their hands on at some point.

750ml bottle.  Had a slight gush of foam when opening.  Pours a lovely burgundy with a pinkish head which dissipated.  Smell was concentrated raspberry and veggie.  Maybe a little sour.  Wonder if this one sat too long.  Taste was sour raspberries.  Mouthfeel was sticky sweet and very carbonated.  Decent, but not as good as expected.  Will give another go when I get a bottle again.

Bouquet is raspberry in abudance.  Deep clear red pour, dark pink head, some lace.  Raspberry is all over the flavor. Very sweet, but not without tartness.  A chocolate malt undertone hides underneath the fruit.  Soft, tiny bubbles on the palate.  Thick, borderline syrupy.

UPDATED: NOV 8, 2012 Bottle, sampled at RBSG 08. Pours a deep, brown-red, with a pink head. Huge raspberry aroma. Sweet and tart raspberry taste. Lingering sweetness. Very tasty raspberry beer.

2010 bottle. Pours a dark amber-brown with an off-white head that fades to a ring. Sweet, juicy aroma, of raspberries, sugar, and a hint of malt. Taste is more tart, of raspberry juice, malt, and sugar. Nice carbonation. Lingering juiciness. Very tasty.

A little difficult for me.  A fresh fruit taste just does not fit with me and beer.  Other than than that, the raspberry taste is so fresh and tart my wife who hates beer, and loves wine coolers loves this, obviously hints at how well New Glarus pulls this off that I need to remind myself that something like this is a great thing to have on hand so that you have something for everyone.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2009 Aroma is intense berry, color is a brilliant ruby.  Fantastic taste that reminds me of a raspberry infusion dessert wine that Ive had before.  The description says it all, tart raspberry.   Sourness is balanced out nicely with the sweet malt base; also a hint of oak.  Theres just the slightest hint of bitterness.  Nice clean tart finish.  I think this is a small step below the Belgian Red, but not by much.

murky dark cloudy deep red pour, very interesting look. A big fluffy pink head. Aroma is a slap in the face of smashed raspberries, and sugar. Flavour is like a very sweet raspberry compote, but the finish has a nice tangy tartness, this is a superb beer!

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2011 Bottle courtesy of Cameron on 10/22/2010. Hazy red body with a small pink head. Sweet raspberry aroma with light tart notes. Slightly tart raspberry flavor. Medium light body with moderately high carbonation.
8/3/9/4/16 - 4.0

Bottle at RBSG2008 Grand Tasting on 08/02/2008. Hazy red body with a reddish pink head. Huge raspberry aroma. Very sweet raspberry flavor. Medium body with moderately low carbonation.
8/3/9/4/17 - 4.1

Had as a lovely finish to a lovely anniversary. Bottle from Hogtown harry. murcky purplish color, with nice pinkish beige head. nose is totally rasberries, amazing. flavor is tart but with a little sweetness, nice champagne like carbonation. great beer.
750ml bottle, thanks to sirpsycho for the trade. Poured a murky red, nice white head. Nice raspberry aroma. Tart raspberry flavor as well. Good beer.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Its a glass of raspberry juice.  Plain and simple.  Aroma, raspberries.  Appearance is raspberry red color with a red head that dissipates to lacing.  Flavor is raspberries.  Palate is a little sweet and a little tart but not much in either.  Good carbonation.  If you like raspberries, you’ll like this.
Thanks to Inkubus27 for the bottle!  Muddy red pour and fluffy red head.  Minimal spotty lace.  Fresh raspberry on the nose.   Very similar flavor profile.  Tart up front, oak & fruity finish.

From bottle : Been waiting awhile to drink this one.  Pours a red hazy color with a reddish tinted foamy head.  The big fruity nose is in your face as soon as it goes into the glass.  The smell is of wonderfully fresh raspberries.  Taste is much the same, mainly all raspberries,  and it really isnt tart like the name would indicate.  Very nice aftertaste of raspberries.  Overall a very enjoyable brew, smell, look and taste, great stuff.

Wow. This stuff is stunning. Gorgeous, dark reddish-purple colour with a hint of brown. Rather murky, as though someone had just pureed some raspberries and poured them in. Aroma of fresh rasperries. Taste? Go figure -- raspberries. Like drinking a raspberry cordial, without the cloying sweetness. Tart? Not so much, though there’s a hint of acidity on the finish. But a beautiful beer to look at, to smell, and to savour.

Very nice dark red pour with pink head. Aroma is full of tart raspberries. Flavor is a perfect balance of sweet and tart, with a nice range of notes from other fruits. Slick, slightly sticky mouthfeel. Passed it around the family and everyone loved it. Another wonderful beer from New Glarus.

Appearance is a cloudy and dense raspberry red hue, moderate amount of rose colored head dissipates to a ring, very little lacing left on the glass. Aroma is sweet and tart raspberries along with a range of other berries and sweet fruits, definitely reminiscent of thick fruit jams or purees. Taste is unsurprisingly full of big sweet raspberries with any accompanying sugar tartness, tones of strawberries, fruit sorbet, and yeast peek through very slightly, this is just hands down an amazingly crafted fruit beer. Medium-bodied, texture is slick and smooth, carbonation is prickly and lively. Very high on the sweet and tart factor that is hard to handle in large quantities, best enjoyed with friends in smaller sipping glasses or after dinner.

Good god what a beer. Holy shit.  Nice cloudy reddish pour with a puffy white head that disappears quickly.  Aroma is sweet/tart of raspberries.  Flavor is just unreal.  The blanace between sweet and sour is remarkable.  Tastes like homeade rasp preserves with a nice squeeze of lemon juice.  Wow, I need more.  The wife LOVED it.

Bottle. Gorgeous earthy red pour. Aroma of fresh, fresh raspberries, pie crust. Flavor of fresh, natural, tart raspberry jam, lots of raspberry seed, just oozing with raspberry that you can almost chew on. I need more bottles of this pronto. Magical.

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2009 Bottle courtesy of iowaherkeye (thanks Joey!).  Pours a murky dark red with a small pink head.  Aroma is wow!  Quite powerful.  Lots of raspberry, also raspberry pie and butteriness.  Flavor is very similar, lots of raspberry, fairly tart, raspberry seed, maybe some plum.  Very similar to Lindemanns Framboise but its better and more complex.  Such a tasty beer!

WOW!!! Very suprised by this one. Pours a very cloudy brick red. Aroma hits the nose with glass still five feet away. Sweetness hits up front, but Hallertau bitterness finds its way through all the flavor and give some structure to what could have easily been an out of balance beer. I think I may have liked this more than the Belgian Red from NG.

Bottle courtesy of Cartdan. Pours cloudy ruby almost red with a pink head.
Aroma is filled with rapsberries.
Taste of raspberries all over, light notes of tart fruits, but the beer remains very sweet.
Sips leave a tingly feeling on palate and tongue, typical of that kind of fruits.

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2014 Bottle. Purple color, cloudy. Strong raspberry aroma with some dust and marzipan. Sweet, even sugary sweet but also tart flavor. lemon and marzipan. Full bodied, thick mouthfeel. Lovely long tart raspberry aftertaste. Liked this beer very much, in spite of the intense sweetness.

Re-rate at ZZTX, november 2014. Pink color. Bottle Rapberry jam and dusty notes in the aroma. Sweet flavor with raspberry jam. Lemon, soft oaky notes, Sticky. Moderate sourness next to the almost sugary sweetness.   Would be very nice as a sauce over ice cream

Poured a dark red color with a small off white head. Aroma was sweet/sour raspberries and thats it. Flavor was much te same, all raspberries, but natural taste, not artificial. Tastes like Raspberry Tootsie ops without the chocolate. Very good and just below the Belgian Red.

Bottle poured to flute.  Pours opaque ridish/purple and small white head.  Strong aroma of sweet berrys.  Barely any hops or malts in the aroma or flavor profile.  Very berry.  Tingly and acidic on sides of the tounge.  Very pleasant berry taste: not fake or overly sweet.  Just a splendid drink to share with a loved one.
75 cL bottle. Pours hazy to murky red with a pink head. Aroma is dense raspberry fruity and mild sulphorish. Sweet and slight herbal raspberry fruity note. Sticky sweet and linger fruity finish.

Poured from a wax-topped 750ml bottle and served in a shaker.  This beer poured a muddy, raspberry puree burgandy with a quickly fading pink head.  No lace.  Almost looked like raspberry concentrate.  The aroma of the beer was made up of sugar and fresh raspberries.  Huge...the aroma filled the air around the glass.  The flavor consisted of fresh raspberries macerated in sugar.  Wow.  Hard to believe this is beer!  The mouthfeel was medium-bodied and surprisingly refreshing and drinkable for something this sweet.  The carbonation was moderate.  Equal in quality to the Belgian Red, its just a matter of which fruit you happen to prefer.  Ill take the Raspberry.

On tap pours red with a thin white head.  The aroma on this beer was amazing.  Exploding raspberries was what I got every time I smelled it.  And I took a smell each time I drank.  It was wonderful.  Had a medium mouthfeel with a lot of tiny carbonation bubbles.  The taste of this is very subtle, yet complex.  High raspberry flavor throughout and is very sweet.  I could enjoy this with a nice flourless chocolate cake for dessert and be the happiest person on the planet.  This is a great brew.

Pours a beautiful murky raspberry red with a bubbly pink head that lingers for a little while and leaves some sporadic lacing.  I imagine this would be what unfiltered raspberry or cranberry juice looks like.

Wow! wonderful smell on this one as sweet raspberries are the dominant aroma with a hint of tartness as well, possibly from some cherries.

Taste follows the aroma with the obvious raspberry dominance and hint more tartness than in the aroma up front.  There are hints of "beer" flavors in there with some wheat if you really look hard, but it’s really all about the raspberries here.

Mouthfeel is medium bodied with big carbonation that tickles your tongue with the raspberry tartness and then sticks the sweetness on the palate in the finish.
