Courtesy of MIBRomeo.  Thanks!  After ive had the Belgian Red i wanted to try this.  Very sweet Rasberry smell, smells great.  Very sweet, medium bodied, smooth, and just a nice beer.  Wish i had eaten it with a cheescake or some other desert, but hey, work with what ya got.  Overall a very good beer, but just like the belgian red, i think it would be hard to drink more than 6 oz of this because of the sweetness.

Bottle, thanks to iowaherkeye.  Pours a delicious deep purple color with a thick pink head.  Aromas of fresh raspberries...and thats about it.  Very sour, tart raspberry flavor, very refreshing.  I could drink a lot of this.  Great bubbly, yet coating mouthfeel.  A wonderful beer.
user_location: The Land of Milk and Honey, Ohio, USA

text: Raspberry Tart is a serious fruit beer but with a low alcohol content.  Looks just like a Cabernet wine except with a low foamy light pink head that laced the glass to the finish.  Aroma is exactly what the name implies, strong black raspberry with a touch of hops.  The flavor, again, is just as the name implies, strong, sweet black raspberry with a touch of hops, yeast, oak, and carbonation.  Overall tart and sweet.  I found this Rasberry Tart very fun to drink.
Aromas of black raspberys and a hint of hops.Pours dark red with a pink head.Flavor is very sour with  strong raspberry.Medium to full mouthfeel with a bitter sour raspberry finish.

UPDATED: JUN 26, 2007 Pours a dark blood red with a frothy pink head.  If it wasnt for the foam I would think it was wine in my glass.  Intense raspberry sour smell, very thick.  I knew this one was gonna be something special.  The taste was even more intense, very thick, kind of explodes in your mouth and makes it pucker up as its not ready for the tannins.  Kind of tastes like a sweet tart.  Very sweet and sugary, finish is long and stays on the tongue and the sides of the mouth.  Very unique and interesting beer.  it was a nice treat.

Cold wax capped 750ml bottle from 2003:  Pours a clear dark amber color with minor light tan bubbles around edges.  Aroma is of raspberry, light grains and wood notes.  Taste is of raspberry and light grains with sweet and tart notes.  Light to medium bodied with fizzy mouthfeel.  Ending is of tart raspberry.

Poured into a champagne flute, this beer is deep red - almost the same color as beet juice actually. Very fizzy carbonation gives it a brief but tall (at least 2") head of very pink foam. The aroma is like raspberry pie filling.

The flavor is more of that raspberry pie filling - thich and potently full of raspberry and more raspberry. The raspberry flavor is both tart and sweet, both fresh and baked, and absolutely natural. Perhaps its my imagination, perhaps its the color, but I also taste just a hint of beet in there too. 

Thats it - all fruity. Bold, full, and flavorful. The fizzy champagne-like carbonation is a nice touch. A great beer!

Deep rubin red body, huge pink head; Great nose, lots of raspberry, some oak, rot and a very little hop sack; Small amount of sharp sparkle in body, soft very pleasant texture, some sweetness and loads of lactic and acetic acid; The acids explodes when the beer is swallowed, a short very pleasant explosion that is soon taken over by lots of raspberry fruity acidity, soft textured with lots of aroma. Super, super beer that actually has a few lambic elements to it. Thanks iowaherkeye!!!

Bottle @ January DMBT.  Man, these New Glarus guys are masters at the fruit beers.  This is sweet, with a bit of sourness to it, but the balance is remarkable.  Not quite as good as the Belgian Red, but very very good.

750ml bottle curtesy of Naven, thanks for bringing this gem.  Beer 4 of the Bartzillas Death Metal Beer Tasting 1/12/2007, consumed with many great beer drinkers including Bartzilla, Naven, as well as Lee creator of Arrogant Bastard, and a really cool guy. 

This is a fantastic fruit beer, it is sweet and sour and really evokes rasberries almost better than the fruit itself.  Ive been really excited to try this beer for a a while, and it tastes great.  While we were drinking this someone said it tasted like flinstones vitatmins, and really it sort of does, it has a taste that resembles that but it is not chalky or concentrated in any way, it is a really fantastic brew that I feel lucky to have had.

Like all NG, this one is way overrated. Everything about this beer is artificial. I know they use real raspeberry, but sure dont tsate like it. Tastes like flat redpop. MMMMM, faygo. I agree, similar to Lindemans crap.

First of all, a big thanks to mwsf for this bottle.  Massive raspberry flavor.  Pretty tart as well.  A little chocolate.  Clearly a hell of a lot of fresh raspberries are used in this.  Its sweet and with a delicate sourness.  Similar to a flemish sour, but with a ton of fruit.  I enjoy it until the pure raspberry flavor in the finish.  I guess nows the time to point out that Im not a huge fan of raspberries in general, but Im still enjoying this.

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2007 A lot of sweet beers, like well made framboises and krieks, are exceptional at capturing the natural flavor of the fruit they represent.  Despite a very meticulous protocol of processing, thermal shock and movement they end up tasting like pure nectar bleeding straight from natures dulcet vines.  The lesser variants tend to taste like they were made from syrup spewed out from an industrial complex, smokestack and all.  I never knew until now that there could be mediation between these two ideas.  New Glarus Raspberry Tart has shown me the way.  As I peer down into the glass of this luxurious drink I see a roseate head that could easily be misconstrued for a fancy strawberry cake.  Meanwhile the body of the beer is murky and quiet with contentment, deep with passion, and as dark red as cardiac muscle.  It sits with a silent Bacchanalian joy that whispers alluring, sweet and aromatic poetry from its top.  The smell instantly transports you to a sunny, verdant farm where youre jarring raspberry preservatives in their rawest form  seeds and all.  The sweet, fruity sugar packs the nose all the way to the sinuses, almost shoving raw natural fructose down your throat before your lips have had a chance to satiate themselves.  The taste is matured, and not as bitter as the more organic fruit beers tend to be.  Its more processed, but only insofar as a compact and colorful tart or an immaculate cake is processed.  Its not industrial, but artisanal, being fashioned from a craftmans hands rather than a moving line of metal hooks and blades.  It feels capacious with expression, boundless but narrowed in its type.  It feels a shame to categorize this beer into any one identity, because at the first sip it feels like it transcends names and identities.  It merely becomes fruit.  At least, thats all that was on my mind.  Pear and apple join the flavorful fray a bit later, and with a bit more degrees (Fahrenheit) acting on the beer a bit of confectioners sugar comes to play.  With all these sugary flavors it might seem a bit much.  It really pushes the boundaries, but New Glarus Raspberry Tart stays a hair short from being cloyingly sweet.  That doesnt mean you should go paring it with savory dishes like filet mignon or salmon.  Its simply moderate enough that it wont crystallize your blood with excess sugar granules.  Take it for what it is  a very sweet, still fruity and opulent beer fit for richness.

From trade with brewblackhole. Poured a deep dark red. The head was medium body and pink. The aroma spelled strongly of raspberry, very tart, sweet, and some spice. The flavor had the same attributes, very big tart/sweet flavor. The palate had harsh hints from the tartness and a lambic effervescence. Excellent fruit beer.

Im one of those annoying guys who reviews a style that he doesnt like to begin with, so i apologize up front.  Either way I am a resident of wisconsin so it is my duty to review new glarus.  Tastes pleasant but is typical for a frambriose.  lacks the the unique complexity of the other lambic (Belgian Red) they produce.  However if you are a fan of the style I reccomend that you try this one.

Deep garnet/red in color, topped with a first class pink raspberry mousse.  Aroma of raspberry, vanilla and oak, like the worlds next award winning ice cream that will astonish and captivate the audience on Rachel Ray or Oprah.  Deep in flavor with lemon, orange, and a honey-oak middle admist the raspberry goodness that frames it all.  Like Belgian Red, it tastes irresistably fresh, and it just barely can be classified as beer, even as one that is infinitely more sweet and sour than it is bitter or robust.  Still, for me, it reaches for transcendence and nearly gets there.

Rapidly succeeding the tremendous effort New Glarus named Enigma, Raspberry Tart was this time where all my long-standing expectations of the brewery lay. It might be useful to remind of my near fanaticism for raspberries, the zeal those tiny plump fruits muster in me, seemingly disproportionate but merely the product of countless beautiful memories. A passionate scarlet juice draped in fizzy pink cloth reflects liquidly the quiddity of the fruit. Little more can be said of the nose which seems to capture in a concentrated form the essence of raspberries, decupling every nuance and raising the soul to a veritable apotheosis. Sugary marshmallow, cherry, grape and oak add to the experience, suggesting a certain depth while raspberry continues to dominate the bouquet. The sumptuous flavor is assumed and appears in its natural form enhanced by sticky grape juice, fig, caramel and a slight sourness. What worries me is that New Glarus has simply reproduced my mothers raspberry jelly in liquid form. Not that its facile, but perhaps... unnecessary. I need a beer that reconcile its status as a beer with the bully raspberries can be. Leave the quintessence to my tartines, I need something with complexity and balance that takes advantage of beer as medium.

(750 ml bottle via trade with <A HREF=http://www.ratebeer.com/View-User-38026.htm target=blank>buckybeer, thanks Mark!) Christmas Eve beer 2006. Red and tasty...Pours crimson with two fingers of light red head. Pungent aroma of sour/tart berries. Mouthfeel soft and smooth, lightly effervescent. Lacing is kind of spotty. Flavor is lightly sourish and pretty tart raspberry/cherry/cranberry. Will kind of remind you of a wine cooler or even raspberry soda but is still a great fruit beer, definitely the tastiest Ive had. I loved the fresh berry flavor. Nice quality feel.

Deep dark red with a light pink thin frothy head. Nice looking. Rich raspberry aroma, but the kicker is the taste. I dont know how much variance there is from batch-to-batch, but this stuff is awesome. Full flavored tart raspberry (go figure). But beneath the tart quality is a lot of balancing sweet character. Great stuff.

Thin light brownish red head of fine bubbles.  Light carbonation.  Huge amounts of sweet raspberries and white grape inthe aroma.  Amazingly, though, with this much fruit in the aroma it does not smell synthetic.  Color is a dark crimson brown.  Sweet, tart and fruity.  Excessive fruitness.  Very sweet.  This brew will definately not appeal to everyone.  Strange fruit in the middle and then ends in delicious red raspberries.  I dont really detect any sourness like other are claiming.  Maybe a little at the finish.  Mild tartness which dissipates into a smooth sweet finish.  Pretty damn good.  Not sure how much I can drink of this though.

Big sour raspberry fresh puree aroma with farm wood planks.  Deep dark garnet with fine layer of bubbles.  Lives up to tart title with sweet sour big pucker like candy and very fruity.  much more pucker than lambic, very sour, but drinkable, enjoyable.

Courtesy of SS. Murky reddish purple and a small, frothy, grayish white head. Huge, pungent raspberries and raspberry juice in the nose. Same huge raspberries in the flavor, sweet and sour, finish starts to dry and is sweet, bitter, sour. Huge, syrupy body is balanced by tingly carbonation. Excellent brew, insanely thick.

750 ml bottle thanks to my Secret Santa.  Wonderful Raspberry aromas.  Fresh and fruity.  The flavor was sweeter than the Tart I was expecting, but that satisfied my sweet tooth just fine.  Very tasty and thanks again Santa.

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2007 Thanks to buckybeer for this. Poured brown to ruby red and cloudy with a small pink head. Aroma of tart raspberries. The flavor is raspberry tartness and a hint of malty sweetness. Sour, tangy finish. An exceptional fruit beer.

25.4 oz bottle.  Enjoyed with the Belgian Red and Thanksgiving appetizers. Hazy purple with a wispy pink head.  Raspberry mousse nose; somewhat subdued.  Sweet-sour raspberry, of course.  Medium carb but not fizzy.  Doesnt have the body and complexity of the Red but still very tasty.  I get less the sense this is a beer.

750 mL bottle. I ried this one side by side with a bottle of Lidemans Framboise. Its a cloudy reddish-brown color with a bubbly pinkish head that laced the glass. Unlike the Lidemans, it smelled and tasted like a bowl of fresh raspberries rather than raspberry candy. It was sweet and tart on the tongue, but not as sweet as the Lidemans. The tartness complimented the sweetness well. Really makes your mouth water. Final score: New Glarus 1, Lindemans nil.

750ml bottle.  Aroma:  Intense raspberry that  walks the line between sweet and sour.  Some earthiness, wood,  and spice poke out from the background.  Appearance:  Purpleish red and very murky.  Pink head was small and fizzy.  No lacing.  Flavor:  Strong sweet and sour raspberry flavor up front and throughout, Some wheat malt, oakiness,  and yeastiness in the middle, and a bit of hop spiciness into the finish.  Finish is fairly sour but never unpleasant.  Palate:  Medium bodied.  Moderate carbonation.  Overall:  I love raspberries and this one didnt skimp.  Packed with raspberry flavor.  Great beer, but carbonation seemed a bit light and didnt have the complexity of the Belgian Red.

Pour is deep red, similar to its belgian red cousin. very sweet and potent raspberry aroma and flavor, also notes of wet cardboard, oak, sour gummi worms, and some raspberry syrup.  A nice tart kick on the palate makes this one much more enjoyable for me than the Red. I didnt like my first glass that much, but I am really loving my second one. I feel like I have been sucking on sour raspberries.  Thanks Benn.

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2007 Sampled from tap at the New Glarus Brewery on 10/11/2006.  Rating:  8  4  9  4  18.

Note:  I picked up a couple extra bottles of this from while I was at the brewery that I hope to sample soon.  I will update my notes with more details at that time...

UPDATE (12/31/2006 and 1/01/2007):  HAPPY NEW YEAR!  What better way to celebrate the New Year than with my wife and a bottle of New Glarus Raspberry Tart?!  Well, the ball has dropped in NYC, so now its offically 2007 here! -- 

New Glarus Raspberry Tart pours a hazy reddish plum color with a brownish tinge to the hue.  The frothy crown is pink in color a leaves an interesting speckled lacing pattern.  This beer has a wonderful fresh raspberry aroma.  The flavor is huge and is dominated by fresh raspberries.  It has a great sweet/tart taste as well (neither dominate too much) with a bit of sourness just before the juicy finish.  This beer is rich and smooth on the palate.  Overall this is another wonderful marriage of fruit and beer by New Glarus (their Belgian Red is also an amazing fruit beer).  This beer was worth the drive to Wisconsin to get a couple of bottles!   My orginal rating stands, but I think that the New Glarus Belgian Red might be just a bit better...

25 oz bottle directly from the New Glarus Brewery.

Another great friut beer from New Glarus. I had this one at the brewery. Great color with a huge rasberry aroma and taste. Sweet and sour balence was great. It was very wine like in appearence. I would love more.

thanks to my brother Chris I finally got to try this.  Great, intense raspberry aroma.  Once in the glass the raspberry aroma comes out ever more.  Intense raspberry flavor but with the sweetness of all the fuit balanced by the sourness.  Great beer   a must try for all and I must find more

Several different vintages sampled over the past several years have left me with a good impression of the quality standards that New Glarus preserves.  I love how cloudy this brew looks.  Gives the feel of a nice hand-made artisan beer.  Floral aroma that invites the fruit aromas to dance with your nose.  Wonderful texture in the mouth as the oak and raspberries continue to waltz around the palate.  Very similar to the belgian red, but a bit more tart.  Very good.
Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus. Pours red with a pink head. Aroma of rasberry and yeast. The flavor is sweet, fruit, with a tart finish. Great beer.

Bottle (courtesy of Brigadier).  As soon as I popped the cap off, my nose was greeted with a relatively intense shot of raspberry.  Once it hit the glass, the raspberry aroma was even more intense and wonderfully enjoyable.  No surprise, the flavor was almost all about the raspberry.  Very, very sweet, but for me, not in a bad way.  There is a bit of sourness that quite nicely balances out some of the sweetness.  Very drinkable.  I need to get some more!
UPDATED: APR 5, 2008 Pours reddish purple with a small pinkish tinted head. Smells like raspberry. Very sweet, maybe a little too sweet. Nice tartness

Beautiful to behold!   The aroma is simply fantastic...all raspberry and tarness.   The flavor is probably too sweet for me, but the quality of ingredients and care in brewing are both perfectly obvious.   Very nice holiday brew!

UPDATED: JUN 19, 2007 Bottle.  Burnt red color.  Sweet cherry and raspberry aroma emphasize the SWEET and RASPBERRY.  Extremely sweet, raspberry flavor that reminds me of raspberry tarts.  I found this beer to be a sweet, syrupy mess.  I REALLY wanted to enjoy it too.

Pours purplish brown with a purple / tan head.  Very hazy cloudy body.  The aroma is fantastic - creamy raspberries that are rich and lush.  It smells like dessert in a glass.  There is definitely tartness, but a creamy sweetness as well.  Medium / full body that is thick and creamy with only a little carbonation at the end, but that is all it needs.  The taste has lots of raspberry goodness that starts of creamy, smooth and rich with some tartness and slightly bitter.  The finish gets a little spicy.  It gets more crisp and taste almost like a raspberry pie.  I was expecting the little seeds from the raspberries to get stuck in my teeth.  A fantastic fruit beer.
This was like drinking a raspberry cobbler.  Just delicious.  Could be a dessert it is so sweet.  Plenty of raspberry in the aroma and the flavor.  Delicious!

Bottle.  Pours a nice red color with a pink head. Aroma of raspberries and wood.Taste of fresh raspberries with a slight carbonation. Has bit of initial tart flavor but balances out nicely with subtile sweetness.Very well balanced with a crisp finish.

UPDATED: JUN 18, 2008 <<<RE-RATE 6/17/08>>>
25.4 oz bottle purchased in March of 2008 at Chicones in Hudson, Wisconsin.  Looking forward to the re-rate on this one.  Pour is hazy pinkish red with a 1 inch pink head. Nice lacing. Very pretty in the glass. Aroma is amazingly like fresh raspberries.  Really good, high quality, raspberries.  Sweet, tart, everything a raspberry should be.  Taste is even more amazingly raspberry.  This is the most similar to the actual fruit beverage I have ever consumed.  Remarkable.  As it warms a bit in the glass, you can get the faintest hint of the yeast, really the only indication this is not just raspberry juice.  Palate is full and mouth coating.  This was good, and outstandingly well made.  I really wish I would have had some vanilla ice cream or choclate cake with this.  I will use this new rating.  8,5,7,4,15 (3.9).

<<<ORIGINAL RATING 10/06/05>>>I poured this at GABF 06 and it appeared to be the 2nd most popular sample at the show (Behind NG Belgian Red).  A bit over the top tart, even for a Raspberry beer. 7,5,7,3,15 (3.7).

GABF 2006.  Red-amber color, very clear, tan-white head.  Huge raspberry aroma with sourness.  The raspberry flavor dominates....strong sweetness balanced with strong sourness.  One of my favorite beers.  Fantastic.
GABF 06. Poured a nice dark red with a medium off white head.  Aroma: is tart rasberries, some malt character, taste is tart fermented rasberries, perfectly balanced, awesome fruit beer!

I received this bottle as part of the BeerSwap 2.0.  I served it in my Lindemans Flute.  I dark red to purple with a very fizzy pink head.  Enormous raspberry nose.  Sweetart.  A rush of raspberry sweetness with a tongue clinching tart finish.  Reminiscent of Jolly Ranchers.  Medium body.  Bubbly.  Can a man get a piece of friggin cheesecake.

750ml bottle thanks to 1FastSTi and HogTownHarry. Mostly red in color with a bit of brown and a very firm pink head. Full raspberry aroma, nice and tart. Flavor is also of tart raspberries, relatively sweet, with a medium body and an acidic prescence. Not rediculously complex but very well made and certainly tasty. thanks guys

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2006 Ok in small doses as a sub for red burgandy if you like that sort of thing. I admire the tartness and this is not too sweet which is nice. Just not my thing. Try El Toro Peach Ale if you want a great fruit ale.

From a dark red wax dripped capped 750 ml. green bottle with a blurb and serving instructions on the right side of label, sampled cold, straight out of the refrigerator, in a flute glass.

Poured a deep reddish brown, dark red hues, with a fizzy, small bubbly head that settled into a thin lacing.

Aromas of fresh cleaned, wet raspberries in bowl, Fruity sweet with a light tartness.

Good, fizzy carbonation and a berry crisp, tart with some dryness, smooth light-medium bodied mouthfeel.

Delicious raspberries taste, dry and juicy with a perfect balance between the sweetness and the tartness, one does not overwhelm the other, a very grain maltness meshed with a light alcohol warmth, and a dry raspberry finish.

One of New Glarus better brews, great fruit beer drinkability, good with seafood or a grilled steak, a nice dessert beer, or just sitting down and reading a book or magazine in the evening.

Traded them and traded them but just finallt had one last weekend. This is a very special brew as I could not believe the amazing aroma from this. Fresh raspberries that have been squashed up in a bowl a slammed in your face like you were the brunt of some Three Stooges scene. Shit, the flavor was so purely beery without any of the syrupy jam or jelly sweetness.A wonderful sour ber that should be enjoyed by every Ratebeerian.

25 oz bottle, via 1FastSTi.  Pours a slightly cloudy dark garnet colored body under a fizzy pink tinged head that faded to a thin ring.  Aroma is full of sweet and tart syrupy raspberries.  A little woodiness and yeast as well, but they barely make it past the raspberry.  Flavor is quite tart and slightly acidic yet finishes quite sweet and syrupy.  The raspberry tastes a little artifically over-the-top.  Mouthfeel is full bodied and syrupy in texture with light fizzy carbonation that helped cut through the syrupyness a little.  Overall, this is pretty decent, but not up to par with its big brother Belgian Red.  Maybe Im being unfair to this beer, because I know in my mind Im comparing it against Belgian Red, no matter how objective Im trying to be.  Oh well, it just comes across to me as too much syrupy fruit and lacking in complexity.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2008 Rerate, courtesy of mj (and others).  Thanks, Mike!  So much more character in the other bottles Ive gotten recently: dense, pitty, mouthwatering fruit; great levels of tartness and acidity; just so generous and tasty.  I think I appreciate this beer a lot more than I first did, or these batches are better.  Id guess the former.  9.4.9.5.18=4.5.  

Many thanks to Monger for the trade!  Cloudy maroon appearance with a small light-pink head; large-bubble formation.  Huge amount of fresh raspberries in the nose, slightest suggestion of tartness.  Upfront tartness in the palate, full mouthfeel, layers and layers of raspberry goodness; oak toastiness appears almost imperceptibly at the finish - raspberries dominate otherwise.  Heads and shoulders above every other framboise Ive tried.  Tartness keeps things balanced, no overhead sugar.  Well done.  7.4.8.4.16=3.9

750mL bottle courtesy of Degarth.  Pours a dark and murky ruby color with a one finger-thick pink head.  Lots of rich raspberries in the fruit juice-like aroma along with some vanilla and hints of oak.  Decent body with plenty of carbonation.  Starts off very sweet/tart with tons of juicy raspberries.  Some creamy vanilla in the middle.  Finishes a bit dry with plenty of sour raspberry and green apple tartness.  A great beer for sure, just not quite up to par with the fantastically drinkable Belgian Red.

Big berry aroma, you can practically taste it before the first sip. Huge sweet/tart raspberry flavor. Not too sweet, the tartness balances it perfectly. So smooth and refreshing, a great treat on a summer night, I really enjoyed this.

Bottle sampled with Beerded_one, thankyou Robert from State Line Liquors for this beauty. Pours deep red with a small pink head. Aroma of fermented raspberries, yeast, and sweetness. the flavor is sweet up-front with loads of fermented raspberries coming through , as well as yeast, finishing with a tart sour finish. Good body, excellent brew.

Bottle.  Thanks JCapriotti for hooking me up with this,wife says thanks also.  Aroma was just all raspberry and a light oak.  Poured a swirling thick raspberry  color with a fizzy head.  Flavor was tasty, raspberry lots of it.  Palate really matched this, tart and sweet.  I only had 1 bottle so I shared it with my wife and mother-in-law.  It was a good dinner drink.
Sweet and delicious.  A slightly bitter finish helps to balance the sweetness which would be too strong otherwise.  Fizzy, tart, slight malty or woody flavor.  Very good.

Amazing. Pours a deep red color with a plentiful pink head. Aroma reminds me of a pound or two of crushed raspberries in a bucket. Delicious heavy raspberry flavor with a nice tart (almost sour) finish. Its not enough to simply describe the flavor of this one. You have to taste it. Its almost like a concentration of intensely tart raspberries. It makes your mouth pucker. Fantastic stuff. I love it.
I really dont like fruit beers.  However, this offering by New Glarus was outstanding.  Its sweet, but not too sweet.  Its not as thick tasting as some of its peers.  It is excellent.

Maybe a little bit of this beer is good...I liked the first couple sips.  But there is just defintely too much of a good thing going on here.  As expected there were huge raspeberry aromas...and I even got some grapes coming through, kinda weird... I know.  The color was a great red purple that reminded me of grape juice I drank when I was a kid.  The mouthfeel and flavors are just way too sweet and syrupy for me to really enjoy this one.  Still a very interesting endeavour, but it is a far cry from how good the Belgian Red is.  Maybe i like cherries more...
Thanks Blake
The Belgian Red is a little better but this is still real good. Pours a cloudy red with a small head. It is tart, just like it says on the label. Good as a desert beer.
Deep, dark purple/red with a big dark pink head. Nose of fresh raspberry preserves. Mildly tart, pleasantly sweet raspberry. Amazingly drinkable, its like candy. WOW!

From 750 thanks to Monger!  Pours what looks like grape juice with a purple head.  Nose is a raspberry, prune juice mix.  Flavor is chocolate, raspberry delight.  Palate is silky and tart, just enough to round our that sweetness.  Wonderful dessert beer.

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2007 750ml bottle with a dark red wax over the cap pours dark ruby red with a very thin pink head and lots of lacing.  The bouqet is very strong of raspberries, cherries, and candied sugars.  The tartness of the raspberries hit the front of your tounge and the sourness moves back as it coats your mouth with an acidic berry flavor (especially as it warms).  Thin body and medium carbonation.   Sometimes the acidity seems a little too much, but a really great beer.

Pours a very deep red with a moderate reddish head.   Nose is predominately raspberries - like fresh picked raspberries.   Flavor is is sour, with raspberries and some vinegar.  Cant say it enough, this beer is raspberries incarnate.

Well I have finally decided to review Raspberry Tart.  This is a beer for raspberry lovers.  The aroma is amazing and the taste is almost the same.  It is quite carbonated and has little to no taste of alcohol.  This beer is perfect for a hot summer day!  And remember they call it tart for a reason!

pours a very dark red with a large pink head. aroma is strong raspberries and candi sugar as has been mentioned. flavor is raspberries, of course, sweet candi sugar. has a thick syrupy mouthfeel. not bad but a little strong on the raspberries but i expected that.

Bottle thanks to 1fasti: Red pour, with a pink head. Aroma, raspberries, candy sugar, and a little tartness. Flavor, plenty more raspberries, some nice tartness, and sweet on the tail end. Mouthfeel was quite nice, a little chewy quality to it.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2007 Bottle from John (JPDIPSO) Thanks!  Pours out a completely cloudy dark red color.  Looks like a very thick framboise.  Smell is full of raspberries and sweet candies.  Taste, surprisingly, is raspberries as well.  This is like driking a liquid raspberry puree.  Very nice, refreshing, pretty awesome actually.  I would love to drink this all the time, but to do so I would have to move.  That cant happen. But this blows KRE out of the water.  This is what a raspberry beer (not a framboise) should taste like.  Very good, Thanks John!  I liked this more than the belgian red, hands down.
Pours a dark ruby red with a small pinkish head. Very strong raspberry scent and flavors. Even better than the red in my opinion. Very tart and carbonated. Sit next to the pool and enjoy. AWESOME

The Raspberry Tart is definitely full of raspberry, and is definitely tart, so Ill call it a win for New Glarus. The pour is thick, and it looks like a Raspberry smoothie, with a pink colored head. The aroma is raspberry, of course. The flavor is tons of raspberry, and nothing else. The mouthfeel is what I really didnt care for in this one. It is too thick and heavy. It has the mouthfeel of a milkshake. A little too thick for me, and a little too heavy in the raspberry department. I think the Belgian Red is a much better balanced example.

Big bottle, I had this as a desert beer with some pals, after a world cup match. Its pretty good, the pour is dark red and vinous with a pink and disapearing foam, the nose is all sour rasberries and the first couple of sips are all raspberries (skin, juice and seeds) a tad of lime and no beer to be found but a lite carbonation. After a while it gets kind of sticky and sweet. Everybody left a bit in there glass. It might be better to have with some cheese or vanilla ice cream. Alone it gets to simple and sweet.

This one hasnt gotten the same accolades as the red, and it shouldnt. The raspberry was way too strong, although the fruitiness was accompanied by a tartness and mild funkiness (even rubbery / slightly barn-like - a feature I like about the fruit lambics, that theyre not all soda-like). Still, too much raspberry and somewhat thick and sticky. Poured a deep burgundy color with a thin pink colored head and some lacing. Mouthfeel was moderately bodied to thick and somewhat sticky. Overall rating for two tastings was mediocre, apart from the appearance.

750 ml bottle, thanks to Wallybrau for getting this for me!  This poured an opaque ruby red with a minimal head.  Aroma was very fruity, like fresh raspberries.  Flavor was bubbly and fruity with a fresh tartness.  Medium bodied with a dry finish, some notes of oak as well .   My wife punked out on my half way through the bottle so the tartness became a bit much.  Great beer nonetheless, New Glarus rocks!

Nice looking deep ruby/purple color with minor lacing. Intense fresh fruity tart raspberries dominate the palate. Earthy oak dryness balances out the sweetness making this a very palatable beer. This is like drinking fresh raspberries. Perectly done for a fruit beer - not too cloying but enough of the fruit is left intact to make it memorable. If you havent tried this yet, get some and share it.

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2007 Thanks to badgerben. Pours dark red almost black looking with a red hue, big fluffy pink head. Aroma is awesome sweet smelling raspberries. Taste is raspberry tartness obviously, great malty mouthfeel and aftertaste with the raspberry tartness staying through everything but with the oak lessening the blow, just like belgian red with a pie crust taste. Sour and Tart raspberry flavor the whole time. Fuckin amazing.

Many thanks go to RooftopRogue for this one! Pours a hazy deep crimson with a light pinkish brown head that diminishes quickly. The aroma is certainly full of raspberries, along with some wheat,yeast, and the faint odor of...olives?  The flavor is much of the same, a huge blast of raspberry throughout...with wheat and clove in the middle and olive and vinegar torwards the back. Fairly well carbonated and super juicy throughout...sweet and moldy in front finishing tart...almost sour. I really do enjoy the creativity and craftsmanship of some of these beers...but sometimes I feel like Im getting hit over the head with the fruit element of it all. Overall though...a delecious offering full of flavor and vigor. Excellant with dark chocolate!

Sampled at the JimMack 06 Invitational.  750ml bottle, thanks to 1FastSti !  cloudy rusty red color, looks like unfiltered/unpasteurized cherry juice.  aroma is dry - like room temp raspberries a few weeks off the vine.  flavor is pure raspberries, a little tea, a little nutmeg.  slightly tart.  pleasant variation from the NG belgian red.  Thanks 1FastSti!

Bottle. Thanks Mullman. Deep red in color with a nice thick pink head. Rasberry very sweet aroma. Wow. Great. Tart and sweet flavor. Lots of rasberries. Smooth mouthfeel. Rasberries, ummmmmmmmmmm.  Finish is sweet and smooth. Really nice beer. Very drinkable. Excellent.

Big thanks to Mullman who brought this to Jimmacks place.  This is always a special treat to taste this stuff.  It really doesnt remind me of beer, more like liquid raspberry candy.  Pours a very thcik purple/dark pink with almost no head.  It almost looks like there might be some raspberry seeds floading around in there.  Aroma is absolutely loaded with fresh raspberries very sweet pungent and lightly tart.  Flavor is very very sweet upfront but very inviting for you to keep drinking more and more.  The sweetness slowly turns to tartness in the end.  Fresh fruit all the way through with a very smooth mouthfeel and finish, and leaves a great aftertaste which coats the mouth which makes you want even more.  This is the kind of fruit beer which I could easily drink a whole 750ml and not think twice about.
Nice redish purple color.  Very sweet and rasberry smell.  Taste is the same.  Nice tart taste at the end.  Great breakfest or desert beer.

mmm. deep, deep burgundy, though completely opaque.. i got a kick out of how the bottle says something about it sparkling like rubies yet was too dense for any sort of glowing to occur. overwhelming raspberry puree aroma. flavor of raspberries (including the bitter seed taste) immediately, with subtle woody flavor, tart finish. a little sweeter and fruit puree-y than i was expecting from a beer, but im in love anyway.

Big thanks to JCap for this crazy brew. Amazing, thick red pour, with a touch of vibrant pink head. Aroma is a powerful raspberry punch, full and overwhelming. It smells more pure than even real raspberries do. The flavor is another raspberry blast up front, though contains a great tartness underneath. Tastes a lot like the seeds to. There is a bit of a lactose taste, some orange and burnt apple. Thick and overwhelming and awesome. Glad a finally got to try this.

Bottle, from trade with CaptainCougar. Raspberry aroma. Cloudy/milky purply red color, small head no lacing. Tart sweet flavor Raspberry lime. Medium body, lite creamy mouthfeel, Tart finish. Great brew.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Bottle shared with HogTownHarry & Dave B. -- courtesy of HogTownHarry. Never in my life has a beer looked like this! Pours a dark, deep murky red with no head -- looks like a raspberry smoothie. The great raspberry aroma is at times tart and at times sweet, It has just the right amount of sugary sweetness, spices and oak. Big full flavour is absolutely amazing -- sweet and sour raspberries, spices, oak and hops. Full bodied. There arent many beers that come in magnums that I could easily drink all of myself but this is definitely one of them. EXCELLENT! Thanks Harry!

This bottled brew poured a small sized head of foamy purple hued mostly diminishing bubbles that left behind a poor lacing.  The aroma was of mild raspberries.  The mouth feel was tingly at the start and smooth in the finish with a very nice raspberry flavor.

UPDATED: SEP 6, 2006 Bottle (750ml).  Shared with blankboy and Dave B, my bottle via trade with UghSmash.  Oh, gawd this looks AWESOME - poured thick slightly pinkish-red, small head, wow - you could add pectin and boil this into jam.  Aroma - raspberry, very tart, a little briney even, massive fruit flavour, hint of light cider.  Taste is alternating sweet and puckeringly sour fresh raspberry, a hint of alcohol and some saltiness again - terrific.  Thick body, fruit-acidity and lively mouthfeel ... dang this is good - I could drink a whole one myself (my wife loved it too)  - big props to UghSmash for this - can I trade for a few more??????

Bottle.  Pours a dark cloudy red.  Aroma that I can only describe as  raspberry jelly on toast.  Taste follows with a puckering tart kick.  The "beer" qualities never seem to come through but it does not matter, this is quality stuff.  Next time Ill have mine with eggs over easy and a side of bacon.

Huge appreciation to Philip for being kind enough for getting me a bottle of this. Thanks Phil! Served as recommended, in a flute, fridge temp, with chocolate covered strawberries. Murky crimson liquid flows from the bottle, and lets of steam in the form of a thin ring of pinkish head.Slight lace. Massive fresh pureed raspberries aroma, with subtle cherries, spicy nuances, woody notes, and a slight funk. Very sweet raspberry flavours mash well with tart cherry, cinnamon, oak, and gamay noir grapes. FInish is pleasantly sweet and astringent, with a lenghty tingle in the throat. Very good, and one of tyhe best fruit beers to pass my lips. Thanks so much Phil!

As far as Im concerned, this isnt beer, its wine. Notwithstanding, I absolutely love it. Its super flavorful, tart scent and aftertaste,  with a nice sweetness in the middle. Pretty much anyone will like it.

The bottle has a tart labic like aroma right as the top is popped. Once I bury my nose in the glass, I am overcome by lots of sweet raspberries, no hops or malt character come through. This is pretty murky, completly opaque, and a somewhat plum red colour. Little to no head. Lively carbonation with a bit of a sweet start that explodes into raspberry flavour with an elegant tart finsih. This is certianly not your average beer, a fantastic fruit beer.
This is a great raspberry beer that pours nice, has a great raspberry nose and fantastic raspberry taste.  GREAT!!!

Sample at Indy tasting Dicks BBQ 3/31/06 - Aroma of raspberries and malt.  Pours a deep creamy red with no head or lacing.  Flavor is mosty pure raspberries with a nicely balanced malt back.  Palate is tart.  So so tasty.

Pour is a very light cloudy reddish with a small head and a fair share of bubbles.  Aroma is huge on raspberries of course, what else, with a hint of that vinegar sourness.  Flavor too is sour, but not overly so, and again the raspberries are kapow in your face.  Quite a tasty treat.
75 cl bottle. Reddish cloudy colour with a small head. Aroma of raspberry, and other berries. Very strong flavour of raspberry, that ends in a strange sweet way. Not a beer for me.

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2007 Pours a muddy, maroon with a fizzy, quickly fading pink head. Nice lacing. The aroma is of very fresh raspberries. Flavor is quite berry centric, but with a touch of wild yeasts, cobwebs, earthy. Some light caramels also, very sweet and fresh. The finish is very tart with a touch of pithy bitterness. Champagne mouthfeel.

Holy shit...this beer is awesome.  I enjoyed sharing the bottle with 3 other people...but now that it is gone I wish I would have kept it under wraps.  Pours a thick creamy velvety...raspberry color with no head.  Aroma is fresh tart raspberries...and yeah like sersdf said (though I brought it up in my conversation with the fellow drinkers) a haagen daaz raspberry cream sicle.  Flavor is exactly the same...except there is an amazing dry fast finishing bitterness that makes each new sip a delight.  Mouthfeel is incredible.  This is like the best fucking desert I could possibly order.

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2007 this is a beer?  if you say so.  zero head, but still quite beautiful.  smells exactly like haagen daaz raspberry sorbet tastes.  very sour, tartness sticks to the tounge well into the finish.  i love the flavor, but im having a hard time figuring out what makes it a beer.  i guess the term refers to the process by which its made, so this is a "beer."  seems more like a girly drink (some sort of sorbet/milk/alcohol smoothie).  a wonderful novelty, however, ill give it that.... after having it a number of times, im going to give it a high-but-not-too-high rating since its awesome for introducing others to what beer can be.  but it isnt the best beer ever by any means.

(on bottle thanx René) Poured a very murky red glass.Just opening it, filled the room with the raspberryaroma; heavy sh*t. The tartness is present, but trumphed by the severe sweetness and cloying feeling of pure fruit pulp. Stinky and nasty sweet, not a winner. Maybe in it´s own league, but still not a winner.

(Bottle 75 cl) Pours copletely opaque dark red - actually it looks like freshly squeezed berry juice - with a tiny, reddish head. Tart and very fresh raspberry aroma. Rather light body with a high acidity and very fresh berry accents. No bitterness and no feel of alcohol either. As said - you could mistake this for being freshly squeezed raspberry juice. 170306
Deep reddish colour with a small pink head. Aroma and flavor are both a blend of the fruity tartness and hints of some sweetness. Flavor seems more balanced.

Bottle.
Hazy red coloured with a pink head.
Light acidic aroma of raspberries.
Light acidic flavour of raspberries.
One dimensional.
Bottle. Dark red colour with a small pink head. Light sour Raspberry, aroma and a sweet light sour Raspberry taste. Medium body with a sweet light sour finish.

Pours like blended raspberries with a thick pink head.  Aroma of blended raspberries; with a flavor of blended raspberries.  One is good, but two and the sourness starts to become too overpowering for me.

UPDATED: APR 25, 2011 2010-06-06, RBESG 2010, Grand Tasting, bottle, 7-4-8-3-15=37Red-amber color; small creamy head. Tart and creamy aroma, some fruits. Sweet fruity (cherry and strawberry) flavor, low sourness level. Balanced final. Very pleasant.2006-03-15, 7-4-8-4-15=38Muddy dark scarlet color; thick pink head. Strong fruity pungent aroma. Good body strength, fruity, sweet, with an incredibly aggressive late sourness, astringent. Strange, good.

25 oz bottle.  Is this really a beer?  Opaque cloudy red body with a small pink head.  Aroma is all fresh raspberries.  Its delicious, tart and sweet with huge raspberry taste and a biscuity finish, but it tastes more like champagne with raspberry puree than like a beer.

Bottle.  Thanks to Kit.  Muddy red color...smells like raspberry syrup...slight pink froth on top...Quite tart, yet very sweet...Intense.  Nice acidity to get some balance...pour this on cheescake.  Im only interested in a few ounces of this, and then it is just too much sweet raspberry syrup for me...Id rather just eat a glassful of fresh raspberries...hey, anybody got a belgian waffle I can pour this on?  Im not into a beer like this at all...too much overrun with fruit it tastes like desert...just give me desert, then I can have a beer later!

This beer offers a wonderfully brilliant raspberry aroma that has hints of wheat lingering in the background.  The glass is filled with a plum colored solution that has a mild purplish colored head.  This mildly heavy beer is very crisp and perks all the taste buds upon entering the mouth.  The tart taste is a burst of raspberry flavor that entices the mouth greatly as it slowly fades away.

"MMMMMM good. At first i said is this really a beer. Poured a great red color with a pink head that was huge and laced very very well. Aroma was strong from the pour of rasberries. Mouthfeel was had a little acidict. Good beer."

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2006 Courtesy of The_Enemy

This poured like something from my smoothie maker. Gloppy fruit juice thick with a rich red/raspberry color and even had a diminishing, thumb thick, tan head. Fore is a blast of sweet raspberry and as that fades a kind of grainy oatmeal/wheat maltiness appears that tastes a bit of oatmeal cakes and malt powder. The overall effect is like a fruitfilled cake with malt powder sprinkled on it. This is so fantastic tasting that it is a little hard to believe. While the raspberry flavors are amazing what turly endears me toward the beer is the far aftertaste which is so malty and oat/wheat cake wholesome that it make me feels like a little kid trying a sweet treat for the first time. Truly an amazing creation.

750ml bottle.  Aroma features undeniably huge amounts of raspberry character, tart, fresh and juicy with background notes of whole grain toast and faint spices.  Also looks like a glass of raspberry juice, thoroughly opaque purplish-red in color with a very minimal head.  Flavor is also fully raspberry-oriented, starting sweet and sugary and turning quite a bit more tart by the finish, which is long, lingering and still packing an incredible amount of fresh raspberry flavor and much lighter suggestions of wood, wheat citrus and buttery pastry.  Mouthfeel is lightly acidic and quite lively with a light body to match.  Certainly is about the most overt raspberry character one is likely to find in a beer.  Nevertheless, it works quite well due to the interplay of tart and sweet, along with the gently balancing malts.  Thanks to Eric for the bottle.

I constantly find myself counting my blessings for living in the great state of Wisconsin and being able to readily obtain all of the New Glarus brews without any problem. This particular "beer" (if you should call it that, i consider it more juice than anything) is incredibly tasty, and the flavor hits you like a ton of bricks. While not particularly satisfying, it was a very nice conversational bottle to discuss with friends. incredibly sweet with a peculiar rosy brown color, it is definitely worth trying for no other reason than to experience the intrigue.

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2007 Simply divine!  This beer blows the Lindemans Framboise out of the water...then takes a samuri sword and filets it in mid-air, goes back in time and defeats the Nazis and ends the Apartheid, then comes back to the future and teams up with Roethlisberger to win Super Bowl XLI-XLV.  This tastes like fresh, super sweet, tart, and sour raspberry juice.  It smells so beautiful.  I predict you will either love it or hate it.  To the amateur it will probably be a huge surprise.  To think that there was some type of brewing process put into this just adds to my respect.  Amazing.  I cant wait for the Belgian Red.  RERATE.  still unbelievable.

New Glarus Raspberry Tart pours to a beautiful, deep ruby color with a pink head that fades, and a lively carbonation. When held to the light, this beer looks spectacular, it really shines bright like a ruby. The nose is pure bliss. Fragrant aromas of fresh raspberry and slight aromas of yeast flood the nose. The palate is firm, with great tart wheat malt character, and sweet and tart flavors of raspberry. This beer finishes with a wonderful tart raspberry edge. 

This is a phenomenal, hand crafted beer of great quality and character.  I have had its brother, New Glarus Belgian Red(kriek or cherry beer) on draught at a few good beer bars in Boston, and Chicago, but again, this isnt a beer you will easily find. Seek this beer out if you can find it. It makes for a wonderful desert beer and is the perfect foil to creme brulee, or cheese cake. This beer also makes a wonderful aperitif beer, and a fantastic marinade or vinegarette.

Pours an opaque bright reddish cherry with almost no head.  I thought the bottle was brown this stuff is so cloudy, almost like puree, though no settling in the bottom.  Aroma of tart berries (raspberries) and nothing but.  Tastes of very sour raspberries--almost like a soda, but I can pick up nothing until late in the finish a slight hop bitterness. Very light carbonation.   I cant really say anything but raspberries, raspberries, raspberries, this is a good ass beer.  Would work great as a dessert all on its own.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Ive gone on a 4 hour beer run for this beer.  Excelent as dessert with cheesecake (my wife dips the cheescake in the beer).  The only reason I didnt give it a perfect score is because Id like to see a little more body and aroma (like their red).  If you havent tried it, go get it!

Nice bordeau red beer with cherry head. Fresh raspberry jam aroma, like a fresh pie. Sweet fresh raspberries in mouth, lightly tart, rich and tingly. Wonderful body of tingly wine. Rich! More! Mondial 2005.

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2006 Not quite as good as the Belgian Red.  It poured with a dark lush red color and a thin amount of head.  My first thought was that it looked like someone poured tomato juice into a flute.  Raspberries dominated the aroma, although there is a hint of cherries somewhere in there too.  The taste is almost like a raspberry sorbet - it is strong at first and slowly melts in the mouth.  Its next to impossible to pick up on the alcohol content in this one.  A very unique creation from a very good brewery.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2006 (many thanks to 1faststi for hooking this up)so i dumped a bit into my flute glass and was surprised by the appearance.it almost looked like a thin fruit smoothy.i got a little head that left tiny lacing on the sides of the glass.the aroma was dominated by raspberries,then follwed by wheat,and oak.the flavor was a mix of raspberries,sour cherries,wheat,and medicine.the palate was nice and full and the finish had a little bite.very good and different for sure.

Deep ruby colored with a thin pink head.  Aroma of a lot of raspberries and not much else that I could pick out.  Taste was cloyingly sweet raspberry and maybe the barest hint of hops at the end.  I think Im with wheatbeerboy on this one.  New Glarus Belgian Red is great; tart, sweet, malty, hoppy, just a wonderfully complex blend all through.  This one is just raspberries and bubbles.  Oddly enough, after drinking about half the bottle and giving the rest the night in the fridge it actually had a bit more tartness to it but it still just wasnt enjoyable for me.

I honestly didnt care for this beer. It tastes like a combonation of tomato juice and grape soda. By way of comparison, I loved the New Glarus Cherry Fruit Beer and the Solstice Weisse beer but I can do without this one. Sorry folks.....

Rating No. 500 
another delicous and unique brew from New Glarus.  pours a very hazy, reddish amber with streaks of lace chasing its way down the sides of my snifter.  like the name implys, its all about tart raspberries.  well done but does not seem to have the layers of complexity of the Belgian Red.  at a paltry 4% abv, it proves that all great beer does not need to be high in alcohol content.  good stuff!

Shared a bottle of this with Duane and my brother on Christmas Eve. Poured an opaque maroonish color.  Kind of reminds me of looking at a V8 Splash. Aroma of sweet raspberries(duh) and maybe some earthy oak tones.  Just like the name says, this is definitely tart!  Its a bit one dimensional though, as I think the Belgian Red had some spiciness and complexity to it that the raspberry tart fails to achieve.

Big aroma of raspberry, malt, and oak.  Appears opaque, deep claret red, with orange tinges on the edges, and with no head at all; its just odd looking.  Flavor is big raspberry, sweet followed by sour, finishing dry and peppery.  Palate is thick and syrupy, and not as dry as I expected.  Overall, this is a very interesting beer and just a bit more than the sum of its parts.  My thanks to joeybgood for this tasty brew.

Whoa, what an aroma from this pour.  Beautiful explosion of raspberry and a delightful pour.  Light pink head, quite lively carbonation.
Great start.  Unfortunately was downhill from there.  Thick as maple syrup with carbonation, the raspberrys almost tasted artificial.  Cloying, harsh, and certainly not good for more than a sip or as a mixer.

This delightful beer arrived in a 750ml bottle, and the pour was a cloudy ruby color with pinkish-brown head.  The aroma is, I kid you not, the same smell as being amid the raspberry canes on a hot summers day and popping them into your mouth as you walk, with a little malt sweetness.  How did they put that into a bottle?  The flavor is a lovely fruity tartness, and a rich, thick mouthfeel.  Hints of sour, and a lingering malt finish.  Initially on the palate, I taste some Hallertauer spiciness and hay.  This beer is fabulous, however, only in small quantities - so rich!  It, with its cousin (New Glarus Belgian Red) are the King and queen of the fruit beer category.  Glad I had the chance to sample it with alaskanwarren, thanks Hezron!

Mirky ruby with an off-pink head. Aroma is fresh raw raspberries, and a hint of malt. Flavor is sweet tangy raspberries. Tart and spicy. Malt aftertaste. Like a bunch of raspberries squashed up and shoved in your mouth. I really really like this beer. Its so marvelously fresh. What a wonderful mix of the sweet and tart raspberries with the spiciness of the hallertau hops. Wow. Thanks Hezron!

(750 ml bottle: Obtained in trade with CaptainCougar, thanks Tom!) Aged for nearly one year in my cellar, this quintessential American-made raspberry beer is fabulous, a beer brimming with the intense flavor of tart, tangy, yet sweet raspberries.  In a way, it has some vinegar characteristics, which I think has intensified with the aging, but it tastes wonderful.  Medium-full in body, effervescent, and quite acidic on the palate, but because of the tartness, the palate remains refreshed for the entire session.  Naturally, the nose jubilantly exudes a strong raspberry aroma, somewhat sweet, but very tart, with balsamic vinegar being very strong.  Dark ruddy purple color, very cloudy, and only slightly translucent through the center of the body.  The tall pinkish white head settles to   If you like fresh raspberries and dessert in general, this beer gives both in one glass, but balances that with a superb tartness so that this isnt like drinking fruit juice.  And exceptional fruit beer.

Thanks to a forgotten rater for sending me this delicious treat many months ago! 

It was the perfect beer to accompany the lovely meal that the girl I am dating prepared. We sat down to chopped grilled chicken breast atop a fresh arugula salad with cranberries and pears. The dressing is what pulled the beer and food together; a fresh balsamic and raspberry vinaigrette.  
The beer poured a somewhat muddy crimson / brune body with edges of amber. The head was a dirty pink hue and didnt last long, although the lacing did. The aroma was marvelous! Some oak and tart balsamic vinegar suggestions sit amidst the sweet yet lightly bitter raspberry. There is a nice malt complexity, toffee, biscuit, and piecrust. It all pulls together so nicely! This is so amazingly real and far more delicious than those nontraditional Lindimans flavored Lambics. The palate was oily and placidly sticky, yet  the bottom of the bottle bet a bit chalky and silty... but it was still astoundingly luscious! 
A GREAT BEER!

UPDATED: OCT 12, 2005 Sitting at a round table of family and friends busted out this one. Big raspberry aroma with fermantation and wooden barrel as well. As the farmer at the table and the fermented aroma did smell like silage but thats not all bad if your from Wisconsin. Body looked like a bloody mary and had a decent head and lacing. The bloody looked turned off the girls at the table but a coulple dug in. Flavor was tart and acidic at first and I thougt this was a 99% beer? Well by finish the berry flavor was dominate and dry finish like these beers have. Lot of other opinions on this one from the others but Im not writing a book so Ill stop now.
Here we go again, looked great ruby red with light head, but tasted like syrup and not beer.  Rasberry tartbeer ?? Why?? adn then the finish--burning,maybe skunked???
user_location: Middle of no where, Ohio, USA

text: FInally trying this one, thanks to Grainbelt...I crack open the cap to get a nice burst of raspberry aroma. On the pour Id swear it smelled like a fresh baked pie. It was a medium cloudy red color with a small head. Poured in a flute, but these suck to drink out of. Great beer though, I see what the hype is truly about

750 ml bottle obtained in a trade with beeryum - Thanks Dave!!  - Pours deep maroon color with a fair purplish tan head that laces pretty well. Aroma of beautiful ripe raspberries..  I like raspberries so i could sniff this one all night.  Flavor is interesting...  Tart raspberries seem to reach out first and attack your tastebuds but it actually blends back to an almost doughlike bread quality that almost becomes sweet before that tart aftertaste comes in and makes you want another sip.  The palate is medium bodied.  Very smooth and the fruit is blended nicely with the malt.  Slightly leans towards the acidic side.. Im guessing because of the berries.  The tart flavor makes it tough to drink all 750ml but Im certainly not going to dump out something this tasty...

Appreciate this far more than the cherry. Sweet and tart with LOADS of fruit. So glad to find the tartness rather than simply the sweet. Much prefer more sour and acidic beers like La Folie, but think that were I to find one that was a blend of the two I might achieve nirvana.

750ml bottle.
Not a visually attractive beer. Lots of sediment makes this relatively light-colored beer completely opaque; looks like red Kool-Aid made with mud water. Lots of natural carbonation forms a dark pink, tightly packed, very persistent head. Aroma is predominatly sour tart berries and little else. The label isnt joking about the "tart" bit -- this stuff is unrepentently so. But not unpleasantly so; thankfully, theres enough sweetness to keep it from being overbearing.  So many fruit beers end up with a contrived "beer with fruit thrown in" character. New Glarus Raspberry suffers no such deficiency. The fruit aspect is extremely well-integrated like this was always meant to be a fruit beer from beginning to end. The relatively low 3.9 rating I gave is in part because of a low "appearance" rating and does not do justice to how truly well-crafted and enjoyable this beer is.

I finally broke down and opened this and drank it myself.  Well, it pours to what looks like some earthy red shade of molten womens lipstick.  Im not too keen on the appearance... Anyway, the aroma is the most aromatic fresh raspberry and wheat you can imagine.  I also managed to drink the entire 750 by myself, so its not cloying by any means.  The flavor is tart fresh red raspberries, light lemon zest, wheat bread.  Kinda smoothie in flavor.  Definitely not extract.  The palate is tart but not exceedingly so.  I can still taste it lingering, even after eating a McDonalds DBL cheeseburger more than 30 minutes after sampling the beer.  This is VERY well made.  Way to go NG!

One of the best smelling beers ever. Like overripe raspberries in syrup. Pours a magnificent  thick red colored jam of a brew.
But thats where the fun ends!
I am ABSOLUTELY certain that I got a bad bottle of this. Probably was sitting on the shelf too long. It tasted like a mouth full of aluminum foil, and burned my throat like hell. It tasted truely awful. I cant imagine its supposed to taste this horrible, and reiterate that Im sure it was an old bottle. But for $7 a bottle the brewer should take precautions that their product doesnt sit on store shelves too long. Until I get to try a fresh bottle (are you reading this New Glarus Brewing Company??) my rating stands: Looks and smells great! Tastes horrible!!!

Another round of thanks to beerhandy! What a treat. I prefrred this to the Belgian Red. Didnt seems as sweet and had a nice bit of tart to it. Couldnt drink very much of it but it was beautiful on looks and smelled wonderful.

WOW!  I love this beer.  it pours an incredibly deep and rich maroon color with a think and lasting pink tinged head.  The aroma is so wonderful... like a fresh raspberry pie (or insert your favorite raspberry desert here).  The flavor matches the aroma, except you get a nice hint of tartness in the flavor which only serves to add to the taste.  its a lot to drink and there is no way i could have finished a bottle myself, but grab a friend and open one up... well worth it!
Pours deep red with pink lingering head.  Strong raspberry aroma.  Strong raspberry flavored sweet-tart flavor.  Solid aroma and flavor.  Lasting raspberry finish.

Thanks to hopdog.  Pours a ruby red raspberry with a small head.  Aroma is all raspberry with some sourness.  Full on tart raspberry flavor.  This was a great raspberry based fruit beer, enjoyed this more than Lindemans.
Very dark purple color.  Dark cream head with creamy lacing. Huge sweet raspberry aroma. Massive raspberry flavor.  Sticky mouthfeel.  Amazingly delicious and decadent.

Bottle: Poured a deep red color fruit beer with a nice bubbly pink head with minimal retention. Aroma of fresh sweet raspberries is just incredible and I could spend days just sniffing in my glass. Taste consisted of sweet fresh raspberry (not the chemical syrupy raspberry that are commonly used in fruit beers), slight tartness and a light acidic finish. Its a shame that I cannot obtain this beer more regularly over here.

From a bottle, most recent vintage. NG does a nice job with this, although I always find I enjoy the cherry more than the raspberry, perhaps because Door County cherries are exceptional. This poors the expected dark, cloudy, and opaque amber red. On the nose, notes of tart raspberries with a bit of lemon zest. On the palate, more of the same, with a few other fruit notes like dried apricot coming across. A fine drink indeed.

UPDATED: APR 20, 2012 Sparkling ruby clear pour, with a light amount of rose colored head. Bright FRESH raspberries dominate the aroma. Intoxicating and enticingly fresh picked. Wow. Candy. Rich sugar sweet full of raspberries that taste like they just came from the bush. Flavor morphs with a touch of light sweet malt, a hint of dry hops, and then finishes with a fantastic warming flourish of Dom Perignon. Bubbly. You definately dont think youre drinking beer. Very three tiered flavor presentation. Complex. Palate is sweet, clear and clean. Crisp. Light touch of alcohol. Hands down the best fruit beer Ive ever put to my lips.

Thanks Secret Santa! whoever you are.  This is definately a great suprise.  This pours a opaque red, with a tint of brown.  Similar to tomato juice.  Smell is nothing like tomatos, this is pure goodness.  It fills the nostrils with a wild raspberry smell, like some elegent and freshly made candies.  I really dont know what to say about this taste other than the name of the beer.  It doesnt offer a real beer-like flavor at first, but there is a slight malt and wheat flavor that peaks out.  The palate is generous in how smooth it ends up being.  The palate is like fresh green apple peals right behind your teath with a heavy  berry taste everywhere else.  Great beer.

Big time thanks for sharing this one jerc.  Dark red pour, medium red dark red head.  Freshly baked raspberry pie aroma - all real raspberry here, no artificialness at all.  Tart raspberry taste over a medium mouthfeel.  This is easily the best fruit beer I have ever tried because of its blend of incredible real fruit flavour with the characteristics of a beer - it never forgets its beer roots.  You can taste some malt body to accompany the tart flavours; there is a nice lingering bitterness from the berries helped along by hops.  Sure it is one dimensional, but what a dimension!  Well done, a true treat.

Very dark ruby body with a nice tan-pink head that defies an accurate colour description. Massive leafy raspberry aroma with green viney quality. Flavour and aroma  are tart yet sweet in the depths. Flavour is richly raspberry with a pleasant moderate tartness throughout. My impression is that it lacks the complexity of the Belgian Red, but makes up for it in higher drinkability. Medium palate. Quite nice. Thanks again JPDIPSO. This brewery is rapidly gaining a permanent place in my heart.

Bottle shared with jerc and tupalev - courtesy of jerc. Deep, dark ruby colour with a small head the colour of pink cotton candy. HUGE aroma of fresh, tart raspberries. Flavour of the same, with some sweet malt lurking in the shadows doing its damnedest to balance the puckering tartness of the berries. A remarkable & truly unique beer, and a great choice to close our little Saturday afternoon tasting session.

Dark murky purple with only ring of bubbles for head. Huge sour and tart raspberry aroma and flavor. Flavor almost all sweet-tart like flavor, makes your mouth pucker. Medium palate but sweetness causes it to be heavy on the stomach.

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2005 Oooooooooooooooooooooh.  Cloudy purple-red, no head.  Pretty stuff.  Beatific raspberry nose, tart and sharp, can almost smell the seeds.  Flavor has some sweetness at first, then a huge kick of raspberries, tart and fruity.  Just great stuff, love how it starts with mild sweetness then comes in with the huge genuine tartness.

Dark purple with a pink head, so neat looking. Aroma is a pure blast of raspberries and sourness. The flavor is surprisingly very salty with a ton of raspberry and tart fruityness. Some sweetness, acidity and sourness in there as well. Medium body with very lively carbonation.

Bottle: Opaque muddy brown with ruby & purple highlights and a large pink head.  Aroma: This is like sticking your head in a bucket of fresh picked raspberries with just a slight bit of tart scent.  Taste is ripe raspberries, definitely not any artificial flavoring, raspberry seeds, very sweet, and just slightly tart and acidic.  Medium bodied, but light on the palate with lively champagne-like carbonation.  What a great beer to sip for desert.

Bottle from brad. Pours a deep red color with a fizzy white head. Nose is sweet cherries and cranberries. Taste is cranberries, very tart, stings the palate alot and is very fizzy. Also some raspberries and sourness.

My 14th fruit beer in under 2 weeks (and my last non-rated one in my cellar). Poured a deep ruby red and pinkish color with an averaged sized pinkish head. Very nice aroma of fat and juicy raspberries. Tastes of raspberries. Semi sweet and semi tart. Good thing I love raspberries - by far one of my favorit fruit beers.
Pours red with a very small head that does not last long.  Smell is of rasberries.  Tste is of over the top rasberries.  Very tart finish.

What a beautiful beer.  Deep ruby/purple with a light pink head.  Aroma of...raspberry preserves, go figure.  Taste is thick and rich.  Tart raspberries, raspberry preserves, sugar cookie, pie crust and even some tiniest tinges of vanilla, spice, and nut.  Carbonation is simply perfect, and the palate overall great; creamy, thick, and a little froth.  Watch out, sweetness and richness with get to you after awhile.

Pours a deep ruby red. Very pretty pour, but the layer of pink-tinged tan head is kind of skimpy. I wouldnt complain, but it seems like this is generally expected to be a highly carbonated style. (Also, every thing else was so good, I felt like I had to complain about something.) The aroma is stunningly fragrant. Raspberries, vanilla, fruity sourness, spice, muskiness, and a bit of lightly toasted wheat. Mmmm. So delicious. An overwhelming slap of flavor, like stepping out of a building into a hurricane. Which comes first here, the incredibly tart, mouth puckering sourness, or the rush of sweet raspberry jam? I sure cant tell, but my mouth is digging the chaos. This is wonderful beer. Bravo to the cheeky brewers of New Glarus! They have gone after a challenging, almost Baroque style here, and the results are remarkable. One small caveat. I think serving it cool, and not  "very cold" as the label suggests, will shows off the sourness of this beer to its best advantage. Thanks Hezron for the bottle!

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2006 Wow!  and by wow I mean WOW!  We cracked this one at a tasting at Mikes (tiadiaguy) last weekend and this was the most memorable beer of the weekend.  It poured with the consistincy of a fruit smoothie.   The aroma and flavor was like a tangy, rasberry sorbet.  Im definately seeking out more of this.

Discount Liquors, Milwaukee, WI. - 500 ml bottle. Thick, murky - orangeish auburn pour with a long lasting, persistent, creamy white head. Aroma has a tangy, fresh, sour raspberry  accent to it - smells like a freshly picked basket of berries. Flavor is tangy, sweet and sour at the same time -very fresh - but not quite up to snuff with the Belgian Red. Nothing artifical here. Very good,  not enough words to describe it. Mouthfeel, thick and creamy and coats your tongue and throat - makes an excellent desert beer.

this definately fell short of expectations as a 99 percentile beer.  raspberries were all over in this one.  ditto with avaulteriam on not serving too cold.  i actually tried to get my girlfriend to try this one since it was sweet and not typical beer which she hates, she said that it tasted like hot dogs and still was beer so she didnt like it.  while i didnt find it as complex as she did, i must say that it was way too sweet.  malternative drinkers would almost find this over the top sweet.

important to not drink too cold. Anyway, this definitely smells like raspberries. Looks like a bubbly merlot. Not really a whole lot to say. Tastes like raspberry jam. Tart, a bit cloying. Violently overrated. It may be beer, but Im not a huge fan. And like I said, do NOT serve very cold, as it concentrates the sweetness. Simple and cloying, not much else.

UPDATED: JUN 27, 2005 Cracked this puppy open and immediately thought I opened a jar of Rasberry jam.  Reaks of rasberry jam which I love!  Color is a dark reddish color.  Taste is obviously rasberry but I detected tastes of wheat and a oaky taste as well.  A great fruit beer even though it isnt my favorite style.  This would be perfect compliment to dessert, perhaps cheesecake?

For rating #100 I decided to use this delicacy!!!! It had a luscious slippery pour and a mouth watering fruit overtone that reminds me of melted raspberry sorbet with a pinch of alcohol added to it. The tartness seems pretty slight as the sweetness exuberates. Thank you Akilla for sharing!

Raspberries Raspberries Raspberries Raspberries Raspberries Raspberries Raspberries Raspberries Raspberries Raspberries Raspberries Raspberries Raspberries Raspberries Raspberries Raspberries Raspberries Raspberries Cloudy pink, with a pinkish head. Can you guess what the aroma is? Can you?Oh, and heres a shocker - the flavor is mouth watering, uncompromising raspberries. Just wonderful. New Glarus really know how to make a real beer with pitch-perfect fruit character.

Facto!  You brought a great number of excellent brews, this being only one.  Thank you!  I could not believe the look of this beer.  Very thick, mauve color.  Like velvet drapes at the theater.  The aroma is strong with a tart sweetness.  Raspberry abounds.  The flavor was intense!  Very tart and crisp raspberry overpowers all your senses.  The body is warm and lingering.  Just fantastic!  My wife thought this was the bees knees!  Not sure I could drink a lot of this but it would not keep me from picking up a couple of bottles.  I think we need to work a trade, Facto

A reddish pink color with a solid pink head. The aroma is raspberries and more raspberries. Same with the flavor. The taste is amazing, sweet upfront, sour back stage. I could drink this stuff all day.

bottle. crimson coloured body with a medium pink head.juicy raspberries in the nose - rather sweet and floral. This is a very well made fruit beer, these guys certainly know what they are doing. Tons of juicy raspberry present in the body. finish leaves a sugar residue. Superb balance. A classic fruit beer.

Sharp, tart raspberry aroma with acrid tobacco-like notes.  Opaque dark reddish-brown with partial cover of fine-bubbled pinkish-white head that lasts nicely and laces.  Sweet-tart balance is like a fresh fruit purée or natural jam.  Medium body is thick and juicy with fairly low carbonation that suits very well.  Sampled at Mondial de la Bière 2005.

Couleur rouge foncée aux vagues reflets brunâtres.  Mousse rose pâle peu abondante.  Arômes très crédibles et réels de confitures de fraises, tarte aux fraises et rhubarbe.  On sent bien la pureté du fruit mais en version sucrée et concentrée.  Peu acide en bouche, semble passablement tartrique, mais le sucre vole un peu la vedette à cet aspect.  Belle texture en bouche, épaisseur moyenne.  Échantillon mondial de la bière, Juin 2005.

UPDATED: APR 19, 2008 Sampled at le Mondial de la bière 2005. Pours a murky dark red color with a thin pink head. Amazing aroma of raspberries. Excellent flavor of raspberries with balanced acidity and sweetness, as with the Belgian Red I feel that the strength of this beer is its balance. The body is medium with a creamy texture, the carbonation is soft. Wow, excellent !

Wonderful ruby color with a thin but lasting pink head. Rich raspberry aroma with some malty and spicy notes. Taste is simply awesome. It is liquorice, perfectly balanced, and leaves a long sour/fruity aftertaste. Superb example of a fruitbeer!

Almost clear, light ruby with a strawberry, flimy head.  Aroma=very fresh raspberries!!! and some malt.  Flavour=very fresh raspberries!!! and some crisp malt.  Light body and a bit sweet, but pleasantly mouth puckeringly tart.  You feel this one in your ears!

better and different than their cherry. I appreciate raspberries, raspberry tea. This was very natural in every way, colour, odour, freshness, and a meal in itself. Mondial 2005. Sweet to start, with tartness in middle, and finshes with refreshing sweeter aftertaste.

Verre de dégustation (provenant dune bouteille verte de 750 ml) au Mondial de la Bière 2005 (Montréal, QC). Arôme: Forte odeur de framboises fraîchement écrasées. Apparence: Couleur rouge moyennement foncée. Mince col crémeux de couleur rose. Presque aucune bulle. Fine dentelle. Saveur: Fort goût de framboises. On a limpression de goûter un concentré plusquun jus. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Corps moyen avec une texture de coulis très liquide. Arrière goût de framboises mais qui laisse un sensation de craie dans la bouche. (Rating #164)
Mondial de la Bière de Montréal 2005. Comme une choulette. Acide-sucré bien balancé. Arômes et saveurs de fruits très plaisant.

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2015 Bottle at Mondial 2005.  Aroma is more of acidic sour raspberries that is mildly pungent.  Very lambic-like in aroma.  Nice transparent ruby color with a touch of orange color and a small pinkish head.  Very sweet to start, almost sugar cane-like.  Turns sour and slightly more acidic in the middle.  Sweet finish.  A nice beer that is almost cloying to start, but finishes very nicely.  (7/5/8/4/15)~~~~~~RE=RATE~~~~~~~~~Aroma has tons of sweet, good raspberry notes.  So aromatic.  Really nice for what it is.  Body is an erythematous transparent color with a pinkish head present.  The head is fairly strong and medium.  Starts with a sweet, somewhat tart raspberry flavor.  Lingering acidity late.  Nice tartness.  Not too sweet or cloying.  Enjoyable, one-dimensional, straight-forward.  Good stuff.

750 mL bottle. Poured a translucent reddish plum-purple with a slight pinkish head that didnt hang around too long. The aroma from the bottle was raspberry jam...plain and simple, and very nice....after is warmed slightly one could detect some light caramel malt and woody aromas.  Initial raspberry sweet flavor gives way to the expected sour tart flavor...but not overly so.   For me this was full bodied with a smooth texture and moderately carbonated.  Splendid example of the fruit style.

Another excellent fruit beer from New Glarus. This one doesnt present the complexity of their Belgian Red (cherry), but instead is more straight to the point of raspberry flavor. So what we have here is a short head which is expected due to the acidity of the fruit, and a strong, deep red raspberry color. Flavor is pretty much a mix of 4/5 raspberry and 1/5 malt, and hops kick in rather surprisingly on the finish. The friends I shared this with are non-BeerRatians and thought Raspberry Tart would just be an overpriced wine cooler; instead they were impressed with the balance of this brew! Give it a try if you can find it.

Awesome red color.  Aroma is unmistakeably rasberry.  Hits me as soon as the bottle is popped.  Taste is rasberries, rasberry seeds, fresh rasberries, not very tart, just a bit sweet, more fresh rasberries, GO RASBERRY ><

Some like the cherry (red) better, but I actually like the Rasberry Tart just a small bit more.  I rate them the same, but if they are both sitting in front of me, Ill drink this one faster.  This is a fantastic beer with all the flavor you would expect without the disagreeable (to me anyhow) aftertaste most Belgians have.

750 mL bottle served in champagne flute.  Pour was deep reddish purple when held to light.. with a 1/4" raspberry head.  Sweet raspberry aroma.  Mouthfeel was very lively due to rather high carbonation.  Taste was like a basket of fresh tart raspberries.  The label does not lie in the least bit.  Only other flavor noted was a faint oakiness.  Very good flavor, but this was not really my style.

750 mL bottle, goblet.  Deep plum, slightly hazy hue.  Pink, frothy, medium head.  TONS of delicious raspberries.  Musty, woody, caramel aromas.  Heavily sweet, moderately acidic (tart) flavor becomes a moderately sweet, moderately acidic finish.  Medium full body, velvety texture, moderate carbonation.  The bottom line is: I *heart* NG fruit beers.
